<skos:Concept rdf:about="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ATMOSPHERIC WINDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Air in motion relative to the surface of the Earth. Since vertical
components&amp;nbsp;of atmospheric motion are relatively small especially near the
surface of the&amp;nbsp;Earth, meteorologists use the term to denote almost
exclusively the horizontal&amp;nbsp;(wind) component. Vertical winds are always
identified as such. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c47f6052-634e-40ef-a5ac-13f69f6f4c2a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="8297bc97-9531-40da-950b-ac7e9d6e1b55"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="385af5fe-ad73-4e04-9d51-675599fb0576"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="05cf5b56-0f86-4819-b713-1272b97b06c5"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="dcc6cbbf-23a0-4ae7-bfbd-6207d35c741f"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ef034881-8bf4-403f-a4ee-c68771769c93"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="858a80ff-5aa4-4590-b2e2-e88a802a6ee4"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="69526601-5607-46e0-954a-251249de80fe"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ebce0874-7635-4094-8ef4-968851873771"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="226d05da-dd0b-4314-919a-0b259ce724b5"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="8bb1dca3-9793-4120-b0ea-f27a5b81f259"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="841a7ac7-5981-4e93-895f-1b57c3d892a0"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="10685919-bc01-43e7-901a-b62ac44627f3"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="592d49c4-e8ae-4ab4-bf24-ae4a896d0637"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="eaeb5cdd-365f-4368-8e20-6defe111b3b4"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="a2cc8e02-3207-4c40-af41-9656404bac0a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ebce0874-7635-4094-8ef4-968851873771"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CONVECTION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">In meteorology, atmospheric (wind) motions that are predominently
vertical,&amp;nbsp;resulting in vertical transport and mixing of atmospheric
properties.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a2cc8e02-3207-4c40-af41-9656404bac0a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CONVERGENCE/DIVERGENCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Convergence is a distribution of wind movement that results in a net inflow
of&amp;nbsp;air into a particular region. Divergence is a distribution of wind
movement&amp;nbsp;that results in a net outflow of air from an area. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="eaeb5cdd-365f-4368-8e20-6defe111b3b4"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">STREAMFUNCTIONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A parameter of two-dimensional, nondivergent (wind) flow, the value of which
is&amp;nbsp;constant along each streamline.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="10685919-bc01-43e7-901a-b62ac44627f3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SURFACE WINDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The wind measured at a surface observing station. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="226d05da-dd0b-4314-919a-0b259ce724b5"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TURBULENCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A state of fluid flow in which the instantaneous (wind) velocities
exhibit&amp;nbsp;irregular and apparently random fluxuations so that in practice
only&amp;nbsp;statistical properties can be recognized and subjected to analysis.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="592d49c4-e8ae-4ab4-bf24-ae4a896d0637"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">UPPER LEVEL WINDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Generally, the wind speeds and directions at various levels in the
atmosphere&amp;nbsp;above the domain of surface weather observations, as determined
by any of the&amp;nbsp;methods of winds-aloft observation. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="841a7ac7-5981-4e93-895f-1b57c3d892a0"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">VERTICAL WIND MOTION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The component of wind motion rising perpendicular to the plane of the
horizon.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="858a80ff-5aa4-4590-b2e2-e88a802a6ee4"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">VORTICITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Measure of the rotational spin about an axis at some point within a fluid
(or&amp;nbsp;wind field).&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8297bc97-9531-40da-950b-ac7e9d6e1b55"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WIND CHILL</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A figure used to express the cooling effect of the combination of
particular&amp;nbsp;temperatures and air speed on exposed human skin.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="05cf5b56-0f86-4819-b713-1272b97b06c5"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WIND SHEAR</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A sudden variation in the vector of wind flow that is especially dangerous
to&amp;nbsp;aircraft during takeoff and landing. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ef034881-8bf4-403f-a4ee-c68771769c93"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WIND STRESS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The drag or tangential force per unit area exerted upon the earth's surface
by&amp;nbsp;moving air in the surface boundary layer.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="69526601-5607-46e0-954a-251249de80fe"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WIND TENDENCY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The character and amount of atmospheric wind change for a
three-hour or other specified period ending at the time of&#xd;
observation.  
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="385af5fe-ad73-4e04-9d51-675599fb0576"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FLIGHT LEVEL WINDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Winds experienced by an aircraft during flight level at any altitude.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="dcc6cbbf-23a0-4ae7-bfbd-6207d35c741f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WIND PROFILES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The vertical (or horizontal) representation of the distribution of winds, usually measured by remote sensing satellites and aircraft or wind profiling radars.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8bb1dca3-9793-4120-b0ea-f27a5b81f259"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BOUNDARY LAYER WINDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">1. The layer of fluid near a boundary that is affected by friction against that
boundary surface, and possibly by transport of heat and other variables (such&#xd;
as winds) across that surface. &#xd;
In meteorology, this is the atmospheric boundary layer. 2. In a physical or&#xd;
mathematical system, a region over which some property or term in the equations
varies rapidly, that is, over its full range; conversely, a region outside of&#xd;
which certain terms may be neglected. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="df160e31-ae45-41a4-9093-a80fe5303cea"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b26769a1-f023-4ab1-bc21-78ef2a5fd185"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CONIFERS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Conifers are pollen- and seed-bearing plants of the dominant group
of&amp;nbsp;gymnosperms; mostly evergreen, woody trees and shrubs with needle-like
or&amp;nbsp;scale-like leaves. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0168947c-5f28-46d8-b643-cb31af02a6de"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SUB-ATOMIC PARTICLE FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">These particles include atomic constituents such as electrons, protons, and&#xd;
neutrons (protons and neutrons are actually composite particles, made up of&#xd;
quarks), as well as other particles such as photons and neutrinos which are&#xd;
produced copiously in the sun. However, most of the particles that have been&#xd;
discovered and studied are not encountered under normal earth conditions; they&#xd;
are produced in cosmic rays and during scattering processes in particle&#xd;
accelerators.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="cad91f82-7e2a-43b7-b272-2dc77e2791f4"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="cad91f82-7e2a-43b7-b272-2dc77e2791f4"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR ENERGETIC PARTICLE FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Solar energetic particles are high energy particles occasionally emitted from
active areas on the Sun, associated with solar flares and coronal mass
ejections. The EarthÂ¿s magnetic field keeps them out of regions close to Earth
(except for the polar caps) but they can pose a hazard to space travelers far
from Earth. Solar energetic particles are somtimes referred to as solar cosmic
rays.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="57383ac5-614c-4b84-9202-e137b000422b"/>

</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="84510f18-a4e6-434c-a54c-44cc995e1af2"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TREE RINGS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the measurement and analysis of ancient tree rings to&#xd;
determine environmental conditions during that tree's lifetime and&#xd;
extrapolate that to climatic conditions. The study of tree rings related to
past climate conditions is called dendroclimatology. Variations in tree ring
widths from year to year are recognized as an important source of chronological
and climatic information. The width of a tree ring is a function of many
variables including tree species, age, availability of stored food within the
tree, soil nutrients, and climatic factors such as precipitation, sunshine
temperature, winds and humidity.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="486f2c33-2401-4292-9d74-8756ee95211f"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ARACHNIDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Arachnids are arthropods with a body divided into an anterior and
posterior&amp;nbsp;part.  The posterior section contains four pairs of legs.
Arachnids are almost&amp;nbsp;entirely terrestrial and mainly free living. &amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ae1c9b54-caf2-4726-b180-5c6544f09111"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HEAT FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The measurement of the heat flux or heat loss from open ocean areas within
the&amp;nbsp;sea ice pack is important for the study of energy balance in the polar
regions&amp;nbsp;and local and regional climatology. Heat loss through the open
water is 100&amp;nbsp;times more than through thick ice. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="3cdebef6-902d-4c1a-9d7e-7609f8ee6ef6"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE DEFORMATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ice that has been squeezed together, and in places, forced upwards&#xd;
and downwards. Some subdivisions of deformed ice are rafted ice, ridged&#xd;
ice, and hummocked ice.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a735d8ca-182c-4307-9305-186a065e84a4"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE DEPTH/THICKNESS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ice depth or thickness refers to the extent of the ice below the surface of
the&amp;nbsp;water. The term is also used in river and lake ice studies. Remote
sensing&amp;nbsp;techniques (particularly radar and microwave) have been used to
estimate ice&amp;nbsp;thickness as have recently declassified submarine
measurements of polar ice&amp;nbsp;thickness. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="87feb47e-aee3-42f1-8c39-5109d9d5422e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE EXTENT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The minimum or maximum length of the ice or ice edge into the open water.&#xd;
Also refers to the extent of the ice pack into the open ocean (which&#xd;
varies seasonally).  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="aa15804c-5f7f-40cc-b949-aa3e4418fc27"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE FLOES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Floe refers to any relatively flat piece of ice 20 m or more across. Floes&#xd;
are subdivided according to horizontal extent: small, medium, big, vast,&#xd;
giant.	&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="89fc22ca-326e-468c-ad3d-171c4ad34977"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE GROWTH/MELT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Melt of the ice can occur at various stages: puddle, thaw holes, dried&#xd;
ice, rotten ice, flodded ice, and frozen puddle. Developing sea ice (or&#xd;
growth) takes on the following stages: New Ice, Youg Ice, First-Year Ice,&#xd;
Old Ice. Lake Ice development goes through the following stages: New Lake&#xd;
Ice, Thin Lake Ice, Medium Lake Ice, Thick Lake Ice, and Very Thick Lake&#xd;
Ice.   &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a6c3e78f-f408-4b72-941a-f40e3d83dd60"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE ROUGHNESS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The small-scale variation in the relief of the terrain surface (in this&#xd;
case the surface of the ice). Remote sensing instruments, such as radar&#xd;
and microwave sensors, have been able to detect the degree of roughness of&#xd;
sea, lake, and river ice.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="2a664e2d-4e50-463a-af9f-b14b86eb42a7"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Measurements of the temperature of the sea ice and surrounding sea
surface&amp;nbsp;temperature. These measurements are usually obtained from remote
sensing&amp;nbsp;satellites. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f5d7cafc-13bf-4ec8-bc6e-a6d850fae5c8"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE TYPES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ice Types is a general term applied to sea, river, and lake ice to&#xd;
describe attributes such as age, stage of development or growth, or&#xd;
surface feature.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1151dc7e-7441-4a21-95b6-1d03a1053f60"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICEBERGS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A piece of ice that has broken off from the end of a glacier that terminates in
water. Only about 10 percent of its mass is above the surface of the water.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f523f73f-efcc-4193-b9e3-1161ed7f4881"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LEADS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any fracture or passage-way through ice which is navigable by surface&#xd;
vessels. Leads and other open water areas within the sea ice pack are also&#xd;
important in studies of the energy budget in the polar regions and in&#xd;
local and regional climatology.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ea85ea0b-1b7d-464a-9f8c-1f80383ffc51"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PACK ICE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pack ice refers to high concentrations of sea ice. When concentrations are&#xd;
60% or less, then the term drift ice is used. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="10a128a6-12d4-4bce-b25d-2ffc464182f4"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">POLYNYAS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any non-linear shaped opening enclosed by ice. May contain brash ice and/or&#xd;
be covered with new ice, nilas or young ice; sub-mariners refer to these&#xd;
as skylights. Polynyas are important in the study of the energy budget of&#xd;
the polar ocean and local and regional climatology. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8ed9f39d-986e-4b36-83f9-f29f6a4df89b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">REFLECTANCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The reflectance properties of ice bodies. A smooth ice surface will act as&#xd;
a near-specular reflector. As surface roughness increases, the reflection&#xd;
becomes diffuse. It is the ratio of the intensity of reflected radiation&#xd;
to that of the incident radiation on a surface. The suffix (-ance) implies&#xd;
a property of that particular specimen surface. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b6085d71-a7ee-4b65-9c9c-ff374bdc3974"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEA ICE AGE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The age of the sea ice is usually a distinction between first-year&#xd;
and multiyear ice. Multiyear sea ice is usually thicker, has more ridges,&#xd;
and can be more of a hinderance to ship travel than first-year ice.&#xd;
Microwave remote sensing studies have shown that first-year sea ice has a&#xd;
higher emissivity at the 1.55 cm wavelength than multiyear ice, thus&#xd;
making it possible to distinguish between different ice ages from&#xd;
satellites. Ice age can also be qualitatively determined using visible,&#xd;
infrared and radar wavelengths from satellites. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a47ab696-7ed9-4374-8965-c8996e61463d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEA ICE MOTION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Refers to the movement and direction of ice fields or floes. Ice&#xd;
motion processes include: diverging, compacting, and shearing. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="bb27bbb7-7bc4-4e38-833a-30e0a7861ccc"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEA ICE CONCENTRATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The ratio of the area of the water surface covered by ice as a fraction of&#xd;
the whole area. Sea ice concentration has been monitored by polar&#xd;
orbiting satellites at all wavelengths. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="32259124-81f7-4845-b2fb-6435d7bb5804"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SNOW MELT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The melting of snow on top of the sea ice. Yearly snow melt on sea ice can be&#xd;
derived from remote sensing satellites such as Nimbus-7 SMMR and SSM/I on the&#xd;
DMSP satellites. Snow melt onset is defined as the point in time when microwave
brightness temperatures increase sharply due to the presence of liquid water in
the snowpack.	 &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5575125b-7f15-4d46-ba47-f86de96a1a25"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SNOW DEPTH</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the thickness of snow pack throughout the year.        
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6e2f1371-05b1-41db-a6d9-bccd7cc2b3da"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEA ICE ELEVATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertains to the measurement of the surface height of the sea ice. In&#xd;
particular, sea ice elevation is measured by the radar altimeter on board the&#xd;
NASA IceSat satellite.	   &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="04fa9023-ab68-4dd0-a82e-abe685105a53"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SALINITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">How salty the water is.   Brine has a very high salinity.   Fresh water has a&#xd;
salinity of zero.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9d99408d-0d8b-4642-a2cb-edee8319fe1d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ISOTOPES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Isotopes are a form of an element with a certain number of neutrons, for&#xd;
example carbon exists in three isotopes: C12, C13, and C14. Some isotopes are&#xd;
naturally unstable and spontaneously decay at a fixed rate; other isotopes are&#xd;
stable.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d73e969a-4b66-4713-8d63-fa3cbb1e25e3"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9e5ec924-2fd3-4cbb-a7eb-ffde114d0cb9"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NITROGEN COMPOUNDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Nitrogen (N) is the most abundant constituent of the atmosphere (78.09%).
Nitrogen enters the atmosphere from volcanoes, and from the decay of organic
matter. It is removed from the atmosphere by nitrogen-fixing bacteria. Nitrogen
compounds are very reactive and play integral roles in the production and
destruction of ozone in the atmosphere. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b9c56939-c624-467d-b196-e56a5b660334"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="6a745a5e-829c-43f5-8d5a-6fb549e7b81b"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="9ca9519d-c62b-42ea-8c91-cad06cfc59cb"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="d92ae6cc-989b-45b8-92d3-68008356c2b0"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="b7bbed0f-24a1-44d8-a10d-92541cd2c05b"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="82a60ed8-5414-4ce0-858c-c50b27b12bc8"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="e82ebd1c-8241-4ca0-95a9-a6e1432519cd"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="6c5a6bbe-a12f-4030-9220-2013db36cf47"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="f8e65155-27c1-483e-a9b8-85399897c3ae"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="3c3b37d4-b934-4057-b8e4-438523ae88e3"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="cf08917f-4cef-456f-99b0-57dc468da877"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b9c56939-c624-467d-b196-e56a5b660334"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ATMOSPHERIC CHEMISTRY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Measurements of chemical constituents in the atmosphere including the
major&amp;nbsp;(non-H2O) greenhouse gases (CO2, CH4, CFC, N2O).&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c47f6052-634e-40ef-a5ac-13f69f6f4c2a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="b80a242d-d5f5-4a5f-976c-6f6fe2ab6b2c"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="d46a5046-e1c6-4a09-a2f1-db6a21eda611"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="9e5ec924-2fd3-4cbb-a7eb-ffde114d0cb9"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="19ab681c-bdd7-4793-bbdb-1ec498575314"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="4dd22dc9-1db4-4187-a2b7-f5b76d666055"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="2d36c283-2fe3-4a08-aeb3-6a8146e79bb3"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="d8dcfd36-f71c-499f-84f5-43da9fee26c5"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="4cc9b4fa-5097-447f-914c-eb90820938c6"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="6433e330-3797-4cf9-a8ba-d26d39624459"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6a745a5e-829c-43f5-8d5a-6fb549e7b81b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AMMONIA</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ammonia (NH3) is a reduced nitrogen gas and is emitted in large quantities from
animal feedstocks, sewerage plants, etc. Ammonia is very soluble in water and
is scavenged from the lower atmosphere by clouds. Ammonia is the most abundant
alkaline gas in the atmosphere and plays a large role in neutralizing acidity
from sulfuric and nitric acids via formation of the ammonium ion.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9e5ec924-2fd3-4cbb-a7eb-ffde114d0cb9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9ca9519d-c62b-42ea-8c91-cad06cfc59cb"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DINITROGEN PENTOXIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Dinitrogen pentoxide (N2O5) is formed from the reaction of the nitrate radical
with nitrogen dioxide. Higher in the atmosphere N2O5 is an effective reservoir
for active nitrogen.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9e5ec924-2fd3-4cbb-a7eb-ffde114d0cb9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b7bbed0f-24a1-44d8-a10d-92541cd2c05b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NITRIC ACID</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Nitric Acid (HNO3) is a corrosive, non-volatile, inorganic acid. It is&#xd;
formed by the conversion of nitrogen oxide into nitrogen dioxide, and then&#xd;
into nitric acid, which is highly water soluble.  This solubility allows&#xd;
easy removal of nitric acid from the troposphere into rain - commonly&#xd;
referred to as acid rain.  Nitric acid has a relatively low concentration&#xd;
in the atmosphere but provides an important role in the production of&#xd;
sulfuric acid by acting as a catalyst in the conversion of sulfur dioxide&#xd;
to sulfuric acid.   [T.E Graedel and Paul J.  Crutzen. Atmospheric Change:&#xd;
An Earth System Perspective. WH Freeman and Co, NY.1993.] &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9e5ec924-2fd3-4cbb-a7eb-ffde114d0cb9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="82a60ed8-5414-4ce0-858c-c50b27b12bc8"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NITRIC OXIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Nitric oxide (NO) is a colorless gas, the most common form of nitrogen emitted&#xd;
into the atmosphere, either by fuel combustion or due to natural emissions. &#xd;
Nitric oxide is interconverted with nitrogen dioxide fairly readily in the&#xd;
atmosphere, resulting in catalytic cycles leading to ozone formation in the&#xd;
troposphere and ozone loss in the stratosphere.    &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9e5ec924-2fd3-4cbb-a7eb-ffde114d0cb9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="3c3b37d4-b934-4057-b8e4-438523ae88e3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MOLECULAR NITROGEN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Nitrogen (N2) is a colorless, tasteless, odorless gas which makes up 78.1%&#xd;
of the atmosphere. Atmospheric nitrogen is converted by nitrogen fixation&#xd;
and nitrification into compounds used by plants and animals. In the far&#xd;
upper atmosphere, N2 is broken down when large numbers of energetic&#xd;
secondary electrons are produced and available to react with the N2. This&#xd;
leads to the eventual production of NO. (Crutzen, Paul J. and T.E.&#xd;
Graedel, Atmospheric Change. W.H. Freeman and Company, New York, 147.)&#xd;
(Webster's New World Dictionary. Prentice Hall, New York, 918.)  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9e5ec924-2fd3-4cbb-a7eb-ffde114d0cb9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f8e65155-27c1-483e-a9b8-85399897c3ae"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NITROGEN DIOXIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A reddish-brown, highly poisonous gas, with the chemical formula NO2. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9e5ec924-2fd3-4cbb-a7eb-ffde114d0cb9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e82ebd1c-8241-4ca0-95a9-a6e1432519cd"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NITROGEN OXIDES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Nitrogen Oxides - NOx (pronounced "nox") are produced from high&#xd;
temperature combustion in air. They are nitrogen oxide and nitrogen&#xd;
dioxide. [Science News; v146; 260-262; 1994] [Science; v242;555-558;1988.]&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9e5ec924-2fd3-4cbb-a7eb-ffde114d0cb9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="cf08917f-4cef-456f-99b0-57dc468da877"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NITROUS OXIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Nitrous oxide (N2O) is a by-product of biological activity of a&#xd;
symbiotic bacteria living in leguminous plant roots. This is a principal&#xd;
greenhouse gas that absorbs in the infrared wavelength region and&#xd;
unfortunately falls in an IR "window" between IR absorbing features of&#xd;
water and carbon dioxide (a characteristic of all the "trace" greenhouse&#xd;
gases with significant radiative forcing). It is also laughing gas used by&#xd;
medicine as a gentle general anesthetic. [Nature;v335;528-529;1988]&#xd;
[Atmospheric sulfur and nitrogen oxides;George Hidy;p13;1986;Academic&#xd;
press; New York]  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9e5ec924-2fd3-4cbb-a7eb-ffde114d0cb9"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">INCOMING SOLAR RADIATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">In general, solar radiation received at the earth's surface. The amount of&#xd;
direct solar radiation incident upon a unit horizontal surface at a specific&#xd;
level on or above the surface of the earth. &#xd;
Incoming solar radiation is solar radition that has not been scattered or&#xd;
absorbed. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ATMOSPHERIC RADIATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Radiation budget refers to the difference between the absorbed solar
radiation&amp;nbsp;and the net infrared radiation. The radiation budget takes into
account the sum&amp;nbsp;of all radiation, transferred in all directions, through
the Earth's atmosphere&amp;nbsp;and to and from space. The radiation budget (or
radiation balance) controls the&amp;nbsp;Earth's temperature and rainfall.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c47f6052-634e-40ef-a5ac-13f69f6f4c2a"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8603db51-3484-4439-8b3b-a06f48e8c686"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GLACIERS/ICE SHEETS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Glaciers are masses of land ice, formed by the further recrystallization of&#xd;
firn, flowing continuously from higher to lower elevations. Ice sheets are a&#xd;
continuous sheet of land ice that covers a very large area and moves outward in
many directions. This type of ice mass is so thick as to mask the land surface&#xd;
contours, in contrast to the smaller and thinner highland ice. The continental&#xd;
glacier of Greenland is sometimes called the Inland Ice. This term is often&#xd;
used to describe the great ice masses that characterized the ice ages. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="fa0a36c3-2503-4662-98cd-7f3e74ce9f80"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="399a84d1-ccf5-4167-a699-15eb7d1ad1e6"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="bf19f1d1-ae18-4ff2-95f6-dc0ed812c568"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a43850a1-7b00-4993-80ff-753c2b5c4015"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PALMER DROUGHT SEVERITY INDEX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The Palmer Index or the Palmer Drought Severity Index (PDSI) is an index&#xd;
formulated by Palmer (1965) and compares the actual amount of precipitation&#xd;
received in an area during a specified period with the normal or average amount
expected during that same period.&#xd;
&lt;P&gt;&#xd;
The PDSI is based on a procedure of hydrologic or water balance accounting by&#xd;
which excesses or deficiences in moisture are determined in relation to average
climatic values.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="f50672b3-13d8-4206-b6c9-a1f9891ea470"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">COASTAL PROCESSES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Scientific field of study of the land environment immediately affected
by&amp;nbsp;marine processes. Includes variables pertaining to both coastal
features and&amp;nbsp;the processes that affect them.&amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="7863ce31-0e06-42a5-bcf8-25981c44dec8"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the measurement of the Earth's magnetic field through the
world's&amp;nbsp;oceans to detect variances in the oceanic crust.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Scientific field of study pertaining to the physics of the oceanic crust

morphological&amp;nbsp;features, geophysical processes of the marine environment,
and geophysical&amp;nbsp;measurements of the marine environment.&amp;nbsp;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any fracture or passage-way through ice which is navigable by surface&#xd;

important in studies of the energy budget in the polar regions and in&#xd;
local and regional climatology.  &#xd;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any non-linear shaped opening enclosed by ice. May contain brash ice and/or&#xd;

as skylights. Polynyas are important in the study of the energy budget of&#xd;
the polar ocean and local and regional climatology. &#xd;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6ee1f87a-dc7a-48f7-9b0f-9c529a5645a5"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TSUNAMIS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A long-period (usually 15-60 minutes) wave caused by a large-scale movement of&#xd;
the sea floor, from a volcanic eruption, submarine earthquake, or landslide&#xd;
although usually barely noticeable at sea, its velocity may be as high as 400&#xd;
knots, so that it travels great distances and in shoal water may reach heights&#xd;
of around 15 meters. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="39f5a91f-c5b6-4aa9-a0c6-05530306f17b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="39f5a91f-c5b6-4aa9-a0c6-05530306f17b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MARINE ADVISORIES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reports providing information on changes in environmental factors including
warnings of potential threat to life, property, resources, and/or the
environment arising from hazards in and around navigable water.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="09d00879-6d96-4df4-9f50-73bd761118d9"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="6ee1f87a-dc7a-48f7-9b0f-9c529a5645a5"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="c1111b23-9946-497a-8829-b58da3fce720"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="a4aea007-d297-4051-8b41-5cdde00b4d1e"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="3de6fa74-bb80-4bc6-ae60-1e6fe8ae6c67"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="d8aee072-097c-496f-8fe7-b65605fc1103"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="c5563d03-2f68-4dac-a50b-3b8450725356"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="f04be06d-5976-43d0-94cb-91d5c487d57c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9337898d-68dc-43d7-93a9-6afdb4ab1784"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">VISIBILITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The greatest distance from an observer that a prominent object of
known&amp;nbsp;characteristics can be seen and unidentified by unaided, normal
eyes.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="77397026-09c9-44e0-b85f-77b2bc9b1630"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6ee8d84e-c829-44e2-8768-3e5342b79707"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BIBLIOGRAPHIC DATABASES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A computerized file consisting of electronic entries or records, each of
which&amp;nbsp;represents a document or bibliographic item retrievable by author,
title,&amp;nbsp;subject heading (descriptor), or keywords. Although some
bibliographic&amp;nbsp;databases are general in scope and coverage, most are
indexes and abstracting&amp;nbsp;services which provide access to the literature of
a specific field or&amp;nbsp;discipline.	 &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="61f4f3d0-7895-4cce-94e3-d249001d5ee8"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MOLECULAR OXYGEN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Oxygen (O2) is found on Earth as a gas and constitutes about 20.8% of the&#xd;
air we breathe. Elemental molecular oxygen consists of two oxygen atoms&#xd;
bonded together. A photochemical reaction of oxygen is (ultimately)&#xd;
responsible for the production of ozone in the stratosphere. Oxygen&#xd;
concentrations found in ice core samples have been used to determine past&#xd;
atmospheric levels of oxygen and helped in determining past climates.&#xd;
[Nature; v351; 217-219; 1991.] [Nature; v365; 143-147; 1993.]  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4cc9b4fa-5097-447f-914c-eb90820938c6"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4cc9b4fa-5097-447f-914c-eb90820938c6"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">OXYGEN COMPOUNDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Oxygen (O) (and molecular oxygen (O2)) is the second most abundant species in
the atmosphere. The abundance of O2 remains fairly constant in the atmosphere
up to about 80km where it photodissociates to atomic oxygen. Atomic oxygen is
formed from the photolysis of molecular oxygen (O2), ozone (O3), or nitrogen
dioxide (NO2) in the atmosphere. Below about 40 km, atomic oxygen recombines
with O2 to form ozone. Above 40 km, oxygen can participate in other chemical
reactions that cause the destruction of ozone.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b9c56939-c624-467d-b196-e56a5b660334"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="61f4f3d0-7895-4cce-94e3-d249001d5ee8"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="dd316647-9043-40c3-9329-f22f9215fefa"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5c4b5f03-8e57-49f0-bb03-f8efafb837d3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MACROFAUNA</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">"Macrobiota" is a general term for the larger soil organisms. Macrofauna, in
particular, refers to burrowing vertebrate animals, but may include larger
insects and earhworms.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a9b89557-c09f-4a4a-a1eb-47c632f8eb59"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CARBON DIOXIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">One of the major greenhouse gases. Human-generated carbon dioxide is
caused&amp;nbsp;mainly by the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation. The
chemical formula&amp;nbsp;for carbon dioxide is CO2. Long-term measurements of CO2
in the atmosphere are&amp;nbsp;conducted at Manua Loa, Hawaii and several
international monitoring stations&amp;nbsp;around the world.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8c02f5d1-ce86-4bf5-84d5-b3496cdba6ad"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8c02f5d1-ce86-4bf5-84d5-b3496cdba6ad"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WATER QUALITY/WATER CHEMISTRY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Water quality refers to the physical, chemical, and biological characteristics&#xd;

refers to the chemical characteristics of water.&#xd;

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MAMMALS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The class Mammals are warm-blooded craniates with glandular skin which
is&amp;nbsp;typically hairy; Young are fed on milk secreted by mammary glands.
Mammals are&amp;nbsp;mostly terrestrial in all habitats from forest to desert, but
some fly and some&amp;nbsp;inhabit freshwater or the sea.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e5815f58-8232-4c7f-b50d-ea71d73891a9"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LAND USE/LAND COVER</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The observed physical cover and natural use of the land including the&#xd;
vegetation and human construction, which covers the earth's surface. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6a426480-c58f-4b6b-8e35-0975b7f6edb5"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="dad75074-b2f7-4cb7-ae02-02d054f18251"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DATA REFORMATTING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reformatting services are defined as Data Handling Services that allow for the alteration of the structure of an Earth science data set so as to make the data set accessible for use by a product or service for which it was not originally compatible. EXAMPLES: Binary to ASCII, HDF to CDF.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="0f3573bc-3cb7-4cec-a5bb-1bb6b7ab9057"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="097a0fad-d822-49ad-bd12-232e9ea7cb30"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PERIGLACIAL PROCESSES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Of, or pertaining to, the outer perimeter of a glacier, particularly to the&#xd;
fringe areas surrounding the great continental glaciers of the geologic ice&#xd;
ages.  Thus, periglacial weathering is said to have produced certain&#xd;
characteristic&#xd;
land forms. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="376a1d5c-2496-4381-981f-bc047af92044"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="376a1d5c-2496-4381-981f-bc047af92044"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FROZEN GROUND</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Soil within which the moisture has predominantly changed to ice, the unfrozen&#xd;
portion being in vapor phase. &#xd;
Ice within the soil bonds (adfreezes) adjacent soil particles and renders&#xd;
frozen ground very hard. Permanently frozen ground is called permafrost. Dry&#xd;
frozen ground is relatively loose and crumbly because of the lack of bonding&#xd;
ice. Frozen ground is sometimes inadvisedly called frost or ground frost. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="fa0a36c3-2503-4662-98cd-7f3e74ce9f80"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="b1ce822a-139b-4e11-8bbe-453f19501c36"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="2e544263-d92f-46c2-9568-25e36d0b9825"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="4931dcac-8b89-4bc9-ba59-469cfdcf6f12"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="2a109b2f-947a-4c2c-9db9-ae315a53ef93"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="c82f3480-545f-4491-83f1-0477369ddcd8"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="097a0fad-d822-49ad-bd12-232e9ea7cb30"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="021714ad-1cae-441c-bb6f-4be866a0f742"/>

   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BAROMETRIC ALTITUDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Also called Pressure Altitude. Barometric Altitude is the altitude&#xd;
which corresponds to a given value of atmospheric pressure according to&#xd;
the ICAO standard atmosphere. It is the indicated altitude of a pressure&#xd;
altimeter at an altimeter setting of 29.92 inches of mercury (1013.2&#xd;
mb); therefore it is the indicated altitude above the 1013.2 mb&#xd;
constant-pressure surface. RT&#xd;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="16bfcf54-f8e1-4c8e-9bd4-a1ac06ea95a0"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A measure of height, especially of great height, as a mountain top or
aircraft&amp;nbsp;flight level. In meteorology, altitude is used almost exclusively
with respect&amp;nbsp;to the height of an airborne object above the earth's
surface, above a constant&amp;nbsp;pressure surface, or above mean sea level.

<skos:Concept rdf:about="990016e0-f247-4c36-8a17-f50e792a964a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GEOMAGNETIC INDICES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Geomagnetic indices are an indicator of geomagntic activity caused by solar&#xd;
events. Typical geomagntic indices are: a, A, Ap, Dst, K, and Kp.   The
A-index,&#xd;
for example, is a daily average composed of 3-hour data points.  Geomagnetic&#xd;
indices can be used in conjunction with solar"wind" data to predict the onset&#xd;
and intensity of geomagnetic storms.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3a942e8a-d2f2-42bf-9e83-b7b3793b100e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="3a942e8a-d2f2-42bf-9e83-b7b3793b100e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">IONOSPHERE/MAGNETOSPHERE DYNAMICS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Refers to dynamic processess of the Earth's ionosphere and solar magnetosphere&#xd;
triggered by solar events. The magnetosphere is the magnetic cavity surrounding
the earth, carved out of the passing solar wind by virtue of the geomagnetic&#xd;
field, which prevents, or at least impedes, the direct entry of the solar wind&#xd;
plasma into the cavity. The ionosphere is the region of the earth's upper&#xd;
atmosphere containing a small percentage of free electrons and ions produced by
photoionization of the constituents of the atmosphere by solar ultraviolet&#xd;
radiation at very short wavelengths (l.t.1000 angstroms).  The ionosphere&#xd;
significantly influences radiowave propagation of frequencies less than about&#xd;
30 MHz.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="57383ac5-614c-4b84-9202-e137b000422b"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="8cbdfa00-852c-452d-8013-86145ad318c8"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="5d290bd8-049b-4002-86c8-8acba563d0e1"/>

update Definition (Desertification is the formation of deserts in arid and semi-arid regions from overgrazing, deforestation, poor agricultural practices, and climate change. Evidence of desertification can be found today in Africa, the
Middle East, and the southwestern United States.);

</skos:changeNote>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f1682ed1-2d9c-41ec-9553-49b9ab55df9b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HABITAT CONVERSION/FRAGMENTATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The change of land quality, for example through land transformation or intensification of land use. Common reasons for habitat conversion are deforestation/reforestation, suburbanization, corridor construction, desertification and agricultural intensification, e.g. wetland drainage, irrigation or degradation due to
overgrazing.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="fb93d937-c17c-45d0-a9e3-ca5c8a800ca8"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="32777aa3-a06a-4719-bbe5-7dcecb1a06f5"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="dee57819-62c7-4f89-87e5-90a87a07820a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="39a032bf-c3bc-481b-9698-8be114fe85cb"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="59b3849e-6704-402f-9a3e-512db10c2f51"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="aa4a9df3-0fed-4512-b158-ed369463e33a"/>

</skos:changeNote>
   <skos:changeNote>2012-07-02 15:39:38.0 [tbs1979]  
update Definition (HABITAT CONVERSION: The change of land quality, for example through land transformation or intensification of land use. Common reasons for habitat conversion are deforestation/reforestation, suburbanization, corridor construction, desertification and agricultural intensification, e.g. wetland drainage, irrigation or degradation due to
overgrazing.

HABITAT FRAGMENTATION: 
breaking up of a continuous habitat, ecosystem, or land-use type into smaller
fragments, which is considered to be one of several spatial processes in land
transformation. It is commonly used in relation to the fragmentation of
forests. Habitat fragmentation is mainly caused by human activities such as
logging, conversion of forests into agricultural areas and suburbanization, but
can also be caused by natural processes such as fire.); 
update Definition (From the Global Terrestrial Observing System (GTOS) Terrestrial Ecosystem Monitoring Sites (TEMS) database. "http://www.fao.org/gtos/tems/index.jsp" ); 
</skos:changeNote>
   <skos:changeNote>2012-06-27 14:10:12.0 [tbs1979] Move Concepts 
add narrower relation (HABITAT CONVERSION/FRAGMENTATION [f1682ed1-2d9c-41ec-9553-49b9ab55df9b,20183] - URBANIZATION [e759cacb-33f0-4564-b151-c7cfa5e85ed3,21607]); 
</skos:changeNote>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="fe4a246b-4614-422b-8ca5-0481ee417318"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">POTENTIAL DENSITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Measurement of water density taking water's compressibility into
account,&amp;nbsp;provided no heat exchange of the water sample with its
surroundings.  This is&amp;nbsp;important because of the potential temperature
change of water at varying&amp;nbsp;levels of pressure.  That is, under high
pressure, water is warmer (less&amp;nbsp;potentially dense) than that same sample
of water at low pressure (lower&amp;nbsp;potential temperature and thus more
potentially dense).    &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a46016d7-e571-403a-ab37-7223fd74e68e"/>
</skos:Concept>

salinity or&amp;nbsp;density are included under this Term.   &amp;nbsp;

the oceans. Oxidized in the marine atmosphere to partially form cloud&#xd;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b80a242d-d5f5-4a5f-976c-6f6fe2ab6b2c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SULFUR COMPOUNDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Sulfur is the fourteenth most abundant element in the Earth's crust. Sulfur is
consistently exchanged between the lithosphere, biopsphere, hydrosphere, and
atmosphere. Sulfur in the atmosphere, in both gaseous and aerosol form, has
imapcts on regional and global chemistry, climate change, and the health of
living organisms. Sulfur gases can also affect stratospheric chemistry.
Carbonyl sulfide (OCS) and volcanic emissions may affect Earth's radiation
budget and climate as well as ozone destriction in the stratosphere.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b9c56939-c624-467d-b196-e56a5b660334"/>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TELECONNECTIONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A linkage between weather changes occuring in widely seperated regions of the
globe.&#xd;
The term "teleconnections" is most commonly applied to variability on monthly
or longer timescales and refers to the fact that such correlations suggest that
information is propagating between distant points through the atmosphere.

<skos:Concept rdf:about="61c3b720-abc8-4430-866c-f1da35d2cd0b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AEROSOL OPTICAL DEPTH/THICKNESS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The degree to which Aerosols prevent light from passing through.&amp;nbsp;Optical
depth/thickness depends upon the physical constitution&amp;nbsp;,the form, and the
concentration of particles.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e5a401b-1507-4f57-82b8-36557c13b154"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="6e7306a1-79a5-482e-b646-74b75a1eaa48"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="2e5a401b-1507-4f57-82b8-36557c13b154"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AEROSOLS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Suspension of particles of condensed matter (liquid, solid, or mixed) in
a&amp;nbsp;carrier gas (usually air).  Aerosols are important in the atmosphere as
nuclei&amp;nbsp;for the condensation of water droplets and ice crystals, as
participants in&amp;nbsp;various chemical cycles, and as absorbers and scatterers
of solar radiation,&amp;nbsp;thereby influencing the radiation budget of the
earth-atmosphere system, which&amp;nbsp;in turn influences the climate on the
surface of the Earth.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c47f6052-634e-40ef-a5ac-13f69f6f4c2a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="1b6342c6-315b-4f4f-b4e3-d6902aaa3e85"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="7db9eab3-4c7a-4471-a826-a306f178ad3e"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="f795b88f-1aba-4548-97f6-7b587e8ba451"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="61c3b720-abc8-4430-866c-f1da35d2cd0b"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ca71b02b-4446-414c-8697-0950d7382cc4"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="768cfa32-003d-47bd-ab3a-3e27e4ec2699"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="548a3f85-bf22-473b-b641-45c32d9c6a0c"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="40633fe2-5b32-4bdc-a17b-b1cfebc01ae7"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="27478148-b4b6-4c89-8829-08d2ee7bfe10"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6e7306a1-79a5-482e-b646-74b75a1eaa48"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ANGSTROM EXPONENT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Aerosol Angstrom Coefficient is an exponent that expresses the spectral dependence of aerosol optical thickness (Ï) with the wavelength of incident light (Î»). 

The spectral dependence of aerosol optical thickness can be approximated (depending on size distribution) by, 
Ïa = Î² Î»Î±   where   Î±   is Angstrom exponent (Î² = aerosol optical thickness at 1 Î¼m)

Angstrom exponent (computed from Ï measurements on two different wavelengths) can be used to find Ï on another wavelength using the relation.

The Angstrom exponent provides additional information on the particle size (larger the exponent, the smaller the particle size), aerosol phase function and the relative magnitude of aerosol radiances at different wavelengths.

</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="61c3b720-abc8-4430-866c-f1da35d2cd0b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e501d002-d11e-4569-8c0d-e40ae5b45f65"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ABSORPTION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A process by which incident radiation is taken into a body and&#xd;
retained without reflection or transmission. It increases either the&#xd;
internal or the kinetic energy of the molecules or atoms composing the&#xd;
absorbing medium. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="457883c4-b30c-4d26-bed8-6c2887ebbc90"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">COCCOLITHOPHORES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Coccolithophores are extremely small, flagellated organisms of the
Kingdom&amp;nbsp;Protista, which are adorned with buttons of calcium carbonate,
called&amp;nbsp;coccoliths.  The coccolithophores appear to contribute
significantly to marine&amp;nbsp;food chains by capturing radiant energy and
manufacturing food during&amp;nbsp;photosynthesis.	The coccolithophores make up a
considerable portion of the&amp;nbsp;microscopic life in warmer regions, such as
the Sargasso Sea. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="dc7d2770-86a3-463c-a92b-c61516ffb32a"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="dafb67df-dc6d-40a0-8d94-e4621d2538ce"

<skos:Concept rdf:about="fa9f54b2-a101-4faf-b1dc-b6dff141c08c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR FLARES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A sudden and violent release of matter and energy within a solar activity
region in the form of electromagnetic radiation, energetic particles, shock
waves, lasting a few minutes to hours.	Solar flares accelerate charged
particles into interplanetary space.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR ACTIVITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any change in the sun's appearance or behavior. The sun's activity&#xd;
is described as being very low, low, moderate, high or very high.&#xd;
Solar activity changes over a period of, on average, 11 years. At&#xd;
solar maximum, the solar activity is high and so too the Extreme&#xd;
Ultraviolet (EUV) radiation output which affects the ionosphere. At solar &#xd;
minimum, the opposite is true. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="57383ac5-614c-4b84-9202-e137b000422b"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="25aa0f7b-89a5-46d7-b3d3-622b60032661"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="88bd8ce6-334d-4a42-8d51-5ed074ef5a89"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="e4fcb001-f517-4295-89dd-73292e0bf3ee"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="a4390c3d-cffa-43ee-8e91-49c6d49ac371"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="6d486f25-7477-4da9-96ae-0091596ed4d2"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="33f0ec3e-cd6d-498c-9468-749741fc12e2"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="e2fc7768-955b-4e76-935e-d33805fcc914"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0b2ca4d1-a225-4243-90eb-1b482fb094a5"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TOTAL ELECTRON CONTENT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Total Electron Content (TEC) is the number of free electrons in a column of the
Earth's ionosphere. TEC is affected by geomagnetic storms and measurements of
TEC is crucial for calibrating measurements obtained by active radar and
altimeter instruments such as used on TOPEX/Poseidon. Measurements of TEC are a
by-product if sea surface height measurements and TEC global ionosphere
climatologies have been developed from TOPEX/Poseidon measurements.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a82d885e-34cd-496a-b34d-17a23ad04126"/>
</skos:Concept>
