<skos:Concept rdf:about="33e3c858-25ee-4a5e-a938-93779679ed06"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HALONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Halon: a compound consisting of bromine, fluorine, and carbon

Halons are used as fire extinguishing agents, both in built-in systems and in handheld portable fire extinguishers. Halon production in the U.S. ended on December 31, 1993, because they contribute to ozone depletion. They cause ozone depletion because they contain bromine. Bromine is many times more effective at destroying ozone than chlorine. At the time the current U.S. tax code was adopted, the ozone depletion potentials of halon 1301 and halon 1211 were observed to be 10 and 3, respectively. These values are used for tax calculations. Recent scientific studies, however, indicate that the ODPs are at least 12 and 6, respectively. Note: technically, all compounds containing carbon and fluorine and/or chlorine are halons, but in the context of the Clean Air Act, "halon" means a fire extinguishing agent as described above. A table of class I substances (http://www.epa.gov/ozone/science/ods/classone.html) shows their ODPs, GWPs, and CAS numbers. Halons are numbered according to a standard scheme.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d46a5046-e1c6-4a09-a2f1-db6a21eda611"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d46a5046-e1c6-4a09-a2f1-db6a21eda611"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HALOCARBONS AND HALOGENS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Halons are a group of brominated organic compounds used as fire retardants. The
transport of these compounds to the stratosphere, followed by their photolysis
to release Br (Bromine) atoms, gives this group a very high ozone depletion
potential. The production of these compounds is now banned according to the
Montreal Protocol.&#xd;
&lt;P&gt;&#xd;
Halogens are made up of the elements fluorine (F), chlorine (Cl), bromine (Br),
iodine (I), and astatine (At). The first four members are present in trace
amounts in the atmosphere as a result of both natural and anthropogenic
activity.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b9c56939-c624-467d-b196-e56a5b660334"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="33e3c858-25ee-4a5e-a938-93779679ed06"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="676248f0-75cd-466d-93f1-351440027c82"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="27d63fe6-9970-46fd-9b22-a58e52efc57b"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ff9f8056-84d6-4fbc-abe0-9b6e82ed3f5e"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="6f96d1bd-f6ba-437a-9079-c575c4822248"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="13588158-07b6-4294-a00c-fa095b6ad4fd"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="146a0a0b-1b42-41a6-b1f7-a27615b006a0"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ed5106fd-a73f-4203-87a3-9c9e7e85dcfc"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="39c478bd-620e-455c-904d-4621965e376c"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="9b6ca807-7719-48aa-864d-ebb45a519ff8"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="a9104127-6846-4123-8ab0-b65c61a0018d"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="e78ae4ce-807a-4417-ad6e-a458c6da6638"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="a56d397b-bff5-4a14-b54c-366470e023c7"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="1ecb1e7c-50fc-4951-b610-5140475d87ed"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="f6b97280-74d0-4233-bd17-f9f3d9dd21c2"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a4a3d233-581b-4171-bf16-41a1528a7dda"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PHASE AND AMPLITUDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Measurements related to the signal recorded by the sensor.&#xd;
&lt;I&gt;Phase&lt;/I&gt;: A property of a periodic phenomenon, for example a&#xd;
wave, referring to its starting point or advancement (fraction) relative&#xd;
to an arbitrary origin.  For example, the angle of a complex number (ie.,&#xd;
the waves are out-of-phase).	&lt;I&gt;Amplitude&lt;/I&gt;: Measure of the strength&#xd;
of a signal, and in particular the strength or "height" of an&#xd;
electromagnetic wave (units of voltage). &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8799f524-e313-4d2d-9428-8d672d123513"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="96400b5a-6932-41f2-a80c-5aba26a2b5de"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR-ATMOSPHERE/SPACE-WEATHER MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Solar-Atmosphere/Space Weather Models typically deal with
Solar-Earth/Atmosphere interactions and warning/prediction systems. These
models are important for telecommunications and all science, commercial
research, and operational satellites. These models also forecast solar particle
fluxes, and indices of solar and geomagnetic activity.	   
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="894f9116-ae3c-40b6-981d-5113de961710"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="0a22b06c-eeed-46dc-b41b-af44ca94c419"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="46461db7-88ba-446f-bdae-2d1e7f6302c2"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="f96bf6c8-2f34-412a-b734-b2644f08a329"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="1eb8b98b-73a1-4657-beda-76ab6355dd08"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="c61a56a3-c08f-4989-92f3-0f0787688424"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ea5ccefb-e390-43d5-8202-33e004565beb"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="e5f94c93-e8af-4919-827f-9059dab9cf27"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="adfee6d2-ca00-4f02-a570-5ccf0850cb55"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="93809fc5-da7c-4ca2-9585-70f09bd99898"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="9a1dd3c3-a126-437e-ad04-9dc0a382d567"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="e49f0aae-c2ef-4fd2-aaf4-ddfad074bb75"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="b8615aad-d2eb-45a3-98a7-4adac5bdf5a5"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="52a32bd3-d701-49e1-a827-67b3d96d8e56"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEA SURFACE SLOPE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The slope of the ocean water surface, resultant from a geophysical
phenomenon&amp;nbsp;such as dynamic circulation or tides.  This variable does not
refer to wave&amp;nbsp;slope.       &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="68f93a0c-1525-4f5a-9545-5d94191a3dbf"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="68f93a0c-1525-4f5a-9545-5d94191a3dbf"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEA SURFACE TOPOGRAPHY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">To measure sea surface height, or surface topography, scientists need&#xd;
to obtain the precise distance between the satellite and the center of&#xd;
the Earth and the precise distance between the satellite and the sea&#xd;
surface. Sea surface height is then calculated by subtracting the&#xd;
distance between the sea surface and the satellite from the distance&#xd;
between the center of the Earth and the satellite. The distance between&#xd;
the satellite and the center of the Earth is obtained by carefully&#xd;
monitoring the satellite position at all times.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="91697b7d-8f2b-4954-850e-61d5f61c867d"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="52a32bd3-d701-49e1-a827-67b3d96d8e56"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="5c0b448c-7eb4-4e8c-8403-260cbb6114bb"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9c974992-0ec2-4c55-9ab9-e8158f446fe7"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PRIAPULANS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="abc6f016-d1f0-4725-b847-639de054d13f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d1c2bba5-799d-412b-80e0-fa04058416e3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NITROUS OXIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A colorless gas, made up of two atoms of univalent nitrogen and one atom
of&amp;nbsp;oxygen, N2O. In the ocean, it is formed as a minor product of
bacterial&amp;nbsp;nitrification and denitrification. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6eb3919b-85ce-4988-8b78-9d0018fd8089"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b677862b-7921-458f-a6db-0eb46469df33"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HYDROTHERMAL VENTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the fractures in the oceanic crust where superheated water
is&amp;nbsp;ejected into the ocean, providing a source of minerals, and unusual
life forms.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e3b178eb-2d47-41db-aba1-43a05e9e9256"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="7e28f2e0-a641-4085-be07-366ed6e701f4"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BARRIER ISLANDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Elongate sand bar formed parallel to the shore in areas of
considerable&amp;nbsp;sediment flux, but separated from shore by a lagoon, and
pierced at intervals&amp;nbsp;by inlets through which the sea communicates with
lagoon and river.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4ba798ce-ad0b-4809-94fa-ec1b8e294252"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BEACHES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A zone of unconsolidated particles extending from below water level to the
edge&amp;nbsp;of the coastal zone.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1fbf5df2-ab7c-43fc-9bb2-8eb3f8891f7b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">COASTAL ELEVATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Vertical height of the land along the coast, measured from a datum such as
mean&amp;nbsp;sea level.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ad497e7a-48fa-45e1-90a5-b052508bdb30"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CORAL REEFS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A mass of calcium carbonate rock material derived from coral organisms,
algae,&amp;nbsp;mollusks, worms, etc.  Also used as pertaining to the living
biological aspects&amp;nbsp;of the reef.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f9f0f92b-7901-4dda-8d64-be4e845ce29b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DELTAS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The deposit of sediments found at the mouth of a river.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="cd7a7748-7231-4a73-b85c-b5696066230a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">EROSION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The process by which soil, rock or sand is gradually worn away by water or
wind&amp;nbsp;action.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a7dcdedf-bcc5-4032-b70f-7fadf74d6144"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ESTUARIES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A semi-enclosed body of water near a coastline where fresh water mixes
with&amp;nbsp;ocean water.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a90899c8-fe50-48e0-b92c-bb64f6ae681c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FJORDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A deep narrow estuary in a valley originally cut by a glacier.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f43cd776-c568-4d09-997c-0a8ad1022e06"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">INLETS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A passage giving the ocean access to an enclosed lagoon, harbor, or bay.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="82b62e59-6ea1-48e1-a402-bd386c5046eb"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">INTERTIDAL ZONE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The marine zone between the highest high tide point on a shoreline and
the&amp;nbsp;lowest low tide point.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c733c179-c12a-47e9-8e9a-817a5212446f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LAGOONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A shallow body of seawater generally isolated from the ocean by a
barrier&amp;nbsp;island or coral reef, or enclosed within an atoll.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5a090f0c-7466-47fd-b679-5dee947ab05c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LOCAL SUBSIDENCE TRENDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Sinking of the land due to tectonic or isostatic processes.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ccf07d90-b3a3-43d3-9249-a494bb48d1b6"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LONGSHORE CURRENTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A current running parallel to shore in the surf zone, caused by the
incomplete&amp;nbsp;refraction of waves approaching the beach at an angle.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="04c4a85f-91ce-4d64-9e19-b3e0897ff187"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MANGROVES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the environment of large flowering shrubs or trees growing
in&amp;nbsp;dense thickets or forests along muddy or silty tropical coasts.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="30056645-a442-4ef6-ac76-c5bc27086d83"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MARSHES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the environment of dense grasses (typically
salt-tolerant&amp;nbsp;cordgrasses of the genus Spartina) growing on broad, flat
coastal areas,&amp;nbsp;characterized by muddy substrate and periodic tidal
draining and flooding.   &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="488f4df2-712e-4fac-98d1-46ab134b84ee"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ROCKY COASTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the environment of rock-dominated shorelines,
often&amp;nbsp;characterized by high-energy wave action, and often common along
isostatically&amp;nbsp;rebounding coastlines.         &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="dffe5a35-09af-4413-bdd3-a5aedfeb49cc"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SALTWATER INTRUSION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The intrusion of saline marine water into fresh groundwater supplies
along&amp;nbsp;coasts, often due to the extraction of fresh groundwater for human
consumption.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0afaaa5e-f88c-4c1f-95c1-1faa0148885a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEA LEVEL RISE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An increase in the average height of the sea surface over a vertical datum.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6fd22ab-dca7-4dfa-8812-913453b5695b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1ed24fe1-d0d5-46d1-8d22-8ac25d289c75"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEA SURFACE HEIGHT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The height of the ocean surface above a datum, such as a vertical datum

altimetric&amp;nbsp;measurements.    &amp;nbsp;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A rise above normal sea level on the coast where the Ekman effect, from

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The height of the ocean surface above a datum, varying as a result of the

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BOWEN RATIO</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The ratio of the amount of sensible to that of latent heat lost by a surface&#xd;
to the atmosphere by the processes of conduction and turbulence. See J. M.&#xd;
Lewis. The story behind the Bowen ratio.  Bull. Am. Meteor. Soc.,&#xd;
76:-2443, 1995.   &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="63bc0693-52eb-4ebd-a39e-e77e96409072"/>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ECHINODERMS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The phylum Echinoderms is a wholly marine group whose members include
the&amp;nbsp;familiar starfish and sea urchins often found on the shore. Some of
their&amp;nbsp;particular features are their five-sided adult symmetry, their
endoskeleton&amp;nbsp;which consists of many small crystals of calcium carbonate
and tube feet, which&amp;nbsp;are outward manifestations of their water vascular
system.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A property whereby substances are injurious to health when ingested or

<skos:Concept rdf:about="63015ca3-455b-4d91-b047-ff83a95d6bbe"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RED ALGAE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e731c2a1-e4b0-42e9-bed9-bd911c9b496c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e731c2a1-e4b0-42e9-bed9-bd911c9b496c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MACROALGAE (SEAWEEDS)</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Macroalgae, or seaweeds, are the dominant marine plants inhabiting
temperate&amp;nbsp;coasts. Macroalgae contain chlorophyll and an assortment of
additional pigments&amp;nbsp;spanning the visible spectrum from blue to red.
Historically, classification was&amp;nbsp;based on pigmentation. At present, the
classification of marine algae relies on&amp;nbsp;additional diagnostic
characteristics. Although pigmentation is only one of the&amp;nbsp;characteristics
used to classify the algae, the original names, which were based&amp;nbsp;on color,
have been retained. The major divisions of seaweed are green
algae&amp;nbsp;(Chlorophyta), red algae (Rhodophyta), and brown algae
(Phaeophyta).&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="0b4081fa-5233-4484-bc82-706976defa0e"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="36e07e20-ce85-4418-83fd-6d718e55f370"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="63015ca3-455b-4d91-b047-ff83a95d6bbe"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="4fb63f34-f934-4a20-9d6e-ee57424f2391"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="61594015-4ab4-4b38-ae4f-e31a4757b065"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WATER TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A measure of the average kinetic energy of the vibration of water molecules.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8c02f5d1-ce86-4bf5-84d5-b3496cdba6ad"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="2eb094d5-70bc-49fa-acb6-4ad07f4c7b08"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HYDROLOGIC AND TERRESTRIAL WATER CYCLE MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Models that relate to the water cycle and hydrological analysis (chemistry and&#xd;
physics of water) predictions in the Terrestrial Hydrosphere. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="934bd870-ffa8-41d8-8da9-214b73707168"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MOSSES/HORNWORTS/LIVERWORTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Mosses and Liverworts belong to the Phylum Bryophyta, Class Musci
and&amp;nbsp;Hepaticae, respectively. Bryophytes are relatively small plants that
grow in&amp;nbsp;moist places on land -- on damp rocks and logs, on the forest
floor, in swamps&amp;nbsp;or marshes, or beside streams and pools. In a moss, the
sporophyte stage of the&amp;nbsp;life cycle is a relatively simple structure
consisting of three parts: a foot&amp;nbsp;embedded in the "leafy" green
gametophyte, a stalk, and a distal capsule, or&amp;nbsp;sporangium. The gametophyte
plants of some liverworts resemble mosses except&amp;nbsp;that the "leaves" are
scaly in appearance, and the "stem" is prostrate.  Other&amp;nbsp;liverworts grow
as flat green structures lying on the substratum.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="0b4081fa-5233-4484-bc82-706976defa0e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f9405e92-0c1c-4443-9cc4-45d662d8b5f2"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ACID RAIN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Rain having a pH lower than 5.6, representing the pH of natural rainwater;
the&amp;nbsp;increased acidity is usually due to the presence of sulfuric acid
and/or nitric&amp;nbsp;acid, often attributed to anthropogenic sources.   &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="1532e590-a62d-46e3-8d03-2351bc48166a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1532e590-a62d-46e3-8d03-2351bc48166a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any or all of the forms of water particles, whether liquid or solid, that

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="cad5c02a-e771-434e-bef6-8dced38a68e8"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="eca0080c-b001-4b6a-b978-f76415e28421"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ac50c468-df2f-429c-8394-9d63efcc6f9d"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d8aee072-097c-496f-8fe7-b65605fc1103"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TIDES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reports providing information pertaining to the study of the periodic rise and
fall of the sea surface, generated by long-wavelength waves that are caused by
the interaction of gravitational force and inertia. Variables include
characteristics of tides and other aspects important to their study.	    &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="39f5a91f-c5b6-4aa9-a0c6-05530306f17b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f85293fe-eb9d-491a-bba8-46261a38b9bf"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CLASSROOM ACTIVITIES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Classroom Activities are defined as Education/Outreach Services that are designed to supplement primary Earth Science and/or Global Environmental Change teaching methods and materials. These materials can be in the forms of a laboratory experiment or a hands-on activity done by students in a classroom. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="97675827-9b0a-4d13-a795-d4a3e78c476a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="97675827-9b0a-4d13-a795-d4a3e78c476a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CURRICULUM SUPPORT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Curriculum Support Services are defined as Education/Outreach Services that are designed to supplement primary Earth Science and/or Global Environmental Change teaching methods and materials. These materials will either reinforce
understanding of a previously introduced concept or will introduce a new concept not covered by primary materials.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="dc2088f9-ffb7-41c3-b0a1-856ecfec89de"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="f85293fe-eb9d-491a-bba8-46261a38b9bf"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="fc889d75-41f3-4f36-b461-1100536c8f50"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="1a2f59f6-76f3-4c57-b70b-de350708426f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5eda068f-97ea-474a-8a1b-b193f6901251"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ANGIOSPERMS (FLOWERING PLANTS)</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Flowering Plants are all included within the class Angiospermae.
Today&amp;nbsp;angiosperms are the dominant plant life, their survival helped by
the&amp;nbsp;angiosperms' flowers (through pollination), fruit (by being carried to
new&amp;nbsp;places), and seeds (which contain food to nourish the young plant).
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="0b4081fa-5233-4484-bc82-706976defa0e"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="f4211da2-9eaa-4bb3-86b1-c4595e9f2971"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="b2957a8b-4c60-42aa-ac1c-56a88421702b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b2957a8b-4c60-42aa-ac1c-56a88421702b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MONOCOTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="5eda068f-97ea-474a-8a1b-b193f6901251"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="e36c5faa-c772-4bb0-aeca-b361e160ce9d"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f4211da2-9eaa-4bb3-86b1-c4595e9f2971"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>

   <skos:broader rdf:resource="5eda068f-97ea-474a-8a1b-b193f6901251"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e3d3f76d-0ffe-4616-9988-0520e78cf842"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SULFUR</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Measure of any form of Sulfur, a macronutrient, in the soil.  &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="199e3af8-4cf3-48ba-8b28-b9b54756b3db"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="096f466a-a86a-42ac-93f7-05a799910817"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ISOTOPES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The isotopic record found in ice cores reveal direct information about the past
climate. d18O (delta oxygen-18), 16O and 18O are isotopes of oxygen with slight
differences in atomic weight. Depending on the temperature of evaporation and
how far the water has had to travel before it fell as snow, the ratio of 18O to
16O will vary. This ratio, known as d18O, can be measured very accurately using
a mass spectrometer. Over short time scales the change in temperature from
summer to winter produces a very clear oscillation in the 18O/16O ratio. This
oscillation is used to determine the age of the core at different depths,
simply by counting the oscillations. Over longer time periods, this ratio
indicates the average temperature of the regions between the evaporation site
and the coring site. Investigators in Greenland and Antarctica are also
analyzing for the ratio of 1H/2H (Hydrogen to deuterium) which will allow even
finer detail about source temperature and condensation history to be obtained.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="dba19648-3f52-48ba-b00b-8527d44c4d74"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="dba19648-3f52-48ba-b00b-8527d44c4d74"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE CORE RECORDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An ice core is a section of ice drilled from a glacier or ice sheet. Ice
deposits contain samples of the atmosphere at the time the ice formed; they
also record seasonal fluctuations of temperature and dust. That's why ice cores
are extremely valuable sources of paleoclimate data on the Earth's climate
in the distant past. Researchers drill sections of ice cores hundreds of meters
long and then match sections at different depths with particular eras in the
Earth's past. These sections can then be analyzed for clues about atmospheric
gases and temperatures from hundreds of thousands of years ago.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7245882-84a1-4192-acfa-a758b5b9c151"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ddbd1be1-2a1b-4aea-a085-6a63208a75c0"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="37dac8df-b04b-4561-91fb-886e1bded2c1"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="2f4ccb5c-7b99-442c-9054-964070d95f7b"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="daab3b2a-1fe7-4ad9-8340-1a7cfa54a2ac"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="3643618f-3af3-4c69-8beb-2ad14141a176"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="63c7d604-707e-4c38-8baf-19a620e61917"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="01a4a324-cad3-441d-b0f1-02dc9742784a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="096f466a-a86a-42ac-93f7-05a799910817"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="591d2038-5c5e-47bf-a551-1b28f33d1f05"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="cac28264-0788-49a9-bb6a-c2251b0b325c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TOTAL ELECTRON CONTENT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Total electron content is the total vertically integrated number
of&amp;nbsp;electrons per unit surface area on the earth. In standard metric
units&amp;nbsp;this is 10E16 electrons/m^2 also known as a TEC unit or TECU.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="0af72e0e-52a5-4695-9eaf-d6fbb7991039"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0af72e0e-52a5-4695-9eaf-d6fbb7991039"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ATMOSPHERIC ELECTRICITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Electrical phenomena, regarded collectively, which occur in the
Earth's&amp;nbsp;atmosphere. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c47f6052-634e-40ef-a5ac-13f69f6f4c2a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="12b1cc7c-cb81-4851-9163-19c04a8ffd1c"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9a583e74-34e9-4eb5-af7a-03418d702af6"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The fitness of water for use (by plants or animals), being affected by&#xd;

A Water Quality Advisory may include information on the types of contaminants&#xd;
that may decrease the water quality in a particular area.&lt;br&gt;&#xd;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reports providing information on changes in environmental factors including
warnings of potential threat to life, property, agricultural resources, and/or
the environment arising from the cycling of water on and inside the Earth.
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1bf8f27a-d6ff-4cb6-acb7-7e5cce11e029"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BIRDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Birds, of the class Aves, are warm-blooded craniates with a body covering
of&amp;nbsp;feathers; typically with forelimbs modified as wings for active flight.
They&amp;nbsp;are free living (most can fly) in all terrestrial and surface water
habitats;&amp;nbsp;some are capable of swimming underwater.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="14802b53-b702-438f-8c8a-f51506807ce6"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c3a4eb4a-4619-43cd-b890-b567d01324ea"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PRECIPITABLE WATER</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The total atmospheric water vapor contained in a vertical column of
unit&amp;nbsp;cross-sectional area extending between any two specified levels,
commonly&amp;nbsp;expressed in terms of the height to which that water substance
would stand if&amp;nbsp;completely condensed and collected in a vessel of the same
unit cross section. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="286d2ae0-9d86-4ef0-a2b4-014843a98532"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="286d2ae0-9d86-4ef0-a2b4-014843a98532"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ATMOSPHERIC WATER VAPOR</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Water present in the atmosphere in gaseous form; the source of all forms of&#xd;
condensation and precipitation. Water vapor, clouds, and carbon dioxide are the
main atmospheric components in the exchange of terrestrial radiation in the&#xd;
troposphere, serving as a regulator of planetary temperatures via the&#xd;
greenhouse effect. Approximately 50 percent of the atmosphere's moisture lies&#xd;
within about 1.84 km of the earth's surface, and only a minute fraction of the&#xd;
total occurs above the tropopause. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c47f6052-634e-40ef-a5ac-13f69f6f4c2a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="b68ab978-6db6-49ee-84e2-5f37b461a998"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="26fc4850-7ba9-44d8-a156-5c623e17b72f"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="15029eb0-6342-4066-8ac9-c50f7dbfb392"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="c3a4eb4a-4619-43cd-b890-b567d01324ea"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="d7fbbafe-fc73-4b63-9837-3d53d2370d9d"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="d438f0a2-5a88-4d56-8bec-7c5e35249544"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="731beb11-9418-40ec-8f2c-c4b320e8231a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="427e5121-a142-41cb-a8e9-a70b7f98eb6a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="5cd8b242-ac18-4d9f-85d5-eb551792d7e9"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="acc824e7-8eea-4e7d-aa3d-757cda7e6ec9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d6379bf5-88dd-4ec0-9b15-441db5b10b59"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WEB COVERAGE SERVICE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Retrieves client-specified subset of client-specified coverage (or image) dataset.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="46c929ad-8729-4484-8dc5-0a58a4e696a6"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="46c929ad-8729-4484-8dc5-0a58a4e696a6"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">INFORMATION MANAGEMENT SERVICES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Services that are designed to store and provide access to data, normally handling multiple separate datasets. In addition, metadata describing multiple datasets can be stored and searched. Access is usually to retrieve a client-specified subset of a stored dataset, or to retrieve selected metadata for all datasets whose metadata meets client-specified query constraints. The services in the Processing Services tier are used by clients and by services in the Application Services and Processing Services tiers. These services can use other services in the Information Management Services tier. </skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="1d550f3a-1c8c-4ef5-beff-74cfe7794f12"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="d2e9b10f-3b62-42fb-b906-7b4779170a4a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="cabd97d6-aa6c-48b8-963b-79248634ce5d"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="f2115645-e006-414a-bfb6-083d4874a665"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="d6379bf5-88dd-4ec0-9b15-441db5b10b59"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="cdb4a032-bb7d-455d-b3dc-e88fa465b7c7"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="73098e85-81ed-4556-93ca-ac1e4f4884ab"/>
</skos:Concept>

pathways.&amp;nbsp;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Mollusks are fundamentally bilaterally symmetrical coelomates with
segmentation&amp;nbsp;almost or completely absent; muscular foot, typically
ventral; head usually&amp;nbsp;with concentrated sense organs; dorsal mantle of
tissue folded to form a cavity&amp;nbsp;with usually houses gills; well developed
blood vascular system and usually an&amp;nbsp;internal or external calcareous
shell.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="abc6f016-d1f0-4725-b847-639de054d13f"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e3bef663-6116-4f15-995c-38c7cdc9652c"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TIDES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the study of the periodic rise and fall of the sea
surface,&amp;nbsp;generated by long-wavelength waves which are caused by the
interaction of&amp;nbsp;gravitational force and inertia.  Variables include
characteristics of tides&amp;nbsp;and other aspects important to their study.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="91697b7d-8f2b-4954-850e-61d5f61c867d"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="f4f40ec7-e698-4e11-b406-a0fa7f4b530c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="062be713-9c35-458e-86e2-26cea9415f5d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">STORM SURGE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A rise above normal sea level on the coast where the Ekman effect, from
strong&amp;nbsp;winds, causes the shallow waters to pile up against the shore.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e3bef663-6116-4f15-995c-38c7cdc9652c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f4f40ec7-e698-4e11-b406-a0fa7f4b530c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TIDAL COMPONENTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Harmonic constituents of tides with characteristic phase, period
and&amp;nbsp;amplitude, unique to a given location and used in the harmonic method
of tide&amp;nbsp;prediction.    &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e3bef663-6116-4f15-995c-38c7cdc9652c"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="54ab2e0e-8e36-48e8-b020-ea9a5b453373"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TIDAL CURRENTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Mass flow of water induced by the raising or lowering of sea level owing
to&amp;nbsp;passage of tidal crests or troughs.   &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e3bef663-6116-4f15-995c-38c7cdc9652c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9afcf69c-f56f-45a9-afd9-6f929850326b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TIDAL HEIGHT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The height of the ocean surface above a datum, varying as a result of the
rise&amp;nbsp;and fall of tides.   &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e3bef663-6116-4f15-995c-38c7cdc9652c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a5a6266a-9457-4acf-b140-fcdc8bc00a00"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FOOD-WEB DYNAMICS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Food-web Dynamics denotes the complex network of interconnected food chains.
&amp;nbsp;Food chains are innumberable pathways where one organism is eaten by a
second,&amp;nbsp;which is eaten by a third.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="233a4d81-44f8-4b0e-8ad3-695f641729f8"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="19ab681c-bdd7-4793-bbdb-1ec498575314"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CARBON AND HYDROCARBON COMPOUNDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Carbon (C) is the 12th element in the periodic table. Carbon is one of the most
versatile elements and combines itself with many other elements to form a huge
variety of organic compounds including hydrocarbons and their derivitives.&lt;P&gt;&#xd;
Hydrocarbons are organic molecules consisting of carbon and hydrogen, but the
term is often applied to derivitives of hydrocarbons consisting of oxygen,
halogens, etc. Hydrocarbons can occur from both natural and anthropogenic
emissions.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b9c56939-c624-467d-b196-e56a5b660334"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="7c892333-f4c4-4f81-b825-d6a86e107e9f"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="35721fc2-a968-487f-ad85-6307a18e4af6"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="af157837-bdbd-4a9a-b24e-6a79adfef57f"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="c3b81888-8a39-4b3f-8033-4c077797bcba"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="88a1b416-1589-45a4-9923-452975ec35c7"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="cdab2cca-6767-427e-b464-09fe26ec59db"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="06d230f1-08f8-48cc-9bbd-5f2358a84d13"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="c6b2279c-804f-42bf-aa8a-0c81f9ecf6cd"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c3b81888-8a39-4b3f-8033-4c077797bcba"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CARBON DIOXIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">One of the major greenhouse gases. Human-generated carbon dioxide is
caused&amp;nbsp;mainly by the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation. The
chemical formula&amp;nbsp;for carbon dioxide is CO2. Long-term measurements of CO2
in the atmosphere are&amp;nbsp;conducted at Manua Loa, Hawaii and several
international monitoring stations&amp;nbsp;around the world.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="19ab681c-bdd7-4793-bbdb-1ec498575314"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="88a1b416-1589-45a4-9923-452975ec35c7"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CARBON MONOXIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Carbon Monoxide (CO) is a toxic, odorless, colorless gas produced&#xd;
during fossil fuel or biomass burning.	It is one of the longest-lived,&#xd;
naturally occurring atmospheric carbon compounds.	The recent change in&#xd;
tropospheric CO content may portend a change in the balance between&#xd;
oxidants and reductants in the atmosphere. [Journal of Geophysical&#xd;
Research;v95; 16443-16450;1990] [Scientific American;v261;&#xd;
82-88;1989]. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="19ab681c-bdd7-4793-bbdb-1ec498575314"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="cdab2cca-6767-427e-b464-09fe26ec59db"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CHLORINATED HYDROCARBONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The presence of pesticides or PCB (POLYCHLORINATED BIPHENYL) in the Atmosphere.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="19ab681c-bdd7-4793-bbdb-1ec498575314"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="06d230f1-08f8-48cc-9bbd-5f2358a84d13"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NON-METHANE HYDROCARBONS/VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Non-Methane Hydrocarbons (NMHCs) are hydrocarbons such as ethylene,&#xd;
butane, hexane, propane and, by definition, exclude the first member of&#xd;
that analogous series, CH4. Large quantities of NMHCs are emitted from&#xd;
vegetation, the vast majority as isoprene, C5H8. This emission is&#xd;
significant compared to that of anthropogenic NMHC. [Nature; v329;&#xd;
705-707; 1987.] [Nature; v329; 705-707; 1987.]	&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="19ab681c-bdd7-4793-bbdb-1ec498575314"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="af157837-bdbd-4a9a-b24e-6a79adfef57f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HYDROGEN CYANIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Hydrogen cyanide (HCN) was discovered by the Swedish chemist Carl Wilhelm&#xd;
Scheele in 1782, who prepared it from the pigment Prussian blue (hence its&#xd;
other name of prussic acid). &lt;p&gt;&#xd;
There are many naturally occurring substances yielding cyanide in certain&#xd;
seeds, such as the pit of the wild cherry. It usually occurs in combination&#xd;
with plant sugars. The tuberous edible plant of the spurge family called&#xd;
cassava (also known as manioc, mandioc, or yuca) was used by primitive peoples&#xd;
to produce HCN for poison darts and arrows. HCN is produced by other plants,&#xd;
bacteria and fungi. Emissions from CN radicals are occasionally observed from&#xd;
lightning disturbed air. Hydrogen cyanide is produced by biomass burning since&#xd;
nitrogen in plant material is mostly present as amino acids and upon combustion
this nitrogen is emitted as a variety of compounds including NH3, NO, NO2, N2O,
organic nitriles and nitrates. It is interesting to note that the atmospheric&#xd;
measurements of HCN reported by Zander et al. (1988) gave a mixing ratio for&#xd;
HCN in the Southern Hemisphere which was approximately 5% higher than that for&#xd;
the Northern Hemisphere. This may be due to biomass burning.&#xd;
There are many anthropogenic sources of compounds containing CN which can be&#xd;
released into the atmosphere. Cyanides are used in a variety of chemical&#xd;
processes including fumigation, case hardening of iron and steel,&#xd;
electroplating and in the concentration of ores. Hydrogen cyanide is used to&#xd;
prepare polyacrylonitrile fibres (known by the generic name of acrylic)&#xd;
synthetic rubber, plastics, and in gas masers to produce a wavelength of 3.34&#xd;
mm. Hydrogen cyanide is a combustion product which is a human hazard during&#xd;
domestic and industrial fires and from tobacco smoking. Some catalytic&#xd;
converters in bad repair can produce large amounts of Hydrogen cyanide.&#xd;
Hydrogen cyanide is produced in large quantities for laboratory and commercial&#xd;
use by three principle methods: Treatment of sodium cyanide with sulphuric&#xd;
acid, catalytic oxidation of a methane-ammonia mixture, and decomposition of&#xd;
formamide (HCONH2).&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="19ab681c-bdd7-4793-bbdb-1ec498575314"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="7c892333-f4c4-4f81-b825-d6a86e107e9f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">METHANE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Methane (CH4) is a colorless, odorless, flammable, greenhouse gas. It&#xd;
is released naturally into the air from marshes, swamps, rice&#xd;
fields, ruminant animals (such as cattle), and sewage sludge.  CH4 is&#xd;
also released from methane-producing bacteria (methanogens) that live&#xd;
in anaerobic places. [Solar Energy; v52n6; 467-477; 1994.] [Air, The&#xd;
Nature of Atmosphere and the Climate; Michael Allaby; pages 39,40;&#xd;
1992; Facts on File; New York] [Dictionary of Science;	R.K. Barnhart;&#xd;
page 398; 1986; Houghton Mifflin Company; Boston.] &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="19ab681c-bdd7-4793-bbdb-1ec498575314"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="35721fc2-a968-487f-ad85-6307a18e4af6"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">METHYL CYANIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Methyl Cyanide (CH3CN), also known as acetonitrile, is emitted from incomplete&#xd;
combustion of vegetable matter, notably biomass, for example, cigarettes.&#xd;
Acetonitrile is relatively unreactive in the troposphere and thus reaches the&#xd;
stratosphere, where it participates in ionmolecule reactions. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="19ab681c-bdd7-4793-bbdb-1ec498575314"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ATTENUATION/TRANSMISSION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Attenuation is the exponential loss of light intensity as light
propagates&amp;nbsp;through water.&amp;nbsp;Attenuation is caused by absorption and
scattering of light energy.&amp;nbsp;Transmission is the measurement of the
percentage of light received at a&amp;nbsp;photo cell placed at fixed distances
from a light source. &#xd;&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ALPHA PARTICLE FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An alpha particle has positive charge and consists of two protons and&#xd;
two neutrons (the nucleus of a helium atom).  Alpha particles can cause &#xd;
ionization of neutral atoms.   Flux is the rate of flow through a reference&#xd;
surface, measured in particles per unit area.&#xd;

commerce.&amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b4a924bb-0d42-4169-bad7-3856f69f0c4a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ACOUSTIC SCATTERING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The process by which some sound is dispersed to travel&amp;nbsp;in directions other
than that which from it was incident&amp;nbsp;by particles suspended in the medium
through which it is travelling.  &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="0517ae1f-7617-4f3b-80cb-649178032825"/>
</skos:Concept>

of sound.&amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1ecb1e7c-50fc-4951-b610-5140475d87ed"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CARBON TETRACHLORIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">CCl4, a compound consisting of a carbon and 4 chlorines that is active in ozone depletion when the compound is broken down and releases chlorine atoms (radicals). Chlorine reacts with the ozone creating diatomic oxygen and chlorine monoxide which cycles back to chlorine radicals.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d46a5046-e1c6-4a09-a2f1-db6a21eda611"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="2a60df4a-a0d7-4e4b-b02a-372a083f0170"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">EMISSIONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">With respect to pollution, the discharge of gases or particles from a
source&amp;nbsp;such as a smokestack or exhaust pipe into the atmosphere, perhaps
resulting in&amp;nbsp;environmental pollution. With respect to radiation, the
generation and sending&amp;nbsp;out of radiant energy.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="77397026-09c9-44e0-b85f-77b2bc9b1630"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d1426df9-7653-442b-8e38-fa28757ec748"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">REFLECTANCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">In radiation transfer, reflectance is the fraction of incoming radiation&#xd;
that is reflected from a medium. The sum of this, the transmittance, and&#xd;
the absorptance must equal unity.    &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="63bc0693-52eb-4ebd-a39e-e77e96409072"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="46975e66-863a-49c9-b673-b2e099a04c85"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RADAR REFLECTIVITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The property of illuminated objects to reradiate a portion of the&#xd;

</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d3b7c3c0-e644-4f01-94da-dfebe854c0d1"/>

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RADAR</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An acronym for &lt;I&gt;radio detection and ranging&lt;/I&gt;, radar uses radio waves
&amp;nbsp;(microwave portion of the spectrum) to detect the presence of objects and
&amp;nbsp;determine their range (position).&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="83150c54-5da8-4ee8-9579-19b95a8dc10c"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="625da982-3648-43fc-a640-1b230509944e"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="e2c01004-be17-4be4-bfcd-7b5c7fc958d6"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="46975e66-863a-49c9-b673-b2e099a04c85"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="11e14ac8-e9f3-4737-b83d-98668ad975ed"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="9613f08d-da11-4ed0-989e-c0c830870044"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="69d394f7-a792-4a17-8d7f-e60cd60dcda0"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CONVECTION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Convection is energy transfer through motion of within the fluid resulting
in&amp;nbsp;transport and mixing of the properties of the fluid. In
oceanography,&amp;nbsp;convection plays a role in the transfer of heat away from
the ocean. As the air&amp;nbsp;near the  warm sea surface gets heated, it expands
and rises, carrying the heat&amp;nbsp;away. In physical oceanography, the sinking
of surface waters to form deep&amp;nbsp;water masses, a process of fundamental
importance for ocean climate and the&amp;nbsp;maintenance of a stably stratified
world ocean. There are two main types of&amp;nbsp;deep convection, the physics of
which are very different. The first is&amp;nbsp;convection near an open boundary,
which involves the formation of a dense water&amp;nbsp;mass which reaches the
bottom of the ocean by descending a continental slope.&amp;nbsp;The second type is
open-ocean deep convection, where the sinking occurs far&amp;nbsp;from land and is
predominantly vertical.  &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="63bc0693-52eb-4ebd-a39e-e77e96409072"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="67648fff-9415-4a36-a1f6-ef028dd1d9b5"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DEPTH HOAR</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the characteristics of the layer of ice crystals that&#xd;
forms between the ground and snow cover by sublimation.  It's also&#xd;
referred to as sugar snow. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="50b8fe04-9149-4b7f-a8b2-b33b1e3aa192"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="7e95b5fc-1d58-431a-af36-948b29fa870d"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SALINITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A measure of the dissolved solids in seawater.   &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a46016d7-e571-403a-ab37-7223fd74e68e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="434d40e2-4e0b-408a-9811-ff878f4f0fb0"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CATALOGING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A Catalog service is defined as Data Handling Services that provide a listing&#xd; of items arranged systematically with descriptive details. These items include, but are not limited to, data sets, reference materials, and other services.&#xd; Catalog services are, however, limited to topics of relevance to the Earth&#xd; Sciences and Global Environmental Change. These foci must be reflected by a&#xd; majority of the items listed in the catalog. Catalog services also include any&#xd; tools that may be used to create a catalog or facilitate the inclusion or&#xd; maintenance of a listing within a catalog. EXAMPLES: NASA's Global Change Master Directory, Geospatial One-Stop (catalogs) and docBUILDER (metadata management).       &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="02d92216-70c6-437c-8c15-2b76f2132921"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Anemones, or Sea Anemones, belong to the class Anthozoa, which are&#xd;

Anthozoans are the most advanced members of the Phylum Cnidaria. &#xd;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c9f1a861-2173-4124-962c-759f71b6f131"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="a368da76-b191-4859-bd55-8643f4fab812"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="548a3f85-bf22-473b-b641-45c32d9c6a0c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PARTICULATE MATTER</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">"Particulate matter," also known as particle pollution or PM, is a complex mixture of extremely small particles and liquid droplets. Particle pollution is made up of a number of components, including acids (such as nitrates and sulfates), organic chemicals, metals, and soil or dust particles.

The size of particles is directly linked to their potential for causing health problems. EPA is concerned about particles that are 10 micrometers in diameter or smaller because those are the particles that generally pass through the throat and nose and enter the lungs. Once inhaled, these particles can affect the heart and lungs and cause serious health effects. EPA groups particle pollution into two categories: 
&lt;BR&gt;
- "Inhalable coarse particles," such as those found near roadways and dusty industries, are larger than 2.5 micrometers and smaller than 10 micrometers in diameter.
&lt;BR&gt;
- "Fine particles," such as those found in smoke and haze, are 2.5 micrometers in diameter and smaller. These particles can be directly emitted from sources such as forest fires, or they can form when gases emitted from power plants, industries and automobiles react in the air.

</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e5a401b-1507-4f57-82b8-36557c13b154"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6641ff15-36c8-4dbc-bf9c-176a08688173"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RADIOCARBON</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A radioactive isotope of carbon (carbon-14) with a half-life of about
5730&amp;nbsp;years, widely used in the dating of organic materials. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6eb3919b-85ce-4988-8b78-9d0018fd8089"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c82f3480-545f-4491-83f1-0477369ddcd8"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PERMAFROST</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">1. (Also called perennially frozen ground, pergelisol, permanently frozen&#xd;
ground.) A layer of soil or bedrock at a variable depth beneath the surface of&#xd;
the earth in which the temperature has been below freezing continuously from a&#xd;
few to several thousands of years. Permafrost exists where the summer heating&#xd;
fails to descend to the base of the layer of frozen ground. A continuous&#xd;
stratum of permafrost is found where the&#xd;
annual mean temperature is below about 5C (23F). &lt;p&gt;2. As limited in&#xd;
application by P. F. Svetsov, soil that is known to have been frozen for at&#xd;
least a century. &lt;p&gt;&#xd;
Muller, S. W., 1947: Permafrost, or Permanently Frozen Ground, and&#xd;
Related Engineering Problems, &lt;p&gt;&#xd;
Hare, F. K., 1951: Compendium of Meteorology, p. 958, and map, p.&#xd;
956.	 &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="376a1d5c-2496-4381-981f-bc047af92044"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8cbdfa00-852c-452d-8013-86145ad318c8"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MAGNETIC FIELDS/MAGNETIC CURRENTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An Electromagnetic field (EM field) is the region of space near electric
currents, magnets, broadcasting antennas etc., regions in which electric and
magnetic forces may act, for example on charged particles.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3a942e8a-d2f2-42bf-9e83-b7b3793b100e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6a426480-c58f-4b6b-8e35-0975b7f6edb5"

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9bad3c7b-daf6-428a-89bd-ce62b074dfcf"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CATION EXCHANGE CAPACITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The sum of exchangeable bases plus total soil acidity at a specific pH value
usually 7.0 or 8.0. When acidity is expressed as salt extractable acidity, the
cation exchange capacity (CEC) is called the effective cation exchange
capacity(ECEC) because this is considered to be the CEC of the exchanger at the
native pH value. It is usually expressed in centimoles of charge per kilogram
of exchanger.	
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0d0de6a7-c340-4e6b-b01d-ccbb6e7fa913"

</skos:definition>

a&amp;nbsp;solid, such as soil, in response to a given  potential gradient.&amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ac061db6-21c7-46fc-b5a8-9f61c795fdd6"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MICRONUTRIENTS/TRACE ELEMENTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A plant nutrient usually found in relatively small amounts(&lt;100 mg&#xd;
kg-1) in plants.  These are usually B, Cl, Cu, Fe, Mn, Mo, Ni, Co, and&#xd;
Zn.  In environmental applications it is those elements exclusive of the eight&#xd;
abundant rock-forming elements: oxygen, aluminum, silicon, iron, calcium,&#xd;
sodium, potassium, and magnesium.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e1179e7f-59e5-465a-9879-6bda6985744e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NITROGEN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Measure of any form of Nitrogen, a macronutrient, in the soil, such&#xd;
as biomass nitrogen, ammonium, nitrate, etc... &#xd;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Soil constituents consisting of a wide range of  organic
(carbonaceous)&amp;nbsp;substances, including living organisms, carbonaceous
remains of organisms which&amp;nbsp;once occupied the soil, and organic compounds
produced by current and past&amp;nbsp;metabolism in the soil.&amp;nbsp;

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PERMAFROST</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Permanently frozen material underlying the solum.&amp;nbsp;

   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

</skos:definition>
