<skos:Concept rdf:about="c22818ce-07aa-4f77-8fe2-be1925743bac"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RECLAMATION/REVEGETATION/RESTORATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">RESTORATION: The processes by which an area is treated in  an attempt&#xd;
to restore original conditions.  RECLAIMATION: The process of reconverting&#xd;
land to other  forms of productive uses.  REVEGETATION: Reestablishment&#xd;
of vegetation which may take  place naturally or be induced by humans&#xd;
through seeding or transplanting. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9d7b0259-2d88-4e78-b2c2-131a02d05c15"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL SALINITY/SOIL SODICITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The term salinity refers to the presence of the major dissolved
inorganic&amp;nbsp;solutes, essentially Na, Mg, Ca, K, Cl, SO4, HCO3, and CO3, in
aqueous samples.&amp;nbsp;As applied to soils, it refers to the soluble plus
readily dissolvable salts in&amp;nbsp;the soil or, more usually, in an aqueous
extract of a soil sample.  Salinity is&amp;nbsp;quantified in terms of the total
concentration (or, occasionally, the content)&amp;nbsp;of such soluble salts.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e497c2e3-cd21-4af9-9a5d-91da4e201631"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL ABSORPTION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The movement of ions and water into the plant root as a result of
metabolic&amp;nbsp;processes by the root or diffusion along a gradient.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e273b634-62f5-4601-8b92-6550f6efeab8"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The branch of soil science that deals with the chemical constitution,&#xd;

</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>

the&amp;nbsp;soil based upon the characteristics and properties.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="013b44e9-df5c-4ef8-a99f-7351d16bfd14"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL COLOR</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The property of a soil that is based upon three components of hue,
chroma&amp;nbsp;(intensity or brightness), and value (lightness or darkness).&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c9f8c1e9-dca8-4c2e-9537-65903d19cfe5"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL COMPACTION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The reduction in bulk volume or thickness of a soil owing to increasing
weight&amp;nbsp;of overlying material that is continually being deposited, or to
pressures from&amp;nbsp;earth movements, resulting in a decrease of porosity.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6ce3eeff-d222-4356-8cd2-50fbcbcbb295"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL CONSISTENCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The combination of properties of soil material that determine its resistance
to&amp;nbsp;crushing and its ability to be molded or changed in shape.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="60e783c1-4b33-4ab3-860b-8bd4ed00dc9f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL DEPTH</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A measure from the surface to the bottom of the soil profile.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="cdb10789-ef01-46bd-8047-86e550df0df4"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The quality of a soil that enables it to provide  essential chemical
elements&amp;nbsp;in quantities and proportions for the growth of specified
plants.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="76c23076-d9d5-4414-a69f-a830cecdd9ce"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL GAS/AIR</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The soil atmosphere; the gaseous phase of the soil, being that volume not&#xd;
occupied by solid or liquid.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c6847d01-cbf9-491b-be59-c283d9072d95"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL HEAT BUDGET</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The relation between the fluxes of heat into and out of a soil and the&#xd;
heat stored by the soil. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="7a16aa40-c74b-4a69-a230-1edd1b453332"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL HORIZONS/PROFILE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The soil profile is the vertical section of the soil, from the surface
through&amp;nbsp;all its horizons, where a horizon is a layer of soil,
approximately parallel to&amp;nbsp;the soil surface, differing in properties and
characteristics from adjacent&amp;nbsp;layers below and above it.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="bcc72093-b2d4-47e8-9213-7f48172e0e95"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL IMPEDANCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The resistance of the soil to penetration by water and by roots.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="bbe2ea34-8842-4a9f-9b0b-95dd3c71857f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL MOISTURE/WATER CONTENT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Soil Water Content: The water lost from soil upon drying to constant&#xd;
mass at 105 degrees Celcius; expressed either as the mass of water per&#xd;
unit mass of drysoil or as the volume of water per unit bulk volume of&#xd;
soil. For GCMD purpose, this also includes all measurements related to&#xd;
soil water, such as capcity, potential, and pressure, etc... &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="357193c5-154d-487b-a1c3-a1a90d15918c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL PH</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The negative log of Hydrogen ion concentration &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="2da4e52a-b43b-4ff0-9e4d-c98438a38c6d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL PLASTICITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The degree to which a soil is capable of being	molded or deformed
continuously&amp;nbsp;and permanently, by relatively moderate pressure, into
various shapes.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="20f932b9-cc40-4462-879f-1c8d8c765152"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL POROSITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The volume percentage of the total soil bulk not occupied by solid
particles.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1e7afff2-cd50-4d26-968b-bffd2d738edd"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL PRODUCTIVITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The capacity of a soil for producing a specified plant or sequence of
plants&amp;nbsp;under a specified system of management; emphasizing the ability to
produce&amp;nbsp;crops.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e699830a-0abf-45b2-8026-ac80e0269ea7"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL RESPIRATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The metabolic process whereby electrons are transfered from a reduced
compound&amp;nbsp;(usually organic) to an inorganic acceptor molecule other than
oxygen.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="aa25235a-596f-4504-89e1-4c625275700d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL STRUCTURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The combination or arrangement of primary soil	particles into secondary
units&amp;nbsp;or peds. These secondary units may be, but usually are not, arranged
in the&amp;nbsp;profile in such a manner as to give a distinctive characteristic
pattern.  The&amp;nbsp;secondary units are characterized and classified on the
basis of size, shape,&amp;nbsp;and degree of distinctness into classes, types, and
grades, respectively.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0546b91a-294d-45d9-8b45-76aaad0cc024"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The degree of hotness or coldness of the soil as  measured on some
definite&amp;nbsp;temperature scale.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="fb05c0c0-7fcd-470c-ba2b-755f04f5d811"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL TEXTURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The relative proportions of the various soil separates in a soil, as&#xd;
described by the percent clay, sand, and silt. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="7c00e468-6a43-49ef-891e-b0ce29e2ff36"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL WATER HOLDING CAPACITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The percentage of water remaining in a soil two or three days after its
having&amp;nbsp;been saturated and after free drainage has practically ceased
(field moisture&amp;nbsp;capacity).&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c67c1e1c-19f1-49de-8b2b-d5ce6f596323"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A measure of the ability of a soil to transfer heat (through a unit
thickness,&amp;nbsp;across a unit area for a unit difference in temperature).&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6eef914d-ff9f-44b0-a3a6-3dcf911023d4"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL EROSION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The wearing away of the land surface by rain or irrigation water, wind,&#xd;
ice, or other natural or anthropogenic agents that abrade, detach and remove&#xd;
geologic parent material or soil from one point on the earth's surface and&#xd;
deposit it elsewhere, including such processes as gravitational creep and&#xd;
so-called tillage erosion; The detachment and movement of soil or rock by&#xd;
water, wind, ice, or gravity. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="49ee4fcc-a0ad-4638-aec9-90b4946d8922"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HEAVY METALS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Those metals which have densities &gt;5.0 Mg m-3. In soils these include the&#xd;
elements Cd, Co, Cr, Cu, Fe, Hg, Mn, Mo, Ni, Pb, and Zn.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The entry of water into soil. Also, the infiltration flux is the volume of&#xd;
water entering a specified cross-sectional area of soil per unit time [L t-1].&#xd;

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MICROFAUNA</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Microfauna (or simply microbiota) refers to the smallest soil organisms,
including bacteria and protozoa.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ed1b3fa6-173d-476c-9b35-c57335c0a473"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MICROFLORA</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Microflora (or simply microbiota) refers to the smallest soil organisms,
including fungi and algae.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1b475201-a032-4a66-a3aa-a35605affaee"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL ROOTING DEPTH</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">he distance in inches that plant roots extend into the soil. Knowing the&#xd;
average root depth for the plants in each watering zone is important to&#xd;
determine an efficient watering schedule. Shallow roots require more frequent&#xd;
watering than deep roots, which can draw water from a larger soil profile. &#xd;
Average root depths vary with plant type. Trees will have root depths of 24&#xd;
inches or more. Xeriscape plants will have root depths around 10 inches. Shrubs
and perennials will have roots of 8 inches or more. Grass can have deep roots&#xd;
(greater than 6 inches, depending on region). Annuals and bedding plants have&#xd;
the shallowest roots at 4-5 inches. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3526afb8-0dc9-43c7-8ad4-f34f250a1e91"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d76e6734-956b-419d-9d7a-52b8e645b6ac"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The portion of the electromagnetic spectrum lying between the extreme of&#xd;

100 micrometers, respectively). &#xd;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="74851074-27ab-425b-9521-8d139b907b0d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RADIATION EXPOSURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Exposure to ionizing and nonionizing radiation on humans. Ionizing radiation
includes highly energetic electromagnetic radiation (x-rays, gamma rays, or
cosmic rays) and particulate radiation (alpha particles, beta particles,
neutrons, or heavy charged ions). Nonionizing radiation includes ultraviolet
radiation (UV), microwaves, and extralow-frequency (ELF) electromagnetic
radiation. These two types of radiation have different modes of action on
biological material. Ionizing radiation originates from external sources
(medical equipment, computer and TV displays) or from internal sources
(ingested or inhaled radioisotopes, such as radon-222, strontium-90 and
iodine-131, and is either anthropogenic or natural. Nonionizing radiation
originates from natural sources (sunlight, Earth's magnetic field, lightning,
static electricity, endogenous body currents) and technological sources
(computer and TV video displays, microwave ovens, communications equipment,
electric equipment and appliances, and high-voltage transmission lines).
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="da2c70fd-d92b-45be-b159-b2c10cb387c6"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a9394dee-8c4e-47a8-b630-6549ac1cb717"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AGRICULTURAL ADVISORIES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reports providing information on changes in environmental factors including
warnings of potential threat to life, property, agricultural resources, and/or
the environment arising from soil cultivation, crop production, and/or the
raising of livestock.	  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="09d00879-6d96-4df4-9f50-73bd761118d9"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="f1c35c74-0b10-46de-9c06-efeda92d383a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="a394776f-b658-44de-b952-90f4e53d58cc"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="09d00879-6d96-4df4-9f50-73bd761118d9"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ENVIRONMENTAL ADVISORIES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="894f9116-ae3c-40b6-981d-5113de961710"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="39f5a91f-c5b6-4aa9-a0c6-05530306f17b"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="89554e78-d69d-4a38-b7f1-78d9e1e4aa57"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="13b8bcd4-7566-49e5-9975-ea15470474ab"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="7f71a0a0-3da7-42b9-b134-c0a824dff971"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="09d1435d-99de-4149-ba64-d98c3335a383"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f1c35c74-0b10-46de-9c06-efeda92d383a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CROP FORECAST</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">To estimate or calculate in advance, especially to predict crop yield by
analysis of agricultural and meteorological data.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a9394dee-8c4e-47a8-b630-6549ac1cb717"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a394776f-b658-44de-b952-90f4e53d58cc"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DROUGHT FORECAST</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Drought is a protracted period of deficient precipitation resulting in&#xd;
extensive damage to crops, resulting in loss of yield.&#xd;
Lack of rainfall for an extended period of time can bring farmers and major&#xd;
metropolitan areas to their knees. It does not take very long; a few rain-free&#xd;
weeks spreads panic and shrivels crops. A drought forecast would be issued for
one of the following:&lt;BR&gt;&lt;BR&gt;&#xd;
Meteorological - a measure of departure of precipitation from normal.  Due to&#xd;
climatic differences what is considered a drought in one location may not be a&#xd;
drought in another location.&lt;p&gt;&#xd;
Agricultural - refers to a situation when the amount of moisture in the soil no
longer meets the needs of a particular crop and can also affect livestock and&#xd;
other dry-land agricultural operations.&lt;P&gt;&#xd;
Hydrological -	occurs when surface and subsurface water supplies are below&#xd;
normal.&lt;p&gt;&#xd;
Socioeconomic - refers to the situation that occurs when physical water&#xd;
shortage begins to affect people.&lt;p&gt;&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a9394dee-8c4e-47a8-b630-6549ac1cb717"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b3a1e091-0bc2-4c9b-a89c-bd003fdd5889"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AFFORESTATION/REFORESTATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Afforestation: "the establishment of trees on an area that has lacked forest&#xd;
cover for a very long time or has never been forested. "&#xd;
Reforestation: " the natural or artificial restocking (i.e., planting, seeding)
of an area with forest trees. Also called forest regeneration. "&#xd;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TORNADOES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A small mass of air (whirlwind) that spins rapidly about an almost&#xd;
vertical axis and forms a funnel cloud that contacts the ground; appears&#xd;
as a pendant from a cumulonimbus cloud and is potentially the most&#xd;
destructive of all weather systems. &#xd;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ground that freezes and thaws annually.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8073b62d-a2f3-4ad9-b619-de26f28877a7"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8073b62d-a2f3-4ad9-b619-de26f28877a7"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FROZEN GROUND</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Soil within which the moisture has predominantly changed to ice, the unfrozen
portion being in vapor phase. &#xd;
Ice within the soil bonds (adfreezes) adjacent soil particles and renders
frozen ground very hard. Permanently frozen ground is called permafrost. Dry
frozen ground is relatively loose and crumbly because of the lack of bonding
ice. Frozen ground is sometimes inadvisedly called frost or ground frost. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6a426480-c58f-4b6b-8e35-0975b7f6edb5"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="6fdd8021-3f6f-4f54-829c-26f744597309"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0e1f3f95-58b5-4f10-b239-850c66ed55ff"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ESTUARINE WETLANDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Areas of marsh grasses and reeds along coasts and estuaries where the ground
is&amp;nbsp;covered by high tides but drained at low tide.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="7da95c01-4b39-437e-a8d4-fd572e43f693"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Wetlands is a term for a broad group of wet habitats.  They are

lands may be&amp;nbsp;permanently or intermittently water covered.&amp;nbsp;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Landforms created by the processes of wind erosion or deposition of&#xd;

pavement. Alternative spelling "aeolian landforms."  &#xd;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d35b9ba5-d018-48a5-8f0d-92b9c55b3279"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GEOMORPHOLOGY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The science dealing with the form and surface configuration of the solid earth.
It is primarily an attempt to reveal the complex interrelationships between the
origin (and therefore material composition) of surface features on the one&#xd;
hand, and the causes of the surface alteration (erosion, weather, crustal&#xd;
upheaval, etc.) on the other hand. &#xd;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TRANSFORMATION/CONVERSION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Transformation/Conversion services are defined as Data Handling Services that, in the case of transformation, apply an adjustment function to the original data that alters the absolute values of the data (e.g., interpolation, standardization, anomalies). In the case of conversion, the service is designed to apply a function to the data that transforms the relative value of the data but not the absolute (i.e., unit conversions).&#xd; EXAMPLES: Anomalies (Transformation). Fahrenheit to Celsius (Conversion).  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="02d92216-70c6-437c-8c15-2b76f2132921"/>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AMPHIBIANS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Amphibians are craniates with a permeable skin across which respiration&#xd;
can take place.  Their life cycle includes a shell-less egg which gives&#xd;
rise to a distinct larval form.  The amphibians are free living in fresh&#xd;
water and on land (some are arboreal) but all are dependent on water or&#xd;
damp conditions. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="14802b53-b702-438f-8c8a-f51506807ce6"/>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CYANOBACTERIA (BLUE-GREEN ALGAE)</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Blue-Green Algae, now called cyanobacteria, are good examples
of&amp;nbsp;photoautotrophic eubacteria.  They are also among the most
common&amp;nbsp;photoautotrophs on Earth.  Most live in ponds and other freshwater
habitats. &amp;nbsp;They may grow as mucus-sheathed chains of cells, which can form
dense, slimy&amp;nbsp;mats near the surface of nutrient-enriched water. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="7437925f-7e10-4c96-af36-f3532ec24276"/>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICEBERGS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A massive piece of ice of greatly varying shape, protruding more than 5m above&#xd;
sea-level, which has broken away from a glacier, and which may be afloat or&#xd;
aground. Icebergs may be described as tabular, dome-shaped, sloping, pinnacled,
weathered or glacier bergs.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="099ab1ae-f4d2-48cc-be2f-86bd58ffc4ca"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="099ab1ae-f4d2-48cc-be2f-86bd58ffc4ca"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GLACIERS/ICE SHEETS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Glaciers are masses of land ice, formed by the further recrystallization of&#xd;
firn, flowing continuously from higher to lower elevations. Ice sheets are a&#xd;
continuous sheet of land ice that covers a very large area and moves outward in
many directions. This type of ice mass is so thick as to mask the land surface&#xd;
contours, in contrast to the smaller and thinner highland ice. The continental&#xd;
glacier of Greenland is sometimes called the Inland Ice. This term is often&#xd;
used to describe the great ice masses that characterized the ice ages. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="885735f3-121e-4ca0-ac8b-f37dbc972f03"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ff79c018-8d61-4811-91bc-c4ddea29677c"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="5ac9ae0b-901a-468e-8a42-5d6f3865a584"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="72fdd0c7-f998-47ab-aeee-2956b9015ccb"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="a994a6f6-cfcd-45d2-95a4-0f8455a9454d"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="87b27ecd-c10b-4d41-8c49-b84f185c5bd4"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="f1c79b5f-fcc2-42e7-818b-7534f79081ff"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="4a426aab-4a95-4bf4-8449-19a72a251541"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="b2800856-f1e3-41aa-bdc4-75e9cd626d3f"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="a870d769-b815-435a-b7cc-cba5e6c27bb3"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="7b657679-78bf-4580-987d-0d1b98dcd0d2"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="064f9784-697e-414c-b463-29cfd734e689"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SNOW MELT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The melting of snow on top of the sea ice. Yearly snow melt on sea ice can be&#xd;
derived from remote sensing satellites such as Nimbus-7 SMMR and SSM/I on the&#xd;
DMSP satellites. Snow melt onset is defined as the point in time when microwave
brightness temperatures increase sharply due to the presence of liquid water in
the snowpack.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="860e2af9-ce29-4f3f-b027-ae3747eb3e01"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="744c38f8-feeb-4e01-a909-33d75fefba82"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">USE/FEEDING HABITATS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Feeding habitat refers to the many aspects of how living organisms obtain
their&amp;nbsp;food. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="58f39353-7e1c-4884-9501-376cd0377fbf"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="23336b57-1ba3-42a6-9ec7-152285c55689"

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FOREST HARVESTING AND ENGINEERING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Process and methods related to removal of trees from the forest for purposes
of&amp;nbsp;forest improvements, manufacturing forest products, and lumber,
or&amp;nbsp;conservation.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="22ec2f9b-1f1a-469b-bc09-851d58637ff4"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6182be8b-d006-4327-994d-6f27c7e4d9a9"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LIDAR</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">LIDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) is an optical remote sensing technology that measures properties of scattered light to find range and/or other information of a distant target. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="83150c54-5da8-4ee8-9579-19b95a8dc10c"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="19c3f401-1328-495c-9705-74b0175fee56"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ca776e14-fc3d-4044-9d1a-fd7c07569399"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="83150c54-5da8-4ee8-9579-19b95a8dc10c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SPECTRAL/ENGINEERING</skos:prefLabel>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ca776e14-fc3d-4044-9d1a-fd7c07569399"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LIDAR BACKSCATTER</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The scattering of radiation in a direction opposite to that of the incident&#xd;
radiation due to reflection of the transmitted lidar signal back towards the&#xd;
instrument (from the Radar Backscatter definition).&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6182be8b-d006-4327-994d-6f27c7e4d9a9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="19c3f401-1328-495c-9705-74b0175fee56"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LIDAR DEPOLARIZATION RATIO</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The ratio of cross polarized to co-polarized lidar signal return reflected back
in a direction opposite to that of the incident radiation from a lidar&#xd;
transmission. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6182be8b-d006-4327-994d-6f27c7e4d9a9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="2d36c283-2fe3-4a08-aeb3-6a8146e79bb3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TRACE ELEMENTS/TRACE METALS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Trace elements are elements that occur in minute quantities. Trace elements
can&amp;nbsp;include copper, silicon, cobalt, iron, zinc, iodine, and manganese.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b9c56939-c624-467d-b196-e56a5b660334"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Hydrogen (H) is the lightest and most abundant chemical element. It is only
found in trace quantities in the atmosphere.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b9c56939-c624-467d-b196-e56a5b660334"/>

   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b9c56939-c624-467d-b196-e56a5b660334"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="0fd2b083-e65c-443b-9794-2c355ebac06b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0fd2b083-e65c-443b-9794-2c355ebac06b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PHOTOLYSIS RATES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The destruction of a molecule by electromagnetic radiation, which provides&#xd;
the energy required for a constituent atom to break the chemical bonds&#xd;
between it and the other atoms comprising the molecule. [Environmental&#xd;
Science and Technology; v.28; p.1300; 1994.][Review of Scientific&#xd;
Instruments; v.59; p.1307; 1988.]  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6433e330-3797-4cf9-a8ba-d26d39624459"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="768cfa32-003d-47bd-ab3a-3e27e4ec2699"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NITRATE PARTICLES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Atmospheric aerosol particles derived from biogenic or anthropogenic
nitrate&amp;nbsp;emissions; comprised of nitrate compounds (e.g., ammonia,
NOx).&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e5a401b-1507-4f57-82b8-36557c13b154"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="de702fdd-3702-4164-a396-08082b0558c0"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">KARST LANDSCAPE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An ecosystem within a landscape defined as Karst topography characterized by&#xd;
caves, sinkholes, disappraring streams and underground drainage. Karst forms&#xd;
when groundwater dissolves pockets of limestone, dolomite, or gypsum in rock.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9361962c-cfc7-4428-8843-b3502718c382"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="36040c6a-5e3a-49fe-b519-162fb77a0fd4"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TRENCHES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Trenches are long, deep (6,000-11,000m/20,000-36,000ft), and narrow depression
of the sea floor with relatively steep sides, associated with a subduction
zone. The deepest of all ocean trenches, is the Mariana Trench (11,020 m/36,000
ft).
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c16bda61-353b-4668-af2f-bbb98785b6fa"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The atmospheric pressure at mean sea level, either directly measured, or,
most&amp;nbsp;commonly, empirically determined from the observed station pressure.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="08fd82a1-4370-46a2-82ea-94c0f91498a7"/>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The pressure exerted by the atmosphere as a consequence of gravitational

in question.

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">METADATA TRANSFORMATION/CONVERSION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Metadata Transformation/Conversion services are defined as Metadata Handling
Services that, in the case of transformation, apply an adjustment function to
the original metadata that alters the absolute values of the metadata (e.g.,
interpolation, standardization, anomalies). In the case of conversion, the
service is designed to apply a function to the data that transforms the
relative value of the data but not the absolute. &lt;br&gt;&#xd;
Example: DIF to FGDC&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a1fedfa9-569f-4313-8ce1-db95513c5469"/>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SUBSETTING/SUPERSETTING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Subsetting/Supersetting services are defined as Data Handling Services that, in the case of subsetting, create a smaller set of Earth science data from a larger set. In the case of supersetting the service creates an aggregate data
set from the contents of several data sets. In no instance of supersetting or subsetting is the data transformed (see transformation) (e.g., averaging), only transferred from one data set to another. EXAMPLES: Global cloud-free composite image (supersetting). Selecting one station's data from a data set containing 40 stations (subsetting).    &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="02d92216-70c6-437c-8c15-2b76f2132921"/>
</skos:Concept>

a median fin&amp;nbsp;as well as a tail fin. &amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="cf9ef34d-ed39-4c8d-bf00-ca1b0bb11363"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any measure related to the composition of harvested forage, such as
hay,&amp;nbsp;fodder, silage, grain, or other processed feed for livestock.  May
include new&amp;nbsp;mixes, new types, etc..., and any additives.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0e06e528-e796-4b7c-9878-dbcb061d878d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TREE RINGS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Tree Rings, also known as annual rings or growth rings, are a sheath of
cells&amp;nbsp;appearing as one of a series of concentric rings in the
cross-section of a&amp;nbsp;woody stem.  Each ring is usually the result of a
single yearly growth flush&amp;nbsp;starting in spring and ceasing in late summer.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="bfbfd84c-6bf0-412f-9e75-1bad5241c339"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SPONGES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Sponges are multicellular organisms with no discrete tissues and organs
but&amp;nbsp;with a skeleton composed of collagen (with or without mineral
elements), and a&amp;nbsp;tubular water filtration system driven by specialized
uniflagellate cells. &amp;nbsp;They have a free living sessile habit and are mainly
marine at all depths and&amp;nbsp;latitudes but some occur in freshwater.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="abc6f016-d1f0-4725-b847-639de054d13f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4722fc1e-f93f-4aa1-854a-2b8a82920008"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">STRATIGRAPHIC SEQUENCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A set of deposited sedimentary beds that reflects the depositional&#xd;
environment of those beds and the geologic history of a region. &#xd;
A stratigraphic sequence is a chronologic succession of sedimentary rocks from&#xd;
older below to younger above without interruption.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="45325a01-2522-48d3-bffa-0edf1a934d48"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">OCEAN/LAKE RECORDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Paleoclimatic information can be inferred from biogenic material in ocean
sediments, oxygen isotopic analyses of sea water (via deep sea cores), coral
growth, inorganic material such as from weathering and erosion, lake levels and
glacial varves, and ocean circulation changes as a result of
glacial-interglacial cycles. &#xd;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NUTRIENT CYCLING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Nutrient cycling is the repeated pathway of particular nutrients or
elements&amp;nbsp;from the environment through one or more organisms back to the
environment. &amp;nbsp;Nutrient cycles include the carbon cycle, the nitrogen
cycle, the phosphorus&amp;nbsp;cycle, and so on.&amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a756fd6b-6208-4af0-ac56-6ee914fc4597"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">IRRIGATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The artificial augmentation of the amount of water available to
crops/plants,&amp;nbsp;either by spraying water directly on to the plants or making
it available to&amp;nbsp;their root systems through a series of surface channels or
ditches.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ea5ccefb-e390-43d5-8202-33e004565beb"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACT ASSESSMENT MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Climate Change Impact Assessment Models examine and predict the vulnerabilities of human populations to future climate change, including associated sea-level rise and changes in the frequency and intensity of climate extremes such as floods, droughts, heat waves and windstorms, and taking into account potential impacts on water resources, agriculture and food security, human health, coastal and other types of settlements, and economic activities. These models can be used to assess the potential responses of natural environments and the wildlife that inhabit them to future climate change and identifies environments at particular risk.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="68eed887-8008-4352-b420-949457ab59ab"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GLACIERS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A mass of land ice, formed by the further recrystallization of firn, flowing&#xd;
continuously from higher to lower elevations. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8603db51-3484-4439-8b3b-a06f48e8c686"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="10b1872b-4a48-4360-a449-388e8988bca9"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE SHEETS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A continuous sheet of land ice that covers a very large area and moves outward&#xd;
in many directions. &#xd;
This type of ice mass is so thick as to mask the land surface contours, in&#xd;
contrast to the smaller and thinner highland ice. The continental glacier of&#xd;
Greenland is sometimes called the Inland Ice. This term is often used to&#xd;
describe the great ice masses that characterized the ice ages. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8603db51-3484-4439-8b3b-a06f48e8c686"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4d95ccc8-3ef9-40df-85e7-db36cb815499"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICEBERGS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A massive piece of ice of greatly varying shape, protruding 5 m or more&#xd;
above sea- level, which has broken away from a glacier and which may be&#xd;
afloat or aground. They may be described as tabular, domed, pinnacled,&#xd;
wedged, drydocked or blocky. Sizes of icebergs are classed as small,&#xd;
medium, large and very large.	  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8603db51-3484-4439-8b3b-a06f48e8c686"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6159b9d9-4aa5-4dec-8146-0e47751449ff"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FIRN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Rounded, well-bonded snow that is older han one year (from NSIDC glossary). A&#xd;
permeable aggregate of small ice grains with densities greater than 0.55 up to&#xd;
0.82 where begins glacial ice.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8603db51-3484-4439-8b3b-a06f48e8c686"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="399a84d1-ccf5-4167-a699-15eb7d1ad1e6"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GLACIER FACIES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">In general, facies are the set of all characteristics of a sedimetary rock that
indicates its particular environment of deposition and which distinguish it
from other facies in the same rock. Glacial facies refer to the characteristic
nature of glacial ice and/or the processes by which the ice formed and
processes by which  rock debris from the bed is entrained into the ice.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8603db51-3484-4439-8b3b-a06f48e8c686"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9f408faa-a427-44e9-a194-b1b9caff1e6d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GLACIER MASS BALANCE/ICE SHEET MASS BALANCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Mass balance describes the net gain or loss of snow and ice through a given&#xd;
year. It is usually expressed in terms of water gain or loss. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8603db51-3484-4439-8b3b-a06f48e8c686"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5034ba1f-7208-40a1-beeb-43aefe1c0c33"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GLACIER THICKNESS/ICE SHEET THICKNESS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The difference in height between two levels in the glacier or ice sheet.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8603db51-3484-4439-8b3b-a06f48e8c686"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="bf19f1d1-ae18-4ff2-95f6-dc0ed812c568"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GLACIER TOPOGRAPHY/ICE SHEET TOPOGRAPHY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Surface relief of the land. Topography usually is measured in meters above sea&#xd;
level. The topography can be very different from one location to another.&#xd;
Topography can be flat, or mountainous, or hilly.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8603db51-3484-4439-8b3b-a06f48e8c686"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d8525750-2ca4-4b1f-a717-08fda61fd547"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BRIGHTNESS TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The apparent temperature of the surface assuming a surface emissivity of 1.0.
&amp;nbsp;Setting the emissivity to one is equivalent to assuming the target is
a&amp;nbsp;blackbody, so the brightness temperature is defined as the temperature
a&amp;nbsp;blackbody would be in order to produce the radiance perceived by the
sensor.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="66700628-2b62-4466-999e-faeb15ca4da5"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="66700628-2b62-4466-999e-faeb15ca4da5"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MICROWAVE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A very short electromagnetic wave. The portion of the electromagnetic&#xd;
spectrum lying between the far infrared and the conventional radio&#xd;
frequency  portion. While not bounded by definition, it is commonly&#xd;
regarded as  extending from 1 mm to 1 m in wavelength (300 GHz to 0.3 GHz&#xd;
frequency).  &lt;P&gt; Passive systems operating at these wavelengths sometimes&#xd;
are called  microwave systems. Active systems are called radar, although&#xd;
the literal definition of radar requires a distance measuring capability&#xd;
not always included in active systems.	&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="83150c54-5da8-4ee8-9579-19b95a8dc10c"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="d8525750-2ca4-4b1f-a717-08fda61fd547"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="af234b68-d1ad-40ea-aa1b-6bc2c8e5b467"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="570397b4-3b45-4e12-85c3-ef26779a2c96"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="d9654ddc-1dc0-4f9d-9b95-61ab0c3d6f87"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="5f6e0ca7-5d60-4973-890b-08ad82654331"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="227cf2d4-968a-4312-89e6-8c6bcf616e5d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TURBIDITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The effect of (primarily) aerosols, through their total optical depth, in reducing the transmission of direct solar radiation to the surface below that through a purely molecular atmosphere.

Measures of turbidity refer to the total aerosol optical depth, either directly at a specified wavelength (e.g., the Volz turbidity factor or the ÃngstrÃ¶m turbidity coefficient, which is referenced to a wavelength of 1 Î¼m), or indirectly by the ratio of aerosol to Rayleigh optical depth (e.g., the Linke turbidity factor). </skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="77397026-09c9-44e0-b85f-77b2bc9b1630"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a28eeef3-b252-4309-957b-860d2e0f97ef"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AFFORESTATION/REFORESTATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Afforestation is the establishment of trees on an area that has lacked forest&#xd;
cover for a very long time or has never been forested. Reforestation is the&#xd;
natural or artificial restocking (i.e., planting, seeding) of an area with&#xd;
forest trees. Also called forest regeneration. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WIND-DRIVEN CIRCULATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The surface currents that form from the transfer of energy from winds
to&amp;nbsp;surface waters.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a031952d-9f00-4ba5-9966-5f87ab9dfdd4"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="39c478bd-620e-455c-904d-4621965e376c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BROMINE MONOXIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Bromine Monoxide (BrO) is one of many bromine (Br)-containing compounds that&#xd;
occur in the atmosphere from both natural and anthropogenic sources. The major&#xd;
source compounds are CH3Br (both natural and anthropogenic in origin), the&#xd;
halons (manufactured for use as fire suppressants), and dibromomethane CH2Br2&#xd;
(emitted from the oceans). Destruction of these compounds results in the&#xd;
formation of a suite of inorganic Br-containing species, including bromine&#xd;
atoms (Br), bromine monoxide (BrO), bromine nitrate (BrNO3), hypobromous acid&#xd;
(HOBr), and hydrogen bromide (HBr). The chemistry that acts to interconvert&#xd;
these inorganic species results in depletion of ozone in the stratosphere.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d46a5046-e1c6-4a09-a2f1-db6a21eda611"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b3b14df8-5197-4a26-ae61-882fdba706f3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FOOD STORAGE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any measure related to the storage of food stuffs, including
refrigeration,&amp;nbsp;canning, smoking, irradiation, drying, etc... Methods of
storage of food&amp;nbsp;products: effects of storage conditions on food quality;
temperature,&amp;nbsp;controlled atmosphere, etc. Shelf life.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b98f3a77-397d-41d7-9507-e7a3e47210b1"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b98f3a77-397d-41d7-9507-e7a3e47210b1"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FOOD SCIENCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Related to the study of products of human consumption specifically for
purposes&amp;nbsp;of human nourishment and  nutrition.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a956d045-3b12-441c-8a18-fac7d33b2b4e"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="b153bcea-3114-4809-8e6f-f22cf9a3be87"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="dd316647-9043-40c3-9329-f22f9215fefa"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">OZONE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ozone (O3) is a molecule that consists of three oxygen atoms bonded&#xd;
together. The ozone layer in the stratosphere absorbs UV radiation and&#xd;
creates a warm layer of air high in the stratosphere. Ozone that is&#xd;
present in the troposphere is mostly a result of anthropogenic pollution&#xd;
and therefore higher concentrations are found in urban areas. Ozone is&#xd;
involved with NOx in the photochemical production of many of the&#xd;
constituents of pollution environments (see nitrogen oxides and hydroxyl&#xd;
definitions) [Chemical and Engineering News; v72; 6-7; 1994.] [Aviation&#xd;
Week and Space Technology; v140; 20-21; 1994.]	&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4cc9b4fa-5097-447f-914c-eb90820938c6"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="04305c55-14f0-42a3-a099-79eb326946d7"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HALOCLINE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The zone of the ocean in which salinity increases rapidly with depth.    &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a46016d7-e571-403a-ab37-7223fd74e68e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d622004f-e155-4af3-87c5-61b3a4b87692"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">VIEWING GEOMETRY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The effects of roll, pitch, and yaw, as well as jitter on  the image&#xd;
geometry. &lt;I&gt;Roll&lt;/I&gt; will cause the image to take on a wavy appearance,&#xd;
&lt;I&gt;pitch&lt;/I&gt; will cause grid cells to contract or expand in the flight&#xd;
direction, and &lt;I&gt;yaw&lt;/I&gt; will create a skewed image.	 &lt;I&gt;Jitter&lt;/I&gt;&#xd;
consists of random and	unsystematic vibaration which cannot be&#xd;
measured. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="cda9b483-8711-42b8-82f9-e7d22ce9c62c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="cda9b483-8711-42b8-82f9-e7d22ce9c62c"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEGMENTED WORMS (ANNELIDS)</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Segmented Worms are worms that have a repeating series of body units that
may&amp;nbsp;or may not be similar to one another. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="617a50aa-5762-4ff3-aa03-c94b5cc65209"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Services that allow a user to extract and edit feature data, interacting with

<skos:Concept rdf:about="adfee6d2-ca00-4f02-a570-5ccf0850cb55"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DYNAMIC VEGETATION/ECOSYSTEM MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Predicts the fast time scale fluxes of water, carbon, nitrogen and energy&#xd;
between the landsurface and the atmosphere and the resulting diurnal surface&#xd;
fluxes, seasonal and inter-annual vegetation growth, and decadal to century&#xd;
scale alterations in vegetation structure and soil carbon and nitrogen. It&#xd;
will be made available to the climate modeling community for studies on&#xd;
seasonal weather evolution, vegetation phenology, the carbon budget, climate&#xd;
variability, paleoclimate, global change scenarios, vegetation-climate&#xd;
feedbacks, and astronomical biosignatures.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="2037d286-6285-49df-aeb4-6e429b18d595"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">REPTILES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reptiles are cold-blooded tetrapod craniates which breathe using lungs, have
a&amp;nbsp;dry, scaly skin and lay large, shelled eggs.  They live in all types
of&amp;nbsp;terrestrial habitats, the majority in tropical regions; many
secondarily&amp;nbsp;freshwater and marine species.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="14802b53-b702-438f-8c8a-f51506807ce6"/>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Marine Wetlands are areas that are sometimes covered with water and
sometimes&amp;nbsp;dry, being influenced by marine water level and tidal
fluctuations. &amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4698858b-bf39-4a2c-9713-e41757739eff"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">VISUALIZATION/IMAGE PROCESSING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Visualization / Image Processing services are defined as Data Analysis and Visualization Services that allow the user to view (Visualization) and/or manipulate (Image Processing) Earth Science data in a graphical (rather than numerical) format. These services may or may not include the ability for a user to view and/or manipulate data in a non-graphical (e.g., numerical) format, however, this ability would not be the primary method of operation of the service. EXAMPLES:
XV, GhostScript, ERDAS IMAGINE, Adobe PhotoShop.	
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="41adc080-c182-4753-9666-435f8b1c913f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="41adc080-c182-4753-9666-435f8b1c913f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="4698858b-bf39-4a2c-9713-e41757739eff"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f082ad51-4ce4-4ffe-be50-6753c4f997ae"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEMS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A surveying method that uses a set of 24 satellites in geostationary position high above the Earth. Specially designed GPS receivers, when positioned at a point on Earth, can measure the distance from that point to three or more orbiting satellites. The coordinates of the point are determined through the geometric calculations of triangulation. GPS provides accurate geodetic data for any point on the Earth.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="41adc080-c182-4753-9666-435f8b1c913f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="fc757c55-83b4-400e-9d23-25bcad230603"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MEDIA TRANSFER/DATA RESCUE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Media Transfer/Data Rescue services are defined as Data Handling Services that physically transfer data from one media form to another (excluding archives), or serve to reconstruct or reconstitute data from deteriorating or unreadable media to accessible media. EXAMPLES: Magnetic Tape to CD-ROM. Book to Diskette.       &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="02d92216-70c6-437c-8c15-2b76f2132921"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="025c1e31-1a97-4a30-a887-0b9a5127fd4d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ACOUSTIC ATTENUATION/TRANSMISSION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Attenuation: Diminution of the intensity of acoustical energy&amp;nbsp;propagating
through a medium with the distance traveled, through&amp;nbsp;absorption and
scattering.&amp;nbsp;Transmission: Propagation or the motion of waves through or
along a medium.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="0517ae1f-7617-4f3b-80cb-649178032825"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="7bb3c4cd-cbb4-4c82-997b-d11ecc1cdb9f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ACOUSTIC FREQUENCY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The number of cycles per unit time of a sound wave. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="0517ae1f-7617-4f3b-80cb-649178032825"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6a583047-6023-4b6a-ab25-b72529721a8c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ACOUSTIC REFLECTIVITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The casting back of sound waves from a surface. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="0517ae1f-7617-4f3b-80cb-649178032825"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1295cf9a-c345-40eb-9b79-82bddc6acf50"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ACOUSTIC TOMOGRAPHY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Identification of water masses and monitoring of water mass movements
using&amp;nbsp;acoustical techniques.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="0517ae1f-7617-4f3b-80cb-649178032825"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e4aae1a4-b4d5-4b13-9cc0-c0df6234ce3b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ACOUSTIC VELOCITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The speed of sound in water, which is dependent on the water's
temperature,&amp;nbsp;salinity and pressure. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="0517ae1f-7617-4f3b-80cb-649178032825"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a74abbc1-dd75-4f22-bbec-7d45091a4593"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AMBIENT NOISE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The acoustic energy above which a single desired signal is heard. In
the&amp;nbsp;oceans, ambient noise can be produced physically (e.g. wind, rain,
bubbles) or&amp;nbsp;biologically (e.g. whales, dolphins). &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="0517ae1f-7617-4f3b-80cb-649178032825"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="de9598de-24cc-4f87-b3df-d9f3d4717d33"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ELEPHANTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="f5161094-3593-4bc1-85ea-c8c2ecab1d9a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d412deec-d4ef-4c97-ac1c-f92ddb6964c6"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MACROFOSSILS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Macrofossils are fossils large enough to be studied without the aid of a
microscope. Macrofossils can indicate the range of plant or animal species in
the past.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="486f2c33-2401-4292-9d74-8756ee95211f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0c28d9e4-c848-4628-9c00-45a540707b59"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DEW POINT TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The temperature to which a given air parcel must be cooled at constant &#xd;
pressure and constant water vapor content in order for saturation to &#xd;
occur.	&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="35e1f93b-99b3-4430-b477-0ecafa80d67a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c3090318-c845-4242-bf2f-ff1631b88831"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SULFUR OXIDES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The concentrations of Sulfur Dioxide (SO2) and Sulfur Trioxide (SO3) in
the&amp;nbsp;atmosphere.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="77397026-09c9-44e0-b85f-77b2bc9b1630"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="2f2f5764-d4e6-4bbb-bd6d-dda373018237"
