   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DEGRADATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The general lowering of the surface of the land by erosive
processes,&amp;nbsp;especially by the removal of material through erosion and
transportation by&amp;nbsp;flowing water.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a246a8cf-e3f9-4045-af9f-dc97f6fe019a"/>

</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a246a8cf-e3f9-4045-af9f-dc97f6fe019a"/>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The wearing away of soil and rock by weathering, mass wasting, and the

material.&amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e4ad5a76-7540-4433-ad82-9fe89259538b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEDIMENT TRANSPORT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The movement of sediment by natural agents (such as flowing water, ice,
wind,&amp;nbsp;or gravity) either as solid particles or in	solution, from one
place to&amp;nbsp;another on the earth's surface.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a246a8cf-e3f9-4045-af9f-dc97f6fe019a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b41498cd-6b2b-47e3-afe7-0f05b4c0807d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEDIMENTATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The process of deposition of sediment, especially by mechanical means from
a&amp;nbsp;state of suspension in water or air.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a246a8cf-e3f9-4045-af9f-dc97f6fe019a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="26558c08-beca-4ef0-9ea3-b000504ece60"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEDIMENTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Unconsolidated particles created by the weathering and erosion of rock,
by&amp;nbsp;chemical precipitation from solution in water, or from the secretions
of&amp;nbsp;organisms, and transported by water, wind, or glaciers.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a246a8cf-e3f9-4045-af9f-dc97f6fe019a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="42b5ae5b-90d5-44f0-b331-6c22cdd45c3f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">STRATIGRAPHIC SEQUENCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A chronological succession of sedimentary rocks from older to younger
above,&amp;nbsp;essentially without interruption.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a246a8cf-e3f9-4045-af9f-dc97f6fe019a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="69ff701a-674e-4b63-bb93-6ebe6cd95281"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SUSPENDED SOLIDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Sediment particles supported by the upward currents in eddies of turbulent
flow&amp;nbsp;in the surrounding fluid.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a246a8cf-e3f9-4045-af9f-dc97f6fe019a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b07017e8-d714-45a6-b1fe-8c00230ec209"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WEATHERING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The destructive processes by which rocks are changed on exposure to
atmospheric&amp;nbsp;agents at or near the earth's surface, with little or no
transport of the&amp;nbsp;loosened or altered material.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a246a8cf-e3f9-4045-af9f-dc97f6fe019a"/>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Flooding, by the rise and spread of water, of a land surface that is&#xd;
not normally submerged. &#xd;
</skos:definition>

   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CLOUD MASS FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The transport of mass by vertical motion within clouds. Mass in this
context is defined as the mass of dry air plus the mass of water vapor,
excluding the mass of any liquid water.  
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="162e2243-3266-4999-b352-d8a1a9dc82ac"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="392ff7f6-dcf6-4543-930e-3e6e441ad881"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reports providing information on changes in environmental factors including

   <skos:broader rdf:resource="09d00879-6d96-4df4-9f50-73bd761118d9"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a4f0e0d2-4bcb-4675-b874-e6e0f3a8c462"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WAVE TYPES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Names of kinds of waves.  Specific types may be included as
Detailed&amp;nbsp;Variables, e.g. capillary waves, Rossby waves, etc.   &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a04804d5-1064-48fd-a7a7-8da8e10399e1"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a04804d5-1064-48fd-a7a7-8da8e10399e1"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">OCEAN WAVES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Study of the disturbances of the ocean medium caused by the movement of
energy&amp;nbsp;through that medium.  Variables include types and characteristics
of waves.   &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="91697b7d-8f2b-4954-850e-61d5f61c867d"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="bf0db125-0182-42e7-81c9-6ed55a05ddd0"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RADIOCARBON</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Radiocarbon refers to radioactive carbon especially carbon-14, but also
carbon-10 and carbon-12. Carbon-14 is a heavy radioactive isotope of Carbon
having a mass of 14 and a half-life of 5730 +/-40 years. Carbon-14 is useful in
dating organic materials during the last 50,000 years.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="486f2c33-2401-4292-9d74-8756ee95211f"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PARTICLE FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The transport of a mass of sediment particles per unit area per unit time.
&amp;nbsp;

include types of&amp;nbsp;sediment, processes affecting sediment and sediment
distribution, and&amp;nbsp;characteristics of sediment. &amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8c05bcf2-d13b-44fd-b1a2-5ec797b2f851"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SWAMPS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Swamps are wet areas that are normally covered by water all year and subject
to&amp;nbsp;drying out during the summer.  The parameter Swamp may be
colloquially&amp;nbsp;interchanged with the parameter Marshes.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

highways,&amp;nbsp;etc.&amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="14c8935f-8a46-4111-8f2e-bec8bbae5d13"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Sediments of biogenic origin, composed mostly of shells of silica producing

   <skos:broader rdf:resource="ce4b2c6e-3d69-4cf1-8416-c36e5f9b1b2c"/>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DIAGENESIS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The physical and chemical change undergone by sediment during lithification
and&amp;nbsp;compaction. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HYDROGENOUS SEDIMENTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Sediments composed of material precipitated chemically from seawater.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="ce4b2c6e-3d69-4cf1-8416-c36e5f9b1b2c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d4f4b5d3-27b2-4b7d-bb69-733b67ac687a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GEOTECHNICAL PROPERTIES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A distinguishing trait, quality, or property of any deposit&amp;nbsp;of insoluble
material, primarily rock and soil particles,&amp;nbsp;transported from land areas
to the ocean by wind, ice,&amp;nbsp;and rivers, as well as the remains of marine
organisms,&amp;nbsp;products of  submarine volcanism, chemical
precipitates&amp;nbsp;from seawater, and materials from outer space (e.g.,
meteorites)&amp;nbsp;that accumulate on the seafloor.&#xd;&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="ce4b2c6e-3d69-4cf1-8416-c36e5f9b1b2c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="17008d04-394d-4de8-8834-dd0a3cd88093"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEDIMENT COMPOSITION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The constituent materials of a sediment sample; including trace metals,
organic&amp;nbsp;material or contaminants.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="ce4b2c6e-3d69-4cf1-8416-c36e5f9b1b2c"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEDIMENTARY TEXTURES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The characterization of sediment by the size of individual particles; the
classification of sediment by particle-size classes.	 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="ce4b2c6e-3d69-4cf1-8416-c36e5f9b1b2c"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="bd55adac-4182-4441-91e2-163aa77e1320"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEDIMENT TRANSPORT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The movement of loose particulate material by a medium such as wind or
water&amp;nbsp;currents.   &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="ce4b2c6e-3d69-4cf1-8416-c36e5f9b1b2c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a4eb3bc4-48a5-4ed2-a74b-ca87a58e90f5"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEDIMENTATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The process of deposition of loose particulate material, especially
by&amp;nbsp;mechanical means, from a state of suspension in water or air.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="ce4b2c6e-3d69-4cf1-8416-c36e5f9b1b2c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="41b7293f-7f20-40ab-8bf7-b211c68146b9"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">STRATIGRAPHIC SEQUENCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A set of deposited sedimentary beds that reflects the depositional
environment&amp;nbsp;of those beds and the geologic history of a region. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="ce4b2c6e-3d69-4cf1-8416-c36e5f9b1b2c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="bcf6975f-2a21-4a6c-9286-fb8f85d00901"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SUSPENDED SOLIDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Particulate matter suspended in the water column, greater than
0.45&amp;nbsp;micrometers, as distinguished from dissolved solids which are less
than 0.45&amp;nbsp;micrometers.  Synonymous with Particulates.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="ce4b2c6e-3d69-4cf1-8416-c36e5f9b1b2c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="31cf96eb-7fcd-490d-9e10-7f17dc12e1e3"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Sediments arranged in a definite pattern of organizations.Such as cross-bedding

etc.

<skos:Concept rdf:about="cb628a66-a10b-4ef1-9261-7ce63a9439dc"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">JELLYFISHES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Jellyfish are acoelomate with a body wall divided into two layers and
separated&amp;nbsp;by a jelly-like mesoglea.  They are primarily radially
symmetrical with no anus&amp;nbsp;and a mouth usually surrounded by tentacles
bearing stinging nematocysts. &amp;nbsp;Jellyfish are free swimming.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b6164a29-8e14-4861-a30c-fefce375e284"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b6164a29-8e14-4861-a30c-fefce375e284"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CNIDARIANS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The name Cnidaria comes from the Greek word "cnidos", which means stinging
nettle (i.e. nematocysts). This phylum contains thousands of living species
worldwide.  These creatures are radially symmetrical. There are four major
groups of cnidarians:&#xd;
1) Anthozoa, which includes true corals, anemones, and sea pens;&#xd;
2) Cubozoa, the amazing box jellies with complex eyes and potent toxins;&#xd;
3) Hydrozoa, the most diverse group with siphonophores, hydroids, fire corals,
and many medusae; and&#xd;
4) Scyphozoa, the true jellyfish.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="abc6f016-d1f0-4725-b847-639de054d13f"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ad557b31-fc70-4519-a8e4-3a5daf05f774"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="cbdf4f94-efc6-4965-a329-5df989a9a211"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="c2c891c2-aa15-40b8-bfae-f02f42d0c739"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="cb628a66-a10b-4ef1-9261-7ce63a9439dc"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a4390c3d-cffa-43ee-8e91-49c6d49ac371"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR ULTRAVIOLET EMISSIONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Radiation with wavelengths roughly between 200 and 400 nanometers.
These&amp;nbsp;wavelengths are shorter than those which characterize visible
light.&amp;nbsp;Observations from satellites in the UV and extreme UV (EUV)
wavelengths have&amp;nbsp;demonstrated the sun's UV variability over short time
scales of days and weeks.&amp;nbsp;UV variability is linked to solar magnetic
activity phenomena such as flares&amp;nbsp;and plages. Studies of the UV and EUV
irradiance variability may have indicated&amp;nbsp;influences on the Earth's
climate dynamics.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:broader rdf:resource="431eca76-9d34-4f86-b1d3-a0b40221e905"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="db9b56da-e05f-4d58-b9d5-34edc83ca650"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The metabolic process whereby electrons are transfered from a reduced
compound&amp;nbsp;(usually organic) to an inorganic acceptor molecule other than
oxygen.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0e53e397-7836-45ec-bc62-0d54f9f176e5"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PACIFIC/NORTH AMERICAN (PNA) PATTERN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The PNA pattern is one of the most prominent modes of low-frequency&#xd;
variability in the Northern Hemisphere extratropics, appearing in all&#xd;
months except June and July. The PNA pattern reflects a quadripole&#xd;
pattern of height anomalies, with anomalies of similar sign located&#xd;
south of the Aleutian Islands and over the southeastern United&#xd;
States. Anomalies with sign opposite to the Aleutian center are&#xd;
located in the vicinity of Hawaii, and over the intermountain region&#xd;
of North America (central Canada) during the Winter and Fall (Spring).&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b887d3e5-4280-43d2-a34e-0f63ac086b6a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ebddda06-097f-4454-9751-bb27c41aca37"/>
   <skos:changeNote>2012-06-25 11:51:02.0 [mpmorahan] Insert Concept 
add narrower relation (PACIFIC/NORTH AMERICAN (PNA) PATTERN [0e53e397-7836-45ec-bc62-0d54f9f176e5,21181] - PNA [ebddda06-097f-4454-9751-bb27c41aca37,39731]); 
</skos:changeNote>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The temperature to which a given air parcel must be cooled at constant

occur.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">EVAPORATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The physical process by which a liquid is transformed to the gaseous
state.&amp;nbsp;Evaporation also implies a loss of heat from the ocean surface and
is an&amp;nbsp;important term in determining the heat budget of the ocean.  &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="286d2ae0-9d86-4ef0-a2b4-014843a98532"/>

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">EVAPOTRANSPIRATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The vaporization of water through direct evaporation from wet surfaces plus
the&amp;nbsp;release of water vapor by plants through leaf pores.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="286d2ae0-9d86-4ef0-a2b4-014843a98532"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="427e5121-a142-41cb-a8e9-a70b7f98eb6a"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Generally, some measure of the water vapor content of the air. Popularly,

</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d438f0a2-5a88-4d56-8bec-7c5e35249544"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SUBLIMATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The transition of a substance from the solid phase directly to the vapor
phase,&amp;nbsp;without passing through an intermediate liquid phase.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="286d2ae0-9d86-4ef0-a2b4-014843a98532"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="15029eb0-6342-4066-8ac9-c50f7dbfb392"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WATER VAPOR</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Water present in the atmosphere in gaseous form; the source of all forms of&#xd;
condensation and precipitation. Water vapor, clouds, and carbon dioxide are the
main atmospheric components in the exchange of terrestrial radiation in the&#xd;
troposphere, serving as a regulator of planetary temperatures via the&#xd;
greenhouse effect. Approximately 50 percent of the atmosphere's moisture lies&#xd;
within about 1.84 km of the earth's surface, and only a minute fraction of the&#xd;
total occurs above the tropopause. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="286d2ae0-9d86-4ef0-a2b4-014843a98532"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="acc824e7-8eea-4e7d-aa3d-757cda7e6ec9"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WATER VAPOR PROFILES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Water vapor is defined as water substance in vapor form; one of the&#xd;
most important of all constituents of the atmosphere. In meteorology,&#xd;
a profile is defined as a graph of the value of a scalar quantity versus a&#xd;
horizontal, vertical, or time scale. It usually refers to&#xd;
a vertical representation. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="286d2ae0-9d86-4ef0-a2b4-014843a98532"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5cd8b242-ac18-4d9f-85d5-eb551792d7e9"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WATER VAPOR TENDENCY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The local rate of change of water vapor with time at a given point in space.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="286d2ae0-9d86-4ef0-a2b4-014843a98532"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="13927300-c59c-491a-91f3-f1540bcb2d8d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">EDDIES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Unit(s) of motion in a fluid medium (ocean) running contrary,
usually&amp;nbsp;circularly, to the main current. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a031952d-9f00-4ba5-9966-5f87ab9dfdd4"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e018b139-7e05-4155-8e2e-8d5603b5fe47"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SHRUBLAND/SCRUB</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Areas with vegetation dominated by shrubs (generally greater than 0.5 m or
1.5&amp;nbsp;ft tall, but less than 5 m or 16 ft tall) with individuals or
clumps&amp;nbsp;overlapping to not touching (generally forming more  than 25%
cover, trees&amp;nbsp;generally less than 25% cover).&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9361962c-cfc7-4428-8843-b3502718c382"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="565cb301-44de-446c-8fe3-4b5cce428315"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DESKTOP GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Desktop Geographic Information Systems (GIS) are defined as Data Analysis and Visualization Services available specifically for the desktop that allows users to capture, store, update, manipulate, analyze, and display all forms of geographically referenced information. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="794e3c3b-791f-44de-9ff3-358d8ed74733"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="794e3c3b-791f-44de-9ff3-358d8ed74733"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Geographical Information Systems (GIS) are defined as Data Analysis&#xd; and Visualization Services that are designed specifically to process and&#xd; visualize geographically referenced data in a layered format. Statistical&#xd; or mathematical algorithms may or may not be applied to the data within&#xd; the service, but would be done so (and the results displayed) in a&#xd; graphical manner. EXAMPLES: Idrisi, Arc/Info.	   &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="41adc080-c182-4753-9666-435f8b1c913f"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="0dd83b2a-e83f-4a0c-a1ff-2fbdbbcce62d"/>

</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f27ad52c-3dfd-4788-851a-427e60ae1b8f"

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8fb66b46-b998-4412-a541-d2acabdf484b"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">COMMUNITY DYNAMICS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Assembled species or populations that dynamically occur in space and time.&#xd;

   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6bef0291-a9ca-4832-bbb4-80459dc1493f"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="7bfdbe8d-3945-4678-a90b-d2251f973955"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4e366444-01ea-4517-9d93-56f55ddf41b7"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BIODIVERSITY FUNCTIONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Biodiversity is the variety of life: the different plants, animals and
micro-organisms, their genes and the ecosystems of which they are a part.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8fb66b46-b998-4412-a541-d2acabdf484b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1a2a8cf8-6d7d-4ad6-b40c-4d9f7fed493f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SPECIES DOMINANCE INDICES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Dominance is the condition in communities or in vegetational strata in
which&amp;nbsp;one or more species, by means of their number, coverage, or size,
have&amp;nbsp;considerable influence upon or control of the conditions of existence
of&amp;nbsp;associated species.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8fb66b46-b998-4412-a541-d2acabdf484b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d3c5e3e3-97bf-4e74-9f8d-523dce5f9270"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">INDICATOR SPECIES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Indicator species are defined as species which can provide information on&#xd;
ecological changes and give early warning signals regarding ecosystem processes
in site-specific conditions due to their sensitive reactions to them. They can&#xd;
also be called sentinel species, indicator organisms, biological indicators&#xd;
("bioindicators"), biological markers, or environmental indicators. The latter&#xd;
three expressions do not necessarily refer to species but also to other&#xd;
environmental elements which can indicate environmental changes.      &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8fb66b46-b998-4412-a541-d2acabdf484b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="7bfdbe8d-3945-4678-a90b-d2251f973955"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">INVASIVE SPECIES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Invasive species are alien species whose introduction does or is likely to
cause economic or environmental harm or harm to human health. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8fb66b46-b998-4412-a541-d2acabdf484b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b98b8823-3e95-4383-bbb0-414ee8832112"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SPECIES RECRUITMENT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">With reference to populations [of species], the maturation and entry of
young&amp;nbsp;into the adult breeding population.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8fb66b46-b998-4412-a541-d2acabdf484b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ad7abcce-b88e-46c7-be44-496d60c88f25"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PLANT SUCCESSION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The phenomenon of orderly transition from one biotic community to another
and&amp;nbsp;is also known as ecological or natural succession.  Natural succession
occurs&amp;nbsp;because the physical environment may be gradually modified by the
growth of the&amp;nbsp;biotic community itself, such that the area becomes more
favorable to another&amp;nbsp;group of species and less favorable to the present
occupants.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8fb66b46-b998-4412-a541-d2acabdf484b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c09be13f-5dc2-4460-9055-1a7232aa41ae"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GRAZING DYNAMICS / PLANT ECOLOGY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">wuewuer
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8fb66b46-b998-4412-a541-d2acabdf484b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f42c849c-7113-4c69-a01e-52ebc5e7b44d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">COMMUNITY STRUCTURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A community is a group of populations of plants and animals in a given
place&amp;nbsp;or an ecological unit used in a broad sense to include groups of
various sizes&amp;nbsp;and degrees of integration. Community structure can refer to
the physical&amp;nbsp;structure or to the biological structure of a community. The
physical structure&amp;nbsp;is what one sees when looking at a community. For
example, in a forest, a&amp;nbsp;primary structure is imposed by large trees, and a
secondary structure is the&amp;nbsp;understory trees and shrubs. Biological
structure involves species composition&amp;nbsp;and abundance, temporal changes in
communities, and relationships between&amp;nbsp;species in a community.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8fb66b46-b998-4412-a541-d2acabdf484b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ae35f430-6534-49de-8b4c-edfc1e98870a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GEOMAGNETIC INDICES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Geomagnetic indices are an indicator of geomagnetic activity caused by solar&#xd;
events. Typical geomagntic indices are: a, A, Ap, Dst, K, and Kp &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="910013d7-1e6a-4d1a-9921-be32d792a290"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4a11a257-99c6-4f87-8884-2a2aa46a49fa"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SALTWATER INTRUSION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The intrusion of saline marine water into fresh groundwater supplies&#xd;
along coasts, often due to the extraction of fresh groundwater for human&#xd;
consumption. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="734f8f27-6976-4b67-8794-c7fc79d6161e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="734f8f27-6976-4b67-8794-c7fc79d6161e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GROUND WATER</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ground water in its broadest sense includes all subsurface water whether in its
liquid, solid or gaseous state, provided it is not chemically combined with the
minerals present. In practice, it is all subsurface water that participates in
the hydrological cycle.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="885735f3-121e-4ca0-ac8b-f37dbc972f03"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="a1bf1e84-c4e7-4154-ad0a-4b9eedf45066"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="a957363b-2f2c-4169-a656-c2f24933eb72"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="4a11a257-99c6-4f87-8884-2a2aa46a49fa"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="d2d4ee50-99ed-4ee7-b957-22271a60c031"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="0976b778-91be-40e7-9ed7-ebbf214bb818"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="d64094ae-774b-4435-8f2e-a54d114e5555"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="c87c086a-933f-44c7-a128-33279b36d7b5"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="8435030e-8d16-409f-a812-ace5d8ffc122"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ecbe9f17-6012-4e39-a707-713973b7d167"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="6a2107ab-38ab-42dc-beb0-8ba5f65e8022"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="638a22af-4e97-450e-a278-b81338443230"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c58320e6-3f1d-4c36-9bee-6bad73404c21"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">COASTAL LANDFORMS/PROCESSES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Coastal processes refers to the action of natural forces (e.g. erosion,&#xd;
deposition, tectonic uplift) on the shoreline, and the nearshore seabed.  Some&#xd;
examples of landforms resulting from these processes are wave-cut cliffs,&#xd;
beaches, and wave-cut benches.	&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b5cb1fab-7281-478f-bb3b-ff04f900b3fc"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b5cb1fab-7281-478f-bb3b-ff04f900b3fc"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GEOMORPHOLOGY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The science that treats the general configuration of the Earth's surface&#xd;
specif.the study of the classification, description, nature, origin, and&#xd;
development of present landforms and their relationships to underlying&#xd;
structures, and of the history of geologic changes as recorded by these surface
features. &#xd;
Syn: physiographic&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2b9ad978-d986-4d63-b477-0f5efc8ace72"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="cb5193ab-2d7a-4b35-b7ec-f16ce78ae270"/>

   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="3c78951a-0293-4fb0-baff-ec7372fe784d"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5c05e69f-f6db-4296-abd3-3b07e6093579"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CATION EXCHANGE CAPACITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The sum of exchangeable bases plus total soil acidity at a specific pH
value, usually 7.0 or 8.0.  When acidity is expressed as salt extractable
acidity, the cation exchange capacity (CEC) is called the &lt;i&gt;effective&lt;/i&gt;
cation exchange capacity (ECEC) because this is considered to be the CEC of the
exchanger at the native pH value.  It is usually expressed in centimoles of
charge per kilogram of exchanger or millimoles of charge per kilogram of
exchanger
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="199e3af8-4cf3-48ba-8b28-b9b54756b3db"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4b85cc37-1577-43f6-8cfa-8da2c49eaece"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE MOTION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Defined as the horizontal displacement of ice over an area.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="aa35a52f-e3d9-41bd-abd2-ec7e1a8101d1"/>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the measured internal temperature of snow/ice pack(s).&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="aa35a52f-e3d9-41bd-abd2-ec7e1a8101d1"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5aad0680-cae2-402b-8311-3fb4ddc892bd"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AUTHORING TOOLS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Authoring Tools services are defined as Metadata Handling Services that helps
in the creation of metadata.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a1fedfa9-569f-4313-8ce1-db95513c5469"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b6723314-3db7-4bdd-85ee-0b8507e6ae1b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PERMAFROST</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">(Also called perennially frozen ground, pergelisol, permanently frozen&#xd;
ground.) A layer of soil or bedrock at a variable depth beneath the surface of&#xd;
the earth in which the temperature has been below freezing continuously from a&#xd;
few to several thousands of years. Permafrost exists where the summer heating
fails to descend to the base of the layer of frozen ground. A continuous
stratum of permafrost is found where the annual mean temperature is below about
5C (23F).&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8073b62d-a2f3-4ad9-b619-de26f28877a7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4eab7956-e59e-4615-8d5c-39a16faa1f27"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ALKALINITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The alkalinity of seawater is the combined negative charges due to&#xd;
hydrogen carbonate and carbonate ions expressed in molal concentrations.&#xd;
Alkalinity is based on seawater being electrically neutral and is&#xd;
determined by titration (and therefore given the subscript t). &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6eb3919b-85ce-4988-8b78-9d0018fd8089"/>
</skos:Concept>

burden brought about by exposure of property or person to natural hazards or
disasters.	 &#xd;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">"Macrobiota" is a general term for the larger soil organisms. Macrofauna, in
particular, refers to burrowing vertebrate animals, but may include larger
insects and earhworms.
</skos:definition>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reports providing information on changes in environmental factors including

the environment arising from wildfires or prescribed burns.

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The act of intentionally setting fire to an area in order to prevent more&#xd;
damaging fires. &lt;br&gt;&#xd;
A Prescribed Burn Advisory may report on a prescribe burn. &#xd;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An uncontrollable fire initially caused by humans or nature.&lt;br&gt;&#xd;
A Wildfire Advisory may report on wildfires occurring in a particular region.   
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="7f71a0a0-3da7-42b9-b134-c0a824dff971"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e5d17711-c9c1-42f6-96e4-c618c0df37cb"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">OIL PRODUCTION/USE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertains to the production and processing of natural gas and oil from reservoirs. Production is the yield of an oil or gas well; the branch of the industry that brings the oil and gas to the surface for sale. The phase of the
petroleum industry that deals with bringing the well fluids to the surface and separating them and with storing, gauging, and otherwise preparing the product for pipeline. It also pertains to the amount of oil or gas produced in a given period.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b73cee46-8e2c-4df9-b1ed-7f0aa98a04ac"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="80ae5fdc-c312-4fa1-bf7d-60346529976d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NATURAL SELECTION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Selection, or natural selection, is a nonrandom reproduction of genotypes
that&amp;nbsp;results in the survival of those best adapted to their environment
and&amp;nbsp;elimination of those less well adapted.  Selection leads to
evolutionary&amp;nbsp;change. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="58f39353-7e1c-4884-9501-376cd0377fbf"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="10270ee0-8d85-4c75-9fa2-49e7a9755cb3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ACTIVE LAYER</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Active layer, also called frost zone or mollisol is that part of the soil&#xd;
included with the suprapermafrost layer (i.e., existing above permafrost) that&#xd;
usually freezes in winter and thaws in summer. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8073b62d-a2f3-4ad9-b619-de26f28877a7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1469f30b-6eb4-4186-b1ef-7dd25c34c592"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CRYOSOLS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Soil formed in either mineral or organic materials having permafrost either&#xd;
within 1 m below the surface or, if the soil is strongly cryoturbated, with 2 m
below the surface, and having a mean annual ground temperature below 0 deg C.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8073b62d-a2f3-4ad9-b619-de26f28877a7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5b4dde5a-733e-4e55-97c9-2108b337cfeb"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GROUND ICE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A general term referring to all types of ice contained in freezing and frozen&#xd;
ground. Ground ice occurs in pores, cavities, voids or other openings in soil&#xd;
or rock and includes massive ice. It may occur as lenses, wedges, veins,&#xd;
sheets, seams, irregular masses, or as individual crystals or coatings on&#xd;
mineral or organic particles. Perennial ground ice can only occur within&#xd;
permafrost bodies.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8073b62d-a2f3-4ad9-b619-de26f28877a7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5181e50a-b1d2-41b1-bde3-fd9b4da9b1bf"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PERIGLACIAL PROCESSES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Of, or pertaining to, the outer perimeter of a glacier, particularly to the&#xd;
fringe areas surrounding the great continental glaciers of the geologic ice&#xd;
ages.  Thus, periglacial weathering is said to have produced certain&#xd;
characteristic land forms.    &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8073b62d-a2f3-4ad9-b619-de26f28877a7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ee2af62b-9f76-440c-aa9b-77940468b8f4"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ROCK GLACIERS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A mass of rock fragments and finer material, on a slope, that&#xd;
contains either interstitial ice or an ice core and shows evidence of past or&#xd;
present movement.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8073b62d-a2f3-4ad9-b619-de26f28877a7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="240ff021-6a9c-4603-983d-f135ee7e49ab"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The temperature measured at a given soil depth, typically at 2, 4, 8, and&#xd;
sometimes 20 and 40 in. &#xd;
Many biological processes, including seed germination, plant emergence,&#xd;
microbial activity, and soil respiration are a function of soil temperature. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8073b62d-a2f3-4ad9-b619-de26f28877a7"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Talik, also called tabetisol, is a Russian term applied to permanently unfrozen

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ice that has been squeezed together, and in places, forced upwards&#xd;

ice, and hummocked ice.  &#xd;

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">KARST LANDFORMS/PROCESSES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Karstification is the geologic process of differential chemical and mechanical
erosion by water on soluble bodies of rock, such as limestone, dolomite,
gypsum, or salt, at or near the Earth4s surface. Karstification is exhibited
best on thick, fractured, and pure limestones in a humid environment in which
the subsurface and surface are being modified simultaneously. The resulting
karst morphology usually characterized by dolines (sinkholes), hums (towers),
caves, and a complex subsurface.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b5cb1fab-7281-478f-bb3b-ff04f900b3fc"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The zone in mountainous regions where the influence of altitude
(vertical&amp;nbsp;relief) results in local climatic regimes that are sufficiently
different from&amp;nbsp;those in the adjacent lowlands as to cause a complex
vertical&amp;nbsp;climate-vegetation-soil zonation.&amp;nbsp;

   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3055774e-8931-4b5d-a131-5ef5911839e4"/>
