<skos:Concept rdf:about="7a79a3f3-1817-4c9f-8485-550a022b5a8d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TSUNAMIS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Japanese for "wave in bay."  A long-period wave generated by
rapid&amp;nbsp;displacement of water, such as by seismic disturbances to the sea
floor. &amp;nbsp;Tsunamis travel at speeds of about 700 km/h in the open ocean and
build to&amp;nbsp;dangerous heights and energy density when their speed slows in
shallow waters. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a04804d5-1064-48fd-a7a7-8da8e10399e1"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="2e544263-d92f-46c2-9568-25e36d0b9825"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ACTIVE LAYER</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Active layer, also called frost zone or mollisol, is part of the soil included&#xd;
with the suprapermafrost layer (i.e., existing above permafrost) that usually&#xd;
freezes in winter and thaws in summer. &#xd;
Its bottom surface is the frost table, beneath which may lie permafrost or&#xd;
talik. The depth of the active layer varies anywhere from a few inches to&#xd;
several feet.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="376a1d5c-2496-4381-981f-bc047af92044"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0cd7a96f-46e1-4d86-93d0-9cbb6fda61e3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CRYOSOLS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Soil formed in either mineral or organic materials having permafrost either&#xd;
within 1 m below the surface or, if the soil is strongly cryoturbated, with 2 m
below the surface, and having a mean annual ground temperature below 0 deg C.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="376a1d5c-2496-4381-981f-bc047af92044"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="021714ad-1cae-441c-bb6f-4be866a0f742"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The temperature measured at a given soil depth, typically at 2, 4, 8, and&#xd;
sometimes 20 and 40 in. &#xd;
Many biological processes, including seed germination, plant emergence,&#xd;
microbial activity, and soil respiration are a function of soil temperature. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="376a1d5c-2496-4381-981f-bc047af92044"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="2a109b2f-947a-4c2c-9db9-ae315a53ef93"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEASONALLY FROZEN GROUND</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ground that freezes and thaws annually.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="376a1d5c-2496-4381-981f-bc047af92044"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="78e5e44c-7832-456d-a599-893ea87ae695"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TALIK</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Talik, also called tabetisol, is a Russian term applied to permanently unfrozen
ground in regions of permafrost. &lt;p&gt;&#xd;
This usually applies to a layer that lies above the permafrost but below the&#xd;
active layer, that is, when the permafrost table is deeper than the depth&#xd;
reached by winter freezing from the surface. Talik is also found within and&#xd;
beneath permafrost; when it occurs beneath the permafrost it is equivalent to&#xd;
subgelisol. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="376a1d5c-2496-4381-981f-bc047af92044"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4931dcac-8b89-4bc9-ba59-469cfdcf6f12"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GROUND ICE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A general term referring to all types of ice contained in freezing and frozen&#xd;
ground. Ground ice occurs in pores, cavities, voids or other openings in soil&#xd;
or rock and includes massive ice. It may occur as lenses, wedges, veins,&#xd;
sheets, seams, irregular masses, or as individual crystals or coatings on&#xd;
mineral or organic particles. Perennial ground ice can only occur within&#xd;
permafrost bodies.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="376a1d5c-2496-4381-981f-bc047af92044"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0451cbfb-3c46-4afe-b02d-456beabd89a6"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WEATHER FORECAST</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A statement of expected meteorological conditions for a specific period and for
a specific area.	     &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="89554e78-d69d-4a38-b7f1-78d9e1e4aa57"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="fec2eb53-bc69-4d35-849c-c2bedf5dc6cf"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FEED PROCESSING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any measure related to the processing of feed, including new methods.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c1f9f5fa-245c-4055-81cf-5230c076c0ce"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9244fe19-b86f-4a8d-82bf-c52f804a77e3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FEED STORAGE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any measure related to the storage of feed, and new methods for
improved&amp;nbsp;qualtiy over the long term, feed hopper types, etc...&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c1f9f5fa-245c-4055-81cf-5230c076c0ce"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="adeb4c27-a115-4ced-9827-5f022883f606"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FOREST PROTECTION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any measure related to or about the protection and/or conservation of
forests&amp;nbsp;from insects, diseases, pathogens, windstorms, excess logging, and
decreased&amp;nbsp;biotic diversity.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="22ec2f9b-1f1a-469b-bc09-851d58637ff4"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1dfb36a3-f985-4514-a1d0-cc73ca572922"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MARINE GEOCHEMISTRY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The related chemical and geological properties of the ocean.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6eb3919b-85ce-4988-8b78-9d0018fd8089"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="686feba9-87ba-474c-8280-7f67565cfb2f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BIOMASS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Mass of biological material. Usually the total mass of a particular group
or&amp;nbsp;category; for example, the biomass of producer organisms.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="abbba948-9b77-4e19-a855-49a7fbc17696"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CANOPY CHARACTERISTICS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Canopy characteristics refer to Global Change Master Directory
detailed&amp;nbsp;variables under the variable, Canopy Characteristics: canopy
height, canopy&amp;nbsp;position, canopy reflectance, canopy resistance, and canopy
temperature.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6f6537f5-773f-4df1-862b-d9ab80eb5e04"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CARBON</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Carbon is one of three important elements that compose plants.	The
higher&amp;nbsp;photosynthetic organisms need light, carbon dioxide, and water and
these raw&amp;nbsp;materials supply the carbon, oxygen, and hydrogen that are the
predominant&amp;nbsp;elements in the organic molecules they manufacture, as well as
the energy&amp;nbsp;needed to drive the synthetic reactions. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5e3999ec-d864-43fd-8d84-bd23630c405f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CHLOROPHYLL</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Chlorophyll is the green pigment in plants responsible for absorbing the
light&amp;nbsp;energy required for photosynthesis.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c59b0666-e20f-4134-847b-89719ed5621a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CROWN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The crown is the horizontal layer of the vegetation where most of the
branches&amp;nbsp;and foliage are found. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b7de16ed-c090-449b-81c1-44fe5b1195f0"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DECIDUOUS VEGETATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Deciduous vegetation is vegetation that sheds its leaves each year in the
fall.&amp;nbsp;Maple, oak, black cherry, and beech trees are examples.  The loss of
leaves in&amp;nbsp;the fall is believed to be an adaptation that greatly reduces
evaporation at a&amp;nbsp;time when the supply of liquid water is limited. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f717330e-3656-4910-beed-d54cc9a19c2b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">EXOTIC VEGETATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Exotic vegetation are species of vegetation that are introduced to
a&amp;nbsp;geographical area where they are not native.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a8d3f9a0-be0b-4690-86b9-ac64d951886a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FOREST COMPOSITION/VEGETATION STRUCTURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Forest Composition refers to the tree species which make up the forest.&#xd;
Vegetation Structure refers to the vertical arrangement of canopy layers and&#xd;
plants of different life forms, or the horizontal variation in canopy&#xd;
closure and canopy layers, or both.  Vegetation Structure also includes&#xd;
standing dead trees (snags) and decaying logs on the ground (coarse woody&#xd;
debris).  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="40766d01-bda1-420b-9fd1-fba6d6924f3f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HERBIVORY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Herbivory is an ecological interaction between two species where one
species&amp;nbsp;eats part or all of a plant species.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="536a5a5a-28bb-473a-aa95-6d2dd1e5098d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">IMPORTANCE VALUE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The importance value is the sum of relative density, relative dominance,
and&amp;nbsp;relative frequency for a species in the community. The larger the
importance&amp;nbsp;value, the more dominant a species is in the particular
community. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0bfb8ae4-c08a-4d69-82d2-1b1b0d4acef6"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">INDIGENOUS VEGETATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Indigenous Vegetation or native vegetation is applied to a species that
occurs&amp;nbsp;naturally in an area, and therefore, one that has not been
introduced by humans&amp;nbsp;accidentally or intentionally. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="bca1b724-3370-4a26-bcbc-3530ce4ddc97"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LEAF CHARACTERISTICS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Leaf characteristics include the Global Change Master Directory
detailed&amp;nbsp;variables under the variable, Leaf Characteristics: leaf angle,
leaf area, leaf&amp;nbsp;area index, leaf carbon dioxide flux, leaf chemistry, leaf
litter, leaf optical&amp;nbsp;properties, leaf osmotic potential, leaf
photosynthetic flux, leaf reflectance,&amp;nbsp;leaf resistance, leaf respiratory
flux, leaf stomatal conductance, leaf&amp;nbsp;transmittance, leaf water potential,
and leaf wetness.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="afc54d28-de94-4674-9528-39f00bf74d6d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LITTER CHARACTERISTICS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Litter characteristics refer to Global Change Master Directory
detailed&amp;nbsp;variable under the variable, Litter Characteristics: litter
chemistry, litter&amp;nbsp;decomposition, litter dry weight, litterfall, and
litterfall flux.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="bf0ddf9c-39ba-4b2d-91ac-63021d644276"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MACROPHYTES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Macrophytes are macroscopic vegetation. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ed7c506e-b18e-4a93-ac03-4bdfe119b72f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NITROGEN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Nitrogen is a plant nutrient that is a component of proteins, nucleic
acids,&amp;nbsp;coenzymes, and chlorophylls.  Plants that are deficient in nitrogen
have&amp;nbsp;stunted growth, and light-green older leaves.  &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9bcb805c-718e-42c3-913d-174bdf06d4c1"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NUTRIENTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Nutrients are elements essential for growth and survival of a given organism.
&amp;nbsp;Directly or indirectly, nutrients have roles in metabolism that no
other&amp;nbsp;nutrients fulfills. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="47f4e7ac-b4ca-4ef9-824b-a36ea5510526"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PHOSPHORUS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Phosphorus is a plant element which is a component of nucleic
acids,&amp;nbsp;phospholipids and ATP.	  Plants lacking phosphorus have
purplish veins, stunted&amp;nbsp;growth, fewer seeds, and fruits. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="db69ecb1-0738-4d82-943f-ae92093f500d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PHOTOSYNTHETICALLY ACTIVE RADIATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Photosynthetically Active Radiation is the light in the whole wavelength
band&amp;nbsp;from 400 nm (deep violet) to 700 nm (dark red) used by plants
in&amp;nbsp;photosynthesis. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="3e801e91-897e-4528-8f4c-4ec527ad33cc"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PIGMENTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pigments are light-absorbing molecules.  In addition to chlorophyll,
other&amp;nbsp;pigments, principally yellow and orange carotenoids, as well as
other forms of&amp;nbsp;chlorophyll, are also present in green plants.	These
molecules absorb light&amp;nbsp;and then pass the energy to the chlorophyll  a.
Accessory pigments, like the&amp;nbsp;carotenoids, enable the plants to use more of
the light than is trapped by&amp;nbsp;chlorophyll a alone. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0408bac9-c247-4b00-80de-f4665b813658"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PLANT CHARACTERISTICS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Plant characteristics refer to Global Change Master Directory
detailed&amp;nbsp;variables under the variable, Plant Characteristics:  Plant
aboveground&amp;nbsp;biomass, plant biomass, plant blooms, plant boron
concentration, plant calcium&amp;nbsp;concentration, plant carbon concentration,
plant copper concentration, plant&amp;nbsp;diameter, plant diseases, plant height,
plant iron concentration, plant&amp;nbsp;magnesium concentration, plant manganese
concentration, plant nitrogen&amp;nbsp;concentration, plant phosphorus
concentration, plant potassium concentration,&amp;nbsp;plant production, plant root
biomass, plant sink capacity, plant sulfur&amp;nbsp;concentration, plant water
potential, and plant zinc concentration.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ff141ffe-05ea-4901-a243-e6186826b05c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b0ad34ee-4b38-4a8d-a483-b3bfea66fa82"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">POLLEN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pollen is, collectively, the mass of microspores or pollen grains
produced&amp;nbsp;within the anthers of a flowering plant or the male cones of a
gymnosperm. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="86dfb9ca-6587-4a91-b397-f220bb48a1eb"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RECLAMATION/REVEGETATION/RESTORATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reclamation, as used here refers, to putting a natural resource to a new
or&amp;nbsp;altered use.  Restoration is the return of an ecosystem to a
close&amp;nbsp;approximation of its condition prior to disturbance. Revegetation is
the&amp;nbsp;planting of vegetation in an area where vegetation has been removed.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="fe6b37b9-f95a-491e-a58e-22aa66be9a9d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">REFORESTATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reforestation is the replanting of trees in forests where the trees have
been&amp;nbsp;cut down.  Reforestation sometimes is undertaken in an effort to
reduce&amp;nbsp;atmospheric carbon dioxide levels by restoring forests, which are
carbon sinks. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5bdb3251-4811-439c-b172-9bbcd98e84b3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">VEGETATION COVER</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Vegetation Cover is the percent of vegetation in an area. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="16a7b4d6-e47f-4753-8803-f72edc4e1c5e"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">EVERGREEN VEGETATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Vegetation that has persistent leaves and whose crown is never totally bare.
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="3f45aadf-ec7c-43a1-a008-b24ca139837a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PLANT PHENOLOGY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The science that treats the periodic biological phenomena with relation to&#xd;
climate, especially seasonal changes.&#xd;
Phenological events are stages of plant growth. From a climatological&#xd;
viewpoint, these phenomena serve as bases for the interpretation of progress in
local seasons and the climatic zones, and are considered to integrate the&#xd;
effects of a number of bioclimatic factors on rate of plant development.&#xd;
Phenology may be considered a branch of the science of bioclimatics, the&#xd;
sequence of plant or crop development stages through its life cycle. Growth&#xd;
stages may be defined by stage of physiological development such as&#xd;
germination, first true leaf, flowering, maturity, etc., and/or by physical&#xd;
stage such as planting, emergence, harvest, etc.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c7b5c02c-724d-4a19-b824-98180f3900c9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="bdfd401f-7eed-4a48-bd6f-f0c2a890594a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">REFLECTANCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ratio of the intensity of reflected radiation to that of the incident&#xd;
radiation on a surface.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1efe6ac1-d375-44c3-b8ec-d0ff2987a881"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICEBERGS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A massive piece of ice of greatly varying shape, protruding more than 5m above&#xd;
sea-level, which has broken away from a glacier, and which may be afloat or&#xd;
aground. Icebergs may be described as tabular, dome-shaped, sloping, pinnacled,
weathered or glacier bergs.&#xd;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d52674c3-0c78-4f35-9675-c2a8b3869b16"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NORTH TROPICAL ATLANTIC INDEX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The timeseries of SST anomalies averaged over 60W to 20W, 6N to 18N and 20W to 10W, 6N to 10N map. Data is obtained from the COADS dataset for 1951-1991 and NCEP afterwards. Anomalies were calculated relative to the 1951-2000 climatology, smoothed by three months running mean procedure and projected onto 20 leading EOFs. Month of data is the center of the 3 months that are smoothed. More information and the indexes forecasted values are available. </skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b83895e9-bac8-49fe-bcf5-8fe4d8fcaa16"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="85586d78-1819-4ba7-ab5f-9f684640d730"/>

</skos:changeNote>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The band of the electromagnetic spectrum which can be  perceived by the&#xd;
naked eye. This band ranges from about .75  Î¼m to .4 Î¼m, being bordered by&#xd;
the infrared and ultraviolet bands. &#xd;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1455c369-88e2-411b-83f7-c914b20609b1"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEA ICE MOTION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Refers to the movement and direction of ice fields or floes. Ice
motion&amp;nbsp;processes include: diverging, compacting, and shearing. &amp;nbsp;

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RIVERS/STREAMS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">River: A large, natural freshwater surface stream having a permanent
or&amp;nbsp;seasonal flow and moving toward a sea, lake, or another river in a
definite&amp;nbsp;channel. Stream: A body of running water moving under the
influence of gravity&amp;nbsp;to lower levels in a narrow, clearly defined natural
channel.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">X-RAY FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Short electromagnetic waves whose wavelengths range from .00001 ? to 3000&#xd;
?. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="12156f9d-9731-446e-b9de-a781af653b1c"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="12156f9d-9731-446e-b9de-a781af653b1c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">X-RAY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">X-Ray (Or x-radiation, Rntgen ray) is electromagnetic radiation with
wavelengths shorter than that of ultraviolet radiation and greater than that of
gamma radiation. &lt;P&gt;&#xd;
Discovered accidentally by Rntgen in 1895. The primary mechanism for the
production of x- rays is deceleration of a rapidly moving charge upon
interaction with matter (bremsstrahlung). The x-ray spectrum from an x-ray tube
consists of this continuous spectrum on which are superimposed narrow bands
(characteristic radiation) that are a consequence of transitions between
electronic energy levels of atoms. No sharp boundary exists between x- and
ultraviolet radiation nor between x- and gamma radiation, although the latter
term is usually restricted to radiation resulting from transitions between
nuclear energy levels.

</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="83150c54-5da8-4ee8-9579-19b95a8dc10c"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="e32b5dca-c243-40d8-9e06-d146a40a71df"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8cc74c57-9a5e-4f71-a918-73746c150bd3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RADIO BLACKOUTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Conditions in which long distance radio communications is poor to propagate to
severely blocked.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="09d1435d-99de-4149-ba64-d98c3335a383"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reports providing information on changes in environmental factors including

environment arising from space weather.&lt;br&gt;&#xd;

sometimes violent and dramatic changes.      &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="09d00879-6d96-4df4-9f50-73bd761118d9"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="ed49aea3-c1ce-4522-985b-1b1b2b2c7790"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="65475fcc-b696-4b02-a812-f12364046c4c"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="3b786f1b-aca7-437b-bd86-44f20789da7b"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="94bafe5f-b97e-49b3-ad62-494865b799f3"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="8cc74c57-9a5e-4f71-a918-73746c150bd3"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="6e039ab2-beed-4b17-9fb2-41965839f5bf"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="b40d8d03-6286-48cd-818c-20d1680d6453"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8435030e-8d16-409f-a812-ace5d8ffc122"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ALPINE/TUNDRA</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Habitat found in the zone on mountain tops between permanent snow and the
cold&amp;nbsp;limits of trees, or in arctic regions,      characterized by very low
winter&amp;nbsp;temperatures, short cool summers, permafrost below a surface layer
subject to&amp;nbsp;summer melt, short growing season, and low precipitation.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="61f57065-8f47-45c7-8319-f6115153a6ad"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ISOTOPES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The isotopic record found in various non-marine records reveal direct
information about the past climate. d18O (delta oxygen-18), 16O and 18O are
isotopes of oxygen with slight differences in atomic weight. Studies using
other isotopes such as Carbon-13, Carbon-14 and Hydrogen are widely used.
Isoptopic analysis is especially important in dendroclimatologic and speleothem
analyses.     
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="486f2c33-2401-4292-9d74-8756ee95211f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9f8a6a52-df35-487d-9a74-74b76943e0c0"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">EXHIBIT MATERIALS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Exhibit Materials are defined as Education/Outreach Services that provide a sensory (visual, auditory, tactile, etc.) presentation of items or concepts related to the Earth Sciences and/or Global Environmental Change. These materials are designed such that one unit is able to disseminate its information to a large number of viewers at any one time. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="dc2088f9-ffb7-41c3-b0a1-856ecfec89de"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="24b7bc59-3f10-4a0b-b9c1-92ae10feb007"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="fb3b3728-a6ff-465d-8a33-2619a3276cdf"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="cabd97d6-aa6c-48b8-963b-79248634ce5d"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CATALOG SERVICE FOR THE WEB</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Retrieves object metadata stored that meets client-specified query criteria.</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="cdb4a032-bb7d-455d-b3dc-e88fa465b7c7"

pre-defined pictorial renderings of maps in an image or graphics format.</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d2e9b10f-3b62-42fb-b906-7b4779170a4a"

<skos:Concept rdf:about="933bf0ab-11af-40df-a9d9-1b4a809edd87"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WEB PROCESSING SERVICES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The OGC Web Processing Service  (WPS) is designed to standardize the way that GIS  calculations are made available to the Internet. WPS can describe any calculation (i.e. process) including all of its inputs and outputs, and trigger its execution as a Web Service. WPS supports simultaneous exposure of processes via HTTP GET, HTTP POST, and SOAP, thus allowing the client to choose the most appropriate interface mechanism. The specific processes served up by a WPS implementation are defined by the owner of that implementation. Although WPS was designed to work with spatially referenced data, it can be used with any kind of data.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="46c929ad-8729-4484-8dc5-0a58a4e696a6"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4539272a-f041-4fc6-883d-4c4c5bef1683"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FREEZE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The condition that exists when, over a widespread area, the surface
temperature&amp;nbsp;of the air remains  below freezing 0 C (32 F) for a sufficient
amount of time&amp;nbsp;to constitute the characteristic feature of the weather. A
freeze is a term&amp;nbsp;used for the condition when vegetation is injured by
these low air&amp;nbsp;temperatures, regardless if frost were deposited.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b7d562cf-9b9b-4461-900b-50423a8c4d29"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0bf50cd4-8a97-468c-8e73-047e3e09a03d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">STORM SURGE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A phenomena wherein sea level rises above the normal tide level when&#xd;
hurricanes or tropical storms move from the ocean along or across a&#xd;
coastal region. This sea level rise can consists of three components, the&#xd;
first of which results from low barometric pressure, i.e. the so-called&#xd;
inverse barometer effect, where lower atmospheric pressure on the surface&#xd;
of the water allows it to rise. The second component is wind set-up where&#xd;
the winds drag surface	    &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a04804d5-1064-48fd-a7a7-8da8e10399e1"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c7570528-f2d5-42b0-b8e9-d12a2432e87e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RECLAMATION/REVEGETATION/RESTORATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reclamation, as used here refers, to putting a natural resource to a new
or&amp;nbsp;altered use.  Restoration is the return of an ecosystem to a
close&amp;nbsp;approximation of its condition prior to disturbance. Revegetation is
the&amp;nbsp;planting of vegetation in an area where vegetation has been removed.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9d7eed04-9c49-4024-8d0f-06474cc38bbc"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BIOMASS BURNING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Biomass burning is the burning of organic matter, such as, wood or crop wastes,that can be burned or converted into gaseous or liquid fuels. Useful biomass includes wood, wood residues left over from the timber industry, crop residues, charcoal, manure, urban waste, industrial wastes, and municipal sewage.  Some of these fuels can be burned directly. Others are converted to methane or a gas.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3f4cfc81-7745-43d9-b313-f68cdf72359b"/>

Industrialization leads to the mass production of&amp;nbsp;products, which means
that more goods are available to more people. &amp;nbsp;</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e759cacb-33f0-4564-b151-c7cfa5e85ed3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">URBANIZATION/URBAN SPRAWL</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Urbanization is the expansion of metropolitan areas by building housing developments and shopping centers farther and farther from urban centers and placing them together with more major highways. An outcome of urbanization is the fact that as more highways are built, surfaces are sealed with pavement, increasing stormwater runoff and quickening concentration times.

Urban sprawl refers to the process in which an increasing proportion of an entire population lives in cities or suburbs of cities. Urban sprawl, also known as suburban sprawl, is a multifaceted concept, which includes the spreading outwards of a city and its suburbs to its outskirts to low-density, auto-dependent development on rural land, with associated design features that encourage car dependency.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="f1682ed1-2d9c-41ec-9553-49b9ab55df9b"/>
   <skos:changeNote>2012-07-02 15:44:58.0 [tbs1979]

An outcome of urbanization is the fact that as more highways are built, surfaces are sealed with pavement, increasing stormwater runoff and quickening concentration times.

Urban sprawl refers to the process in which an increasing proportion of an entire population lives in cities or suburbs of cities. Urban sprawl, also known as suburban sprawl, is a multifaceted concept, which includes the spreading outwards of a city and its suburbs to its outskirts to low-density, auto-dependent development on rural land, with associated design features that encourage car dependency.); 
update Definition (Princeton University Dictionary);

<skos:Concept rdf:about="14555831-70ae-4650-8983-956d65595575"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WATER MANAGEMENT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Water management is a very broad term which can include human direct or indirect impacts on the water cycle.  Water management can involve (1) changing the Earth's surface such as when dams are created to control flooding (perhaps due to more deforested and overgrazed slopes), (2) pollution control, when decisions are made to minimize the chemicals, such as fertilizers, pesticides, or road salt, that are used on the soil surface in order to minimize the amount of pollutants that will leach into the soil, and (3) amount and quality of water available for human use as when water is used for irrigation, industry or for direct human consumption.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d81b77be-0177-4e26-942c-aa911239482d"/>
   <skos:changeNote>2012-07-11 09:38:51.0 [tbs1979]

<skos:Concept rdf:about="36c862a7-7117-4fd2-8e33-0dda03097178"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL EROSION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">(i) The wearing away of the land surface by rain or irrigation water, wind,&#xd;
ice, or other natural or anthropogenic agents that abrade, detach and remove&#xd;
geologic parent material or soil from one point on the earth's surface and&#xd;
deposit it elsewhere, including such processes as gravitational creep and&#xd;
so-called tillage erosion; (ii) The detachment and movement of soil or rock by&#xd;
water, wind, ice, or gravity. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="199e3af8-4cf3-48ba-8b28-b9b54756b3db"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="01a4a324-cad3-441d-b0f1-02dc9742784a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An important baseline measurement in ice cores is electrical conductivity.&#xd;
Electrical conductivity measurements (ECM) of the core is a very rapid method
to indicate how acidic the core is without the chemical detail of the ion
analyses. The value of the measurement is that it can be done for the whole
length of the core in high resolution and provide an immediate picture of the
core and allow quick detection of interesting areas, such as a volcanic
eruptions. Because it is a high resolution, continuous measurement it can be
used, along with the other measurements, for time frequency analysis in order
to identify cycles in the climate signal.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="dba19648-3f52-48ba-b00b-8527d44c4d74"/>
</skos:Concept>

of&amp;nbsp;organisms, and transported by water, wind, or glaciers.&amp;nbsp;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Anisotropy is the characteristic of a surface for which a physical&#xd;
property, such as reflectivity, varies in value with the direction in or&#xd;
along which the measurement is made.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Dissolved organic matter (DOM) produced by the decomposition of plant

brought to the&amp;nbsp;ocean by rivers, and producing a distinctive yellow-brown
to yellow-red&amp;nbsp;coloration of the water. &amp;nbsp;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Longwave Radiation (or Infrared Radiation) is electromagnetic radiation in

the&amp;nbsp;electromagnetic energy radiated outward by the earth (land and sea) at
a rate&amp;nbsp;depending on the absolute temperature of the earth.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A sudden motion or trembling in the Earth caused by the abrupt release of&#xd;

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GEOLOGICAL ADVISORIES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reports providing information on changes in environmental factors including&#xd;
warnings of potential threat to life, property, agricultural resources, and/or&#xd;
the environment arising from the natural processes that occur within the Earth.
These processes include but are not limited to those that create, deform,&#xd;
destroy, and/or recycle the lithosphere of the Earth.	&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="09d00879-6d96-4df4-9f50-73bd761118d9"/>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The pattern of constructive and destructive interference that

few minutes'&amp;nbsp;time.      &amp;nbsp;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ozone (O3) that is measured  in the lowest 10-20 km of the Atmosphere.
While&amp;nbsp;the maximum concentration of ozone occurs between 20-25 km, a
high&amp;nbsp;concentration of ozone close to the Earth's surface is considered a
public&amp;nbsp;health threat. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="64d4ff80-59bb-4565-8759-e5223939abfd"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">EAST ATLANTIC PATTERN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The East Atlantic (EA) pattern is the second prominent mode of low-frequency variability over the North Atlantic, and appears as a leading mode in all months. The EA pattern is structurally similar to the NAO, and consists of a north-south dipole of anomaly centers spanning the North Atlantic from east to west. The anomaly centers of the EA pattern are displaced southeastward to the approximate nodal lines of the NAO pattern. For this reason, the EA pattern is often interpreted as a âsouthward shiftedâ NAO pattern. However, the lower-latitude center contains a strong subtropical link in association with modulations in the subtropical ridge intensity and location. This subtropical link makes the EA pattern distinct from its NAO counterpart. This EA pattern is similar to that shown in the Barnston and Livezey (1987) study, but is distinctly different from the EA pattern originally defined by Wallace and Gutzler (1981).

The positive phase of the EA pattern is associated with above-average surface temperatures in Europe in all months, and with below-average temperatures over the southern U.S. during January-May and in the north-central U.S. during July-October. It is also associated with above-average precipitation over northern Europe and Scandinavia, and with below-average precipitation across southern Europe.

The EA pattern exhibits very strong multi-decadal variability in the 1950-2004 record, with the negative phase prevailing during much of 1950-1976, and the positive phase occurring during much of 1977-2004. The positive phase of the EA pattern was particularly strong and persistent during 1997-2004, when 3-month running mean values routinely averaged 1.0-2.0 standard deviations above normal.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b887d3e5-4280-43d2-a34e-0f63ac086b6a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="739f9b7e-3ca7-4f0b-8ce2-68753fc0a6d9"/>
   <skos:changeNote>2012-06-25 11:52:56.0 [mpmorahan] Insert Concept 
add narrower relation (EAST ATLANTIC PATTERN [64d4ff80-59bb-4565-8759-e5223939abfd,21717] - EATL [739f9b7e-3ca7-4f0b-8ce2-68753fc0a6d9,39735]); 
</skos:changeNote>
</skos:Concept>

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR FLARES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An abrupt release, from a localized region on the Sun, of large amounts of
energy in ultraviolet light, x-radiation, and occasionally gamma radiation.
Flares usually occur in or near complex sunspot regions and may be related to
the rearrangement of the intense magnetic fields there.&#xd;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="58c12630-a889-44c1-a951-56bbbe9758c9"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FRACTURE ZONES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Fracture zones are large, linear zone of irregular bathymetry of the sea floor,
characterized by asymmetric ridges and troughs. Fracture zones are the
topographic expression of transform faults, faults with horizontal displacement
connecting the ends of an offset in a mid-ocean ridge.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c16bda61-353b-4668-af2f-bbb98785b6fa"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d7ef7608-01f5-4e95-9fd9-7dc2aa36113d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NINO 3 INDEX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The NiÃ±o 3 index is an average of the sea surface temperatures in the region 150 degrees West - 90 degrees West (longitude) and 5 degrees North to 5 degrees South (latitude). When the index is positive (red) then waters are warmer than normal and when the index is negative (blue) then waters are cooler than normal. El NiÃ±os occur when the water is much warmer than normal for a sustained period of time. For example, El NiÃ±os occured in 1982-83, 1986-87 and 1997-98</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b83895e9-bac8-49fe-bcf5-8fe4d8fcaa16"/>

</skos:changeNote>

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CLOUD OPTICAL DEPTH/THICKNESS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The degree to which a cloud prevents light from passing through it.
Optical&amp;nbsp;thickness depends upon the physical constitution (crystals, drop,
droplets),&amp;nbsp;the form, the concentration of particles, and the vertical
extent of the cloud.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="162e2243-3266-4999-b352-d8a1a9dc82ac"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b709d6fc-f0cf-47de-bdbb-1cd875b5f3ab"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CLOUD PRECIPITABLE WATER</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The total atmospheric water vapor contained in a vertical column of
unit&amp;nbsp;cross-sectional area (in a cloud) extending between any two specified
levels,&amp;nbsp;commonly expressed in terms of the height to which that water
substance would&amp;nbsp;stand if completely condensed and collected in a vessel of
the same unit cross&amp;nbsp;section.  &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="162e2243-3266-4999-b352-d8a1a9dc82ac"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8a6572c3-676a-41dd-851f-836ac9f1f1d9"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CLOUD REFLECTANCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ratio of the intensity of reflected radiation to that of the incident&#xd;
radiation on a cloud. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="162e2243-3266-4999-b352-d8a1a9dc82ac"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">For a given cloud or cloud layer, the lowest level in the atmosphere at which

See also the definitions for cloud height and cloud ceiling.

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Models that represent continuous elevation values over a topographic surface by

Models (DEM) and Digital Terrain Models (DTM) are used to predict the
topography and terrain over a given land surface.
