</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="3d64f625-fb84-4178-ad08-4be2dd15979b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LAKES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An inland body of water, small to moderately large, with its surface
water&amp;nbsp;exposed to the atmosphere.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="5debb283-51e4-435e-b2a2-e8e2a977220d"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b409a30b-0e3f-4592-bec9-7d371797b4a9"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GLACIAL LANDFORMS/PROCESSES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A glacier is an accumulation of ice, air, water, and rock debris or&#xd;
sediment. It is a large enough quantity of ice to flow with gravity due to&#xd;
its own mass. The ice can be as large as a continent, such as the ice&#xd;
sheet covering Antarctica; or, it can fill a small valley between two&#xd;
mountains, such as a valley glacier. "Glacial landforms/processes"&#xd;
refers to the erosional or depositional processes of glaciers and the&#xd;
landforms (e.g., drumlins, cirques, fjords) that result. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d35b9ba5-d018-48a5-8f0d-92b9c55b3279"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f24c4f33-5b89-4e8d-8de7-296078a7f18a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LIGHTNING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Generally, any and all of the various forms of visible electrical
discharge&amp;nbsp;produced by thunderstorms.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b7d562cf-9b9b-4461-900b-50423a8c4d29"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1651d2e2-4483-42fc-aef2-fd49e650eff1"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CAVE DEPOSITS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Cave deposits, or speleothems, are mineral formations in caves. While the water
flows, the speleothems grow in thin, shiny layers. The amount of growth is an
indicator of how much ground water dripped into the cave. Little growth might
indicate a drought, just as rapid growth could point to heavy precipitation.
When the speleothems stop growing, the outside becomes dirty and eroded in
places, giving it a dull appearance. Spelothems can be dated by measuring how
much uranium has decayed. Evidence of past climate changes can be inferred from
measuring oxygen isotopes in speleothems.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="486f2c33-2401-4292-9d74-8756ee95211f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8c615709-df55-4b09-a5a9-1fabb133fe1a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GLACIATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A glaciation (a created composite term meaning Glacial Period, referring to the
Period or Era of, as well as the process of High Glacial Activity), often
called an ice age, is a geological phenomenon in which massive ice sheets form
in the Arctic and Antarctic and advance toward the equator. Conversely, the
term interglacial or Interglacial Period, such as the current era, is used to
denote the absence of large-scale glaciation on a global scale Â¿ i.e., a
non-Ice Age. Interglacials are, in general, shorter than glacial epochs.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="486f2c33-2401-4292-9d74-8756ee95211f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="733234ec-053b-4595-811a-b221e6afb35e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LOESS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Loess is a deposit of wind-blown silt and dust of Pleistocene age that covers
large areas of the continents. It is predominently calcerous consisting of
quartz feldspars and micas. Loess is extensive in the North American Great
Plains, south-central Europe, Ukraine, central Asia, China, and Argentina.
Loess deposits in North America are related to large outwashes from the
Laurentide ice sheet and floodplains of large rivers. Loess deposits in Europe
are related to the former Alpine and Scandinavianice sheets. Loess in China and
central Asia are related to desert conditions.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="486f2c33-2401-4292-9d74-8756ee95211f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f2ceb98b-4b5d-4ee6-b033-e987d2f820f1"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PALEOMAGNETIC DATA</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Paleomagnetism is the study of natural remnant magnetization of the Earth's&#xd;
materials in order to determine the itensity and direction of the Earth's&#xd;
magnetic field in the geologic past. Variations in the Earth's magnetic field&#xd;
can be used as a means of stratigraphic correlation. Major reversals of the&#xd;
Earth's magnetic field are well known and the record of these reversals in&#xd;
sediments can be used as time markers or chronostratigraphic horizons.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="486f2c33-2401-4292-9d74-8756ee95211f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b54e01eb-02d9-413a-baf1-40a6e59d9eae"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PALEOSOLS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Paleosols are soils that formed in a landscape of the past with distinctive
morphological features resulting from a soil-forming environment that no longer
exists at the site.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="486f2c33-2401-4292-9d74-8756ee95211f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e4871f3e-bc88-4380-b7b7-3a18afccc2bd"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PALEOVEGETATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Paleovegetation refers to plant species that were living at some time in the
past. Indicators of past vegetation include pollen and plant macrofossils.
Animal fossils and sedimentary indicators can also be used to reconstruct past
vegetation.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="486f2c33-2401-4292-9d74-8756ee95211f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="14c8721e-4d05-4aaa-90be-8607ae2f84b1"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">POLLEN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pollen are several-celled microgametophyte of seed plants enclosed in a
microspore wall. Fossil pollen consists entirely of the microspore wall. The
study of pollen is called palynology or pollen analysis and is an important
aspect in reconstructing past climates. Paleoclimatic reconstructions by pollen
analysis is possible because (1) pollen grains possess morphological
characteristics that are specif to a particular genus or species of plant; (2)
they are produced in vast quantities by wind-pollinated plants and are
distributed widely from their source; (3) they are extremely resistant to
decay; and (4) they reflect the natural vegetation at the time of pollen
deposition, which can yield information about ast climatic conditions.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="486f2c33-2401-4292-9d74-8756ee95211f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ac45c059-9555-45ee-ad20-d58514578f1e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">STRATIGRAPHIC SEQUENCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A set of deposited sedimentary beds that reflects the depositional&#xd;
environment of those beds and the geologic history of a region. &#xd;
A stratigraphic sequence is a chronologic succession of sedimentary rocks from
older below to younger above without interruption.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="486f2c33-2401-4292-9d74-8756ee95211f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9761565c-2126-49cd-b4c4-cd3bcb5dbbde"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">VOLCANIC DEPOSITS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Volcanic deposits can consist of tephra, which is airborne pyroclastic
material. Extremely explosive volcanic eruptions can produce vast quatntities
of tephra over wide areas. Tephra layers can form regional isochronous
stratigraphic markers. Tephrachronology can a very important tool in
paleoclimatic studies. Volcanic ash horizons can also be used as
chronostratigraphic markers.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="486f2c33-2401-4292-9d74-8756ee95211f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5a63fa7f-2971-4874-a920-394df07d218e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BOREHOLES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Boreholes are holes drilled deep into the ground (or ocean crust). Profiles of
rock temperatures with depth can be related to the history of temperature
changes at the surface, which can be converted to estimates of air temperature.
Borehhole temperature measurements can provide estimates of local temperature
variations over time intervals of a few hundred to over a thousand years. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="486f2c33-2401-4292-9d74-8756ee95211f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="efe175a0-100b-404b-a702-2e179bee034a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">STRATIGRAPHIC SEQUENCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A set of deposited sedimentary beds that reflects the depositional environment
of those beds and the geologic history of a region.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="1e17c8d3-81d0-473c-8f24-d2a4ea52b6b9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="07b53dde-6fea-4662-9d03-ccfd617ca710"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PHOTOSYNTHESIS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Photosynthesis is the synthesis of carbohydrates from carbon dioxide and
water&amp;nbsp;by chlorphyll using light as energy with oxygen as a
byproduct.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="233a4d81-44f8-4b0e-8ad3-695f641729f8"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e757b032-bfa4-4976-b98a-838f61a86ea8"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FLOODS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A rising body of water (as in a stream, lake, or sea, or behind a dam) that&#xd;
overlaps its natural or artificial confines and that covers land not normally&#xd;
under water, esp. any relatively high streamflow that overflows its banks in&#xd;
any reach of the stream, or that is measured by gage height or discharge&#xd;
quantity.    &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&#xd;
A Flood Advisory reports on conditions favorable for flooding and will provide&#xd;
locations in which flooding is more likely.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="7406a787-6ab6-429f-bc09-9a86d393e114"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c5b13fa4-0069-40ce-85cb-bfbab34c2058"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">COUPLED CLIMATE MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Coupled atmosphere-ocean general circulation models (AOGCMs) are the most
complex models in use, consisting of an Atmosphere general circulation model
(AGCM) coupled to an Ocean general circulation models (OGCM). With the addition
of other components (such as a sea ice model or a model for evapotranspiration
over land), the AOGCM becomes the basis for a full climate model. &#xd;
Some recent models include the biosphere, carbon cycle and atmospheric
chemistry as well. AOGCMs can be used for the prediction and rate of change of
future climate. They are also used to study the variability and physical
processes of the coupled climate system. Global climate models typically have a
resolution of a few hundred kilometres. Climate projections from the Hadley
Centre make use of the HadCM2 AOGCM, developed in 1994, and its successor
HadCM3 AOGCM, developed in 1998. Greenhouse-gas experiments with AOGCMs have
usually been driven by specifying atmospheric concentrations of the gases, but
if a carbon cycle model is included, the AOGCM can predict changes in carbon
dioxide concentration, given the emissions of carbon dioxide into the
atmosphere. Similarly, an AOGCM coupled to an atmospheric chemistry model is
able to predict the changes in concentration of other atmospheric constituents
in response to climate change and to the changing emissions of various gases.
Further information is available on: some aspects of ocean simulation in HadCM3
(thermohaline circulation, ventilation, vertical mixing), decadal variability
in the ocean of HadCM3.&#xd;
Recently a global coupled climate model with an eddy-permitting ocean
resolution has been developed at the Hadley Centre, in order to better
represent important oceanic processes. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f342683b-94ee-4ef6-8915-b18a473fafbd"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">VOLCANIC ACTIVITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Activity pertaining to a vent in the surface of the Earth through which magma&#xd;
and associated gases and ash erupt.   &lt;br&gt;&#xd;
A Volcanic Activity Advisory may include reports on erupting volcanoes,&#xd;
seismic/GPS information that may predict a pending eruption, and volcanic ash. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="13b8bcd4-7566-49e5-9975-ea15470474ab"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b560f23d-f190-4c41-8bd9-4650a83296af"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BRYOZOANS/MOSS ANIMALS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="abc6f016-d1f0-4725-b847-639de054d13f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="36a4ac5a-1082-4922-9bca-934c06e54cda"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LANDSCAPE MANAGEMENT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The identificaion, assessment, design, and manipulation of features or&#xd;
values of a landscape. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="f36d71c6-f2ad-49c4-809f-09b4f0688412"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="53f69037-ff05-4b09-a95d-e65ff42da595"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RADAR IMAGERY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A mapping of the observed radar reflectivity of a scene, consisting of a&#xd;
file of digital numbers assigned to spatial	  positions on a grid of&#xd;
pixels. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d3b7c3c0-e644-4f01-94da-dfebe854c0d1"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5c349776-dd95-483e-a5da-e8d1b1434985"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A measure of the ability of a soil to transfer heat (through a unit
thickness,&amp;nbsp;across a unit area for a unit difference in temperature).&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="199e3af8-4cf3-48ba-8b28-b9b54756b3db"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="2c1cf609-c70d-4811-8514-3ca45a8bb380"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ROUNDWORMS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Roundworms are mostly worm-like and unsegmented, with an external cuticle,
a&amp;nbsp;pseudocoelom between body wall and gut, an anus and complex nervous
system but&amp;nbsp;not circulatory system.  They are mostly free living bottom
dwellers in marine&amp;nbsp;and freshwater environments and in the soil.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="abc6f016-d1f0-4725-b847-639de054d13f"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The timeseries is calculated from the HadISST and the NCEP OI Datasets. It is the standardized Nina 12 minus the Nina 4 with a 5 month running mean applied which is then standardized using the 1950-1979 period. </skos:definition>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Deforestation is the removal of trees from a locality. <skos:Concept rdf:about="2f4ccb5c-7b99-442c-9054-964070d95f7b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">VOLCANIC DEPOSITS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Volcanic deposits (including volcanic ash, debris, etc.) are found within ice
core&#xd;
records. Volcanoes can produce large quantities of particles and leave a record
in the ice. Scanning electron micrographs of the particles from a particularly
large dust peak in an ice core may reveal that it is from a known volcano and
allow a firm date to be placed on that section of core. For prehistoric times,
the dust record is a key tool for reconstructing a history of volcanic
activity. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="dba19648-3f52-48ba-b00b-8527d44c4d74"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="46172bbe-8bf0-49a0-848f-129c089aeb8e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TECTONIC LANDFORMS/PROCESSES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">"Tectonic landforms" are structural landforms of regional extent. These&#xd;
landforms make up extensive landscapes whose topography is strongly influenced&#xd;
by the structure of underlying rocks that have undergone (or are undergoing)&#xd;
some degree of deformation (and possible associated metamorphism and igneous&#xd;
intrusion). Landscapes developed on orogenic belts, uplifts, domes, basins, and
shields can all be thought of as tectonic landforms. "Tectonic processes" are&#xd;
large-scale geologic processes that develop these landforms and include&#xd;
mountain &#xd;
building and crustal rifting.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b5cb1fab-7281-478f-bb3b-ff04f900b3fc"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="48c16952-b6e0-40cd-b6dd-7cdbf5a443a1"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ALBEDO</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Albedo is the ratio of the radiation (radiant energy or luminous
energy)&amp;nbsp;reflected by a surface to that incident on it. Snow and cloud
surfaces have a&amp;nbsp;high albedo, because most of the energy of the visible
solar spectrum is&amp;nbsp;reflected. Vegetation and ocean surfaces have low
albedo, because they absorb a&amp;nbsp;large fraction of the energy. Clouds are the
chief cause of variations in the&amp;nbsp;Earth's albedo.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="dcb100c9-5b43-422a-a429-25cae9dbb170"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">REFORESTATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Restocking an area with forest trees.&amp;nbsp;

   <skos:broader rdf:resource="f36d71c6-f2ad-49c4-809f-09b4f0688412"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="061f7fd0-67af-42bf-bc9f-5a007c146f65"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ABSORPTION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The process by which incident radiant energy is retained by a substance.
The&amp;nbsp;absorbed radiation is converted to another form of energy according to
the&amp;nbsp;nature of the absorbing medium.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1ed8ac8d-3a66-4b86-be30-a5b79b3806d2"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ATMOSPHERIC EMITTED RADIATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The part of the terrestrial radiation which is emitted by the atmosphere.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="06a24fd2-38b6-4a4a-a0cf-1abf149283e2"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ATMOSPHERIC HEATING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Atmospheric heating has been used to refer to the heat transfer or heat
balance&amp;nbsp;of the Earth's atmosphere. Heat transfer is the exchange of heat
by radiation,&amp;nbsp;conduction, or convection. Heat balance is the balance of
the gains and losses&amp;nbsp;of heat at any point in the atmosphere.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="49c8770a-2eb7-40f1-aab0-9c12d3aed031"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">EMISSIVITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The ratio of the emittance of a given surface at a specified wavelength
and&amp;nbsp;emitting temperature to the emittance of an ideal black body at the
same&amp;nbsp;wavelength and temperature. Emissivity has a value between 0 (least)
and one&amp;nbsp;(greatest).&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="46a3c823-727d-4c3c-b09d-e3e3fcaa43a5"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HEAT FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Heat flux is the amount of heat that is transferred across a surface of&#xd;
unit area in a unit of time. Also refers to latent and sensible heat&#xd;
fluxes in the atmosphere and between the Earth's surface and&#xd;
atmosphere. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="68323795-3614-462f-8259-bd5293620799"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LONGWAVE RADIATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Longwave radiation is radiation with wavelengths longer than 4 micros.
Also&amp;nbsp;referred to as infrared radiation or terrestrial radiation.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="50ee8910-449b-46c8-a59b-1cd76d632b44"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NET RADIATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Net radiation refers to the difference between the downward and upward
(total&amp;nbsp;and terrestrial) radiation. The net flux of all radiations. Canalso
refer to&amp;nbsp;the net solar radiation which is the difference between the sola\
r radiations&amp;nbsp;directed downwards and upwards.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="13723b5d-1945-4e62-8672-4535ffdddb87"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">OPTICAL DEPTH/THICKNESS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">In radiative transfer, optical thickness or optical depth is the mass of
a&amp;nbsp;given absorbing or emitting material in a vertical column of
unit&amp;nbsp;cross-sectional area and extending between two specified
levels.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="006b1ea6-222d-4740-b220-03886d49cd81"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">OUTGOING LONGWAVE RADIATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The outgoing longwave radiation (OLR) refers specifically to the
radiation&amp;nbsp;emitted by the Earth and its atmosphere (the terrestrial
radiation). Satellite&amp;nbsp;measurements of the OLR from terrestrial surfaces
and clouds show that OLR is&amp;nbsp;low over cold land and high clouds and high
over hot land surfaces. Climate&amp;nbsp;variations, such as El Nino Southern
Oscillation (ENSO) can be measured from&amp;nbsp;OLR anomalies from longer-term
variations.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="107582ef-a356-4afa-a9a4-4e1d2200c134"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RADIATIVE FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The amount of radiation incident on a given surface per unit time.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4fad64ce-32fe-413d-8b55-c78000d1980c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RADIATIVE FORCING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A change imposed upon the climate system which modifies the radiative
balance&amp;nbsp;of that system. The causes of such a change may include changes in
the sun,&amp;nbsp;clouds, ice, greenhouse gases, volcanic activity, and other
agents. Radiative&amp;nbsp;forcing is often specified as the net change in energy
flux at the troposphere&amp;nbsp;(watts per square meter). Radiative forcing may
sometimes be referred to as&amp;nbsp;external forcing or perturbations of the
climate.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ec9e0b6a-1315-4569-93bc-0f1190bb8c08"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SCATTERING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The process in which a wave or beam of particles is diffused or deflected&#xd;
by collisions with particles of the medium which it traverses. Along&#xd;
with absorption, scattering is a major cause of the attenuation of&#xd;
radiation by the atmosphere. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a8f5c969-34e9-4284-afb5-ff2113f5f881"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SHORTWAVE RADIATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Shortwave radiation is radiation at wavelengths shorter than 4
microns.&amp;nbsp;Sometimes called the solar radiation. Usually radiation in the
visible and&amp;nbsp;near-infrared wavelengths.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="de7647c9-b129-4cba-afe4-63fa9998206e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR IRRADIANCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Solar irradiance at the top of the atmosphere on a plane normal to the
incident&amp;nbsp;radiation, and at the mean distance of the Earth from the Sun.
Solar irradiance&amp;nbsp;is also referred to as the solar constant. In satellite
remote sensing, the&amp;nbsp;solar irradiance is used as an onboard calibrartion of
visible band sensors.&amp;nbsp;Some climate studies suggest that small variations
in the solar irradiance&amp;nbsp;associated with solar activity over days to
decades may have an effect the&amp;nbsp;Earth's climate.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a0f3474e-9a54-4a82-97c4-43864b48df4c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR RADIATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Solar radiation is the total electromagnetic radiation emitted by the Sun.
Also&amp;nbsp;could include insolation, direct solar radiation, diffuse radiation,
solar&amp;nbsp;irradiance, and shortwave radiation.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="714be1d7-2012-4a98-bdd5-02bbcadf69d8"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TRANSMITTANCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A measure of the amount of radiation propagated through a given medium.
defined&amp;nbsp;as the ratio of transmitted radiation to the total radiation
incident upon the&amp;nbsp;medium. Also known as transmissivity.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="90e7fd13-2da2-4ba6-9e0c-dbecdf7c2215"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ULTRAVIOLET RADIATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Electromagnetic radiation of shorter wavelength than visible radiation
but&amp;nbsp;longer than x-rays. Radiation in the interval 10 to 4000 angstroms.
UV&amp;nbsp;radiation from the sun is responsible for many photochemical ractions
in the&amp;nbsp;upper atmosphere especially the formation of ozone. UV-B radiation
in the range&amp;nbsp;280-320 nm can possibly have serious health effects on humans
and animals.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="bf22e55d-fbff-4eaf-8592-68be24e2bc32"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AIRGLOW</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A faint luminescence of the night sky originating in photochemical reactions in
the upper atmosphere. Also referred to as geocoronal emission. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="4ad0c52d-6449-48ff-8678-adc6b2cebcb7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="90f97e5b-f883-4a34-a3bc-7dea8d96eb7d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BIOLUMINESCENCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The production of visible light by organisms. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="457883c4-b30c-4d26-bed8-6c2887ebbc90"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="356a10e1-c81d-44c7-9706-31f7f2642586"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RECLAMATION/REVEGETATION/RESTORATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">RESTORATION: The processes by which an area is treated in  an attempt
to&amp;nbsp;restore original conditions.  RECLAIMATION: The process of reconverting
land&amp;nbsp;to other  forms of productive uses.  REVEGETATION: Reestablishment
of&amp;nbsp;vegetation which may take  place naturally or be induced by humans
through&amp;nbsp;seeding or transplanting.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="199e3af8-4cf3-48ba-8b28-b9b54756b3db"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="20b41061-e6dc-47ef-b73b-00dc08a59618"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SCATTERING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The process by which some of a stream of radiation is dispersed to travel&#xd;
in directions other than that which from it was incident by particles&#xd;
suspended in the medium through which it is travelling.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="457883c4-b30c-4d26-bed8-6c2887ebbc90"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a8f6e91f-7875-4597-8ab8-64f4b14e8b49"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LANDSLIDES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A general term covering a wide variety of mass-movement landforms and processes
involving the downslope transport, under gravitational influence, of soil and&#xd;
rock material en masse.  Usually the displaced material move over a relatively&#xd;
confined zone or surface of shear.  The wide range of sites and structures, and
of material properties affecting resistance to shear, result in a great range&#xd;
of landslide morephology, rates, patterns of movement, and scale.  Landsliding&#xd;
is usually preceded, accompanied, and followed by imperceptible creep along the
surface of sliding and/or within the slide mass.  Terminology designating&#xd;
landslide types generally refers to the landform as well as the process&#xd;
responsible for it, e.g. rockfall, translational slide, block glide, avalanche,
mudflow, liquefaction slide and slump. &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt; &#xd;
A Landslide Advisory may be included in other types of advisories such as ones&#xd;
for earthquakes, volcanic activity, and floods. Landslide advisories may also
take the form of landslide susceptibility and probability maps.      &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="13b8bcd4-7566-49e5-9975-ea15470474ab"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="83520258-413c-4842-93c0-58a23dc58638"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEAMOUNTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Isolated steep-sided volcanic peak that rises abruptly at least 1000 m from the
sea floor, sometimes piercing the surface to become islands.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c16bda61-353b-4668-af2f-bbb98785b6fa"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c7708bb6-a0fa-4905-b99d-c468da7d951a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE DEPTH/THICKNESS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ice depth or thickness refers to the extent of the ice below the surface of
the&amp;nbsp;water. The term is also used in river and lake ice studies. Remote
sensing&amp;nbsp;techniques (particularly radar and microwave) have been used to
estimate ice&amp;nbsp;thickness as have recently declassified submarine
measurements of polar ice&amp;nbsp;thickness. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="860e2af9-ce29-4f3f-b027-ae3747eb3e01"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="29a64468-46a8-4dbc-955d-80b7b4cf9aaf"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RESPIRATION RATE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The chemical process that occurs in all living cells wherein organic
compounds&amp;nbsp;are broken down to release energy required for life
processes.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="233a4d81-44f8-4b0e-8ad3-695f641729f8"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a61d1705-a6b7-4df3-9f8e-57e26029629c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BEACHES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The gently sloping shore of a body of water which is washed by waves or
tides,&amp;nbsp;especially the parts covered by sand or  pebbles.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9361962c-cfc7-4428-8843-b3502718c382"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8d38de3b-2d05-4ad2-a960-f47a66191319"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DUNES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Mounds, ridges, or hills of wind-blown sand, either bare or covered
with&amp;nbsp;vegetation.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9361962c-cfc7-4428-8843-b3502718c382"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="fa3c6df8-a1e1-41d5-9de1-49b92e1ea455"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ISLANDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Tracts of land smaller than a continent, surrounded by the water of an
ocean,&amp;nbsp;sea, lake, or stream.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9361962c-cfc7-4428-8843-b3502718c382"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f8d55ee4-1efb-4d83-b07f-1029ab0fa9e1"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SAVANNAS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An open, grassy, essentially treeless plain,  especially as developed
in&amp;nbsp;tropical or subtropical regions.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9361962c-cfc7-4428-8843-b3502718c382"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="3e59af3d-500b-4c66-a9a1-76db5cf4a00b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">URBAN LANDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Areas that have been altered or obstructed by humans, especially by
structures&amp;nbsp;relating to cities.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9361962c-cfc7-4428-8843-b3502718c382"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e9ed684e-5252-4091-a794-aaf6e5f249ed"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RADIONUCLIDES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Nuclides which are unstable and that decay or disintegrate
spontaneously,&amp;nbsp;emitting radiation. A synonym for radioactive nuclide.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6eb3919b-85ce-4988-8b78-9d0018fd8089"/>
</skos:Concept>

measure radiance from marine aerosols.	 &#xd;

   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e5a401b-1507-4f57-82b8-36557c13b154"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="3b54403e-25a1-43cc-97ac-7c14e73bda96"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOIL SALINITY/SOIL SODICITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The term salinity refers to the presence of the major dissolved
inorganic&amp;nbsp;solutes, essentially Na, Mg, Ca, K, Cl, SO4, HCO3, and CO3, in
aqueous samples.&amp;nbsp;As applied to soils, it refers to the soluble plus
readily dissolvable salts in&amp;nbsp;the soil or, more usually, in an aqueous
extract of a soil sample.  Salinity is&amp;nbsp;quantified in terms of the total
concentration (or, occasionally, the content)&amp;nbsp;of such soluble salts.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="199e3af8-4cf3-48ba-8b28-b9b54756b3db"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b6b51058-1111-4498-a9ac-e1515270fb27"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEAFLOOR TOPOGRAPHY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">General elevation pattern of the land surface or the ocean bottom.  Also refer
to as bathymetry, the study and mapping of sea floor elevations and the
variations of water depth; the topography of the sea floor.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c16bda61-353b-4668-af2f-bbb98785b6fa"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0b011562-ee55-4ba0-a026-4faa7493ca5b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ABYSSAL HILLS/PLAINS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to geophysical (seismic, magnetic, gravity, etc.) data collected&#xd;
on the plains and hills of the deep oceanic floor. &#xd;
ABYSSAL HILLS: Small hills found only in the deep sea which rise from the ocean
basin floor with heights ranging from 10 to over 500 feet and widths from a few
hundred feet to a few miles. They are found along the seaward margin of most&#xd;
abyssal plains and originate from the spreading of mid-ocean ridges. As such,&#xd;
they usually form two strips parallel to mid-ocean ridges. They generally&#xd;
decrease in height as one traverses away from the ridges as they gradually&#xd;
become covered with sediment and are replaced by abyssal plains.&#xd;
ABYSSAL PLAINS: Flat areas of the ocean basin floor which slope less than 1&#xd;
part in 1000. These were formed by turbidity currents which covered the&#xd;
preexisting topography. Most abyssal plains are located between the base of the
continental rise and the abyssal hills. The remainder are trench abyssal plains
that lie in the bottom of deep-sea trenches. This latter type traps all&#xd;
sediment from turbidity currents and prevents abyssal plains from forming&#xd;
further seaward, e.g. much of the Pacific Ocean floor.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c16bda61-353b-4668-af2f-bbb98785b6fa"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a91a00f7-05ed-4633-9fac-1772a48b6342"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CONTINENTAL MARGINS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The ocean floor from the shore of a continent to the abyssal plain.  The
continent margin is the zone separating the continents from the deep-sea
bottom, usually subdivided into the continental shelf, slope, and rise.  &#xd;
They are two basic types of continental margins: passive, or Atlantic, margins
and active, or Pacific, margins.  Passive margins have little seismic or
volcanic activity and form when continents are rifted apart, creating a new
ocean basin between them.  Active margins are tectonically active and are most
often associated with plate convergence and subduction.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c16bda61-353b-4668-af2f-bbb98785b6fa"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="73e02157-9df9-415f-93fc-cb457989ddb1"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">OCEAN PLATEAUS/RIDGES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Geological features pertaining to the large, flat rises or ridges.  A ridge is
a long, narrow elevation of the sea floor, with steep sides and irregular
topography.  Ocean plateaus refer to an area of highland, usually consisting of
relatively flat rises, and are formed when land has been uplifted and then
eroded by wind or water.  
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c16bda61-353b-4668-af2f-bbb98785b6fa"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="18ce5577-26e9-4b76-860b-1ba31cafa9d0"

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SUBMARINE CANYONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Submarine canyon are relatively narrow, V-shaped, deep depression with steep
slopes, the bottom of which grades continuously downward across the continental
slope.	
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c16bda61-353b-4668-af2f-bbb98785b6fa"/>
</skos:Concept>

into&amp;nbsp;snow-flakes, especially at temperatures warmer than -5 C (23
F).&amp;nbsp;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Management of the human use of the biosphere so that it may yield the greatest&#xd;
sustainable benefit to present generations while maintaining its potential to&#xd;
meet the needs and aspirations of future generations. It includes the&#xd;
preservation, maintenance, sustainable utilisation, restoration and enhancement
of the environment. &#xd;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="77cbdebf-eddf-42b5-8603-e939eccd1780"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LAKE LEVELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Lake level fluctuations can provide important evidence for paleoclimatic
conditions, particulary in arid and semiarid areas. Lake levels are
particularly sensitive to changes in hydrologic balance due to climatic
fluctuations. Lakes may develop and expand if there is an abundance of
precipitation and will recede and even dry up (due to evaporation) during
prolonged droughts. Lake sediment cores are often drilled to provide
stratigraphic clues to past climate conditions.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="45325a01-2522-48d3-bffa-0edf1a934d48"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Anomaly of the average of the monthly SST from 5.5N to 23.5N and 15W to 57.5W. GISST and NOAA OI 1x1 datasets are used to create index. Climatology is 1951-2000.</skos:definition>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The process in which a neutral atom or molecule is given a net electrical
charge. The atomic process in which ions are produced by removing one or more
electrons from an atom, ion, or molecule, typically be collisions with atoms or
electrons (collisional ionization), or by interaction with electromagnetic
radiation (photo-ionization).&#xd;
Reference: the Cambridge Encyclopedia od the Sun, The Cambridge University
Press &#xd;
Cambridge, CB2, 2RU, UK, 2001.
</skos:definition>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Caused by solar flares, radiation storms are made up of photons, electrons, and

breaking chemical bonds in genetic material.	   &#xd;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0976b778-91be-40e7-9ed7-ebbf214bb818"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GROUND WATER DISCHARGE/FLOW</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the amount of water traveling through an aquifer, or&#xd;
aquifer system, measured in units of volume per units of time. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="734f8f27-6976-4b67-8794-c7fc79d6161e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6a2107ab-38ab-42dc-beb0-8ba5f65e8022"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DRAINAGE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the process/method that water discharges out of an aquifer. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="734f8f27-6976-4b67-8794-c7fc79d6161e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="638a22af-4e97-450e-a278-b81338443230"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">INFILTRATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the process by which substances enter an aquifer. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="734f8f27-6976-4b67-8794-c7fc79d6161e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a1bf1e84-c4e7-4154-ad0a-4b9eedf45066"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LAND SUBSIDENCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the process by which the land surface sinks over an aquifer&#xd;
as water is pumped out of it. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="734f8f27-6976-4b67-8794-c7fc79d6161e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d64094ae-774b-4435-8f2e-a54d114e5555"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PERCOLATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the movement of water through the pore space of an aquifer. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="734f8f27-6976-4b67-8794-c7fc79d6161e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c87c086a-933f-44c7-a128-33279b36d7b5"

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SPRINGS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the zones where the water table intersects the land surface,&#xd;
and water flows out of an aquifer without needing to be pumped out of a&#xd;
well. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="734f8f27-6976-4b67-8794-c7fc79d6161e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ecbe9f17-6012-4e39-a707-713973b7d167"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WATER TABLE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The surface defined by the level of freestanding water in fissures and pores at
the top of the saturated zone. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="734f8f27-6976-4b67-8794-c7fc79d6161e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f795b88f-1aba-4548-97f6-7b587e8ba451"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AEROSOL BACKSCATTER</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Redirection of electromagnetic radiation due to the interaction with
molecules&amp;nbsp;or particles. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e5a401b-1507-4f57-82b8-36557c13b154"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="40633fe2-5b32-4bdc-a17b-b1cfebc01ae7"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AEROSOL EXTINCTION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Fractional energy removed from incident beam by scattering plus
absorption;&amp;nbsp;wavelength dependent. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e5a401b-1507-4f57-82b8-36557c13b154"/>
</skos:Concept>

</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e5a401b-1507-4f57-82b8-36557c13b154"/>

&amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="27478148-b4b6-4c89-8829-08d2ee7bfe10"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CLOUD CONDENSATION NUCLEI</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Known as CCN: particles that will take up water to form cloud droplets at
or&amp;nbsp;above a specified supersaturation of water. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1b6342c6-315b-4f4f-b4e3-d6902aaa3e85"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DUST/ASH/SMOKE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Solid materials suspended in the atmosphere in the form of small,
irregular&amp;nbsp;particules, many of which are microscopic in size. Dust and Ash
are due to&amp;nbsp;biogenic and anthropogenic sources such as volcanic eruptions,
salt spray,&amp;nbsp;plant pollen, smoke, industrial processes, etc. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e5a401b-1507-4f57-82b8-36557c13b154"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8929113a-ded5-4c39-b20f-7968ed114317"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ORGANIC PARTICLES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Aerosol particles consisting predominantly of organic compounds, mainly C,
H,&amp;nbsp;O, and lesser amounts of other elements: may be biogenic or
anthropogenic;&amp;nbsp;primary or secondary; some organic compounds in aerosols
may exhibit&amp;nbsp;substantial light absorption. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e5a401b-1507-4f57-82b8-36557c13b154"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ca71b02b-4446-414c-8697-0950d7382cc4"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SULFATE PARTICLES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Atmospheric aerosol particles derived from biogenic or anthropogenic
sulfur&amp;nbsp;emissions; comprised of sulfate compounds (e.g., DMS, sulfuric
acid, ammonium&amp;nbsp;sulfate).&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e5a401b-1507-4f57-82b8-36557c13b154"/>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CHEMICAL WEATHERING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the breakdown of an exisiting rock or mineral through chemical,&#xd;
as opposed to physical, means; i.e., dissolution of limestone by acidic&#xd;
groundwater. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="906e647b-2683-4ae7-9986-1aea15582b52"/>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AMOEBOIDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6a2a2417-1a9c-4767-bffd-6b99f9747bab"/>

</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6f2a1cfb-13f4-444f-a6e6-2d8b29797253"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CILIATES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ciliates are members of the phylum Ciliophora. As their name implies,
ciliates&amp;nbsp;use numerous cilia as locomotor organelles.  The ciliates exhibit
the greatest&amp;nbsp;elaboration of subcellular organelles of any protozoan group,
where, for&amp;nbsp;example, the Paramecium has a special oral groove and
cytopharynx, into which&amp;nbsp;indigestible wastes are expelled from food
vacuoles. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6a2a2417-1a9c-4767-bffd-6b99f9747bab"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="fdb04105-e8ba-4a83-9c35-ed3c931ccc9f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DIATOMS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Diatoms are algae of the Phylum Ochrista that lack flagella.  They have
a&amp;nbsp;jewel-like appearance.	They play an extremely important role in
aquatic food&amp;nbsp;webs in that they are the second most abundant component of
marine plankton&amp;nbsp;(after blue-green algae). &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6a2a2417-1a9c-4767-bffd-6b99f9747bab"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="32ffe87f-c0f0-4398-9a6a-755d7f87a5ff"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SPOROZOANS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Sporozoans are one of four categories of protozoans. Sporozoan is an
informal&amp;nbsp;name for parasitic protistans that complete part of the life
cycle inside&amp;nbsp;specific cells of host organisms.  Many sporozoans cause
human diseases. &amp;nbsp;Plasmodium causes malaria while Cryptosporidium strains
which contaminate many&amp;nbsp;water supplies can cause serious intestinal
disorders. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6a2a2417-1a9c-4767-bffd-6b99f9747bab"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="98b35c6b-5d40-41d0-b29f-a6b159c03b78"

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SLIME MOLDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6a2a2417-1a9c-4767-bffd-6b99f9747bab"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a69dd814-e7c0-437f-ba2a-63500f68c9a3"
