   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PLANKTON</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6a2a2417-1a9c-4767-bffd-6b99f9747bab"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="28dc7895-3365-4bab-9946-3b247f4137b0"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d324729f-cc0d-4943-8d1a-d38335120c00"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEDIMENTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Marine sediments are composed of both biogenic and terrigenous materials.
Biogenic sediments includes the remains of planktic and benthic organisms,
which provide a record of past climate and oceanic circulation. Terrigenous
material provides a record of humidity-aridity variations on the continents,
intensity and direction of winds, and other modes of sediment transport
(rivers, glaciers, erosion, etc.).
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="45325a01-2522-48d3-bffa-0edf1a934d48"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e36c5faa-c772-4bb0-aeca-b361e160ce9d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEAGRASS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b2957a8b-4c60-42aa-ac1c-56a88421702b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9b5474eb-2dc8-4a8e-90b4-872f9fda80d9"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MYRIAPODS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="bb87baf5-3844-4a56-865f-ea5ed420db06"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="d6db51cf-d2d0-4203-94c8-c884579e0cb0"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="582efbf1-ae9c-47f4-8155-c445f3816dd8"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="582efbf1-ae9c-47f4-8155-c445f3816dd8"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CENTIPEDES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Centipedes are in the Class Chilopoda, and are elongate arthropods with
body&amp;nbsp;divided into head and trunk, the latter bearing ten or more pairs of
legs.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9b5474eb-2dc8-4a8e-90b4-872f9fda80d9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d6db51cf-d2d0-4203-94c8-c884579e0cb0"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MILLIPEDES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Millipedes are in the Class Chilopoda, in the Phylum Arthropoda, and
are&amp;nbsp;elongate arthropods with body divided into head and trunk, the latter
bearing&amp;nbsp;never many more than 200 pairs of legs.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="9b5474eb-2dc8-4a8e-90b4-872f9fda80d9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b2800856-f1e3-41aa-bdc4-75e9cd626d3f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE SHEETS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A continuous sheet of land ice that covers a very large area and moves outward&#xd;
in many directions. This type of ice mass is so thick as to mask the land&#xd;
surface contours, in contrast to the smaller and thinner highland ice. The&#xd;
continental glacier of Greenland is sometimes called the Inland Ice. This term&#xd;
is often used to describe the great ice masses that characterized the ice ages. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="099ab1ae-f4d2-48cc-be2f-86bd58ffc4ca"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="84784fef-5b76-45a0-91e0-28788e09fea6"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WATER PRESSURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the measurement of force per unit area exerted on water by&#xd;
the overlying column of water. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="5debb283-51e4-435e-b2a2-e8e2a977220d"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5fb90409-f9b5-46bc-8a6a-7c42e250c7c3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">OXYGEN DEMAND</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Oxygen demand or biochemical oxygen demand is the amount of oxygen that will
be&amp;nbsp;absorbed or "demanded" as wastes are being digested or oxidized in
both&amp;nbsp;biological and chemical processes.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="233a4d81-44f8-4b0e-8ad3-695f641729f8"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="3678d18c-9dca-4743-abc0-1442b4d438d2"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DROUGHT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Drought should be considered relative to some long-term average condition of
balance between precipitation and evapotranspiration (ET) in a particular area,
a condition often perceived as "normal." Common to all types of drought is the&#xd;
fact that they originate from a deficiency of precipitation that results in
water shortage for some activity or for some group. It is also commonly
recognized that other meteorological elements, such as temperature, wind, and&#xd;
relative humidity, may aggravate the severity and impacts of drought in some
instances. &lt;BR&gt;&lt;BR&gt; &#xd;
A Drought Advisory may report on drought occurring in a particular region.    &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="7406a787-6ab6-429f-bc09-9a86d393e114"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b28c7543-e313-43e5-8a27-2d84098d2e11"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AVALANCHE FORECASTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An avalanche is caused when a build up of snow is released down a slope, and is
one of the major dangers faced in the mountains in winter. In an avalanche,
lots of material or mixtures of different types of material fall or slide
rapidly under the force of gravity. Avalanches are often classified by what
they are made of, for example snow, ice, rock or soil avalanches. A mixture of
these would be called a debris avalanche.  &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&#xd;
A large avalanche can run for miles, and can create massive destruction of the 
lower forest and anything else in its path. Avalanches occur when the load on
the upper snow layers exceeds bonding forces (bonding to layer beneath, support
from anchors such as rocks and trees, stress support from top or bottom of
slope). Critical load may be exceeded naturally by adding new snow or by rapid 
loading, by falling ice, cornices and similar means. The bonding forces within 
a snowpack are affected by temperatures (e.g., a lubricated melt layer, or a
fragile crystal layer) before, during and after snowfall. Avalanches are also &#xd;
triggered by humans - because of the additional weight, kicks during skiing &#xd;
(e.g. during jumps) or intentionally by explosives, slope-cuts and other means.
&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt; &#xd;
An Avalanche Advisory reports on conditions favorable for an avalanche and will
provide locations in which an avalanche is more likely to occur.   &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="7406a787-6ab6-429f-bc09-9a86d393e114"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="57383ac5-614c-4b84-9202-e137b000422b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SUN-EARTH INTERACTIONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e9f67a66-e9fc-435c-b720-ae32a2c3d8f5"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="a82d885e-34cd-496a-b34d-17a23ad04126"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="cad91f82-7e2a-43b7-b272-2dc77e2791f4"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="3a942e8a-d2f2-42bf-9e83-b7b3793b100e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="36bab763-b5d7-450a-8328-1c1f935184f4"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ENERGY DEPOSITION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The energy deposited into the atmosphere from ionization of atmospheric&#xd;
gases, as well as excitation of photometric and x-ray emissions.  The&#xd;
ionospheric effects resulting from the energy deposition by incident particle&#xd;
fluxes include:&#xd;
- production of secondary electrons (ionization)&#xd;
- enhanced steady-state electron density&#xd;
- photometric emissions &#xd;
- bremsstrahlung x-rays&#xd;
- conductivity changes&#xd;
- E-region horizontal currents &#xd;
- plasma heating(collisional, Joule heating)&#xd;
- magnetic field perturbations &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a82d885e-34cd-496a-b34d-17a23ad04126"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="bc02662f-d4a1-43c6-833f-836107ae6737"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PARTICLE COMPOSITION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Particle composition refers to the elemental composition of solar particles,
such as protons, electrons, atoms, etc. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a82d885e-34cd-496a-b34d-17a23ad04126"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c39210ba-7659-424b-a2f0-5777a1519115"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PARTICLE DISTRIBUTION FUNCTIONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A characterization of the density of particles located at a given point in
phase space (a combination&#xd;
of either velocity or position coordinates) at a given time. The velocity-space
distribution function gives the number of particles with a particular velocity;
the position-space distribution function is synonymous with the particle
density in position-space.  Different combinations of position and spatial
coordinates are useful in different problems.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a82d885e-34cd-496a-b34d-17a23ad04126"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="68f1ff0e-2e23-4025-ba71-7f6177352311"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PARTICLE SPEED</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The distance per unit time of particles propagating through the Earth's
atmosphere or through the interplanetary magnetic fields as a result of solar
events. For example, the solar wind has a 'fast' component or high speed stream
with a speed of about 10*5 M/sec. and a 'slow' component of about 5x10*4 m/sec.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a82d885e-34cd-496a-b34d-17a23ad04126"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="630c1f3f-73b9-4f80-bc47-4cbf1fa43788"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PARTICLE TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The measure of the heat of an object, namely of the average kinetic energy of
the randomly moving particles in an object.  &#xd;
Reference: the Cambridge Encyclopedia of the Sun, The Cambridge University
Press,&#xd;
Cambridge, CB2, 2RU, UK, 2110.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a82d885e-34cd-496a-b34d-17a23ad04126"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a228b67f-0791-470b-a4ca-71b8da279332"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LAND TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The measurement of the thermal energy of the land.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6a426480-c58f-4b6b-8e35-0975b7f6edb5"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="40d6a3e7-89dd-4399-8fa5-bbc7a0917b4e"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="d559b900-eca6-42a4-9311-0297b2ef98ab"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="8931329c-3f6d-4ba6-913c-27afa8d104c1"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6c44a08d-0a08-47f5-b819-7e561445e613"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LANDSCAPE PROCESSES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The physical processes that shape an area of land, including landforms, living elements of flora and fauna, and human activity and the built environment.  </skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="f36d71c6-f2ad-49c4-809f-09b4f0688412"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="676248f0-75cd-466d-93f1-351440027c82"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">METHYL CHLORIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">CH3Cl, this compound supplies chlorine to the stratosphere by occasional volcanic eruptions and by tropospheric to stratospheric transport. Methyl chloride is also produced by seaweed. The natural chlorine content of the stratosphere as a consequence of these sources is about 0.6 ppbv.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d46a5046-e1c6-4a09-a2f1-db6a21eda611"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1fd206a9-83a7-4f43-902d-003811080fed"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Classifications as to human employment of land; includes settlements, cultivation, pasture, rangeland, and recreation, among others.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2be0af28-a6b8-4fce-82e4-1ad86788a4d5"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="063177a9-14cd-4750-9aa4-ad5d266bd7ad"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ATMOSPHERIC GENERAL CIRCULATION MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Numerical representation of the atmosphere and its phenomena over the entire&#xd;
Earth, using the equations of motion and including radiation, photochemistry,&#xd;
and the transfer of heat, water vapor, and momentum.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f66e185f-7e17-4b5c-bc4e-523ddfbbe9ca"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">COMPONENT PROCESS MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Component Process Models are models that are part of the Earth System
component, including Atmosphere, Ocean, Land Surface Processes, Hydrology,
Snow/Ice, Biospheric (vegetation, ocean biology) Chemistry, and Radiation.
These can be grouped together by a specific process type such as Cloud and
Precipitation Dynamics, Cloud-radiation feedback (Cloud-aerosol interaction,
Atmospheric-land surface coupling, atmosphere-ocean surface coupling, ocean-ice
coupling/interaction), land hydrology (run-off models), Transport models (e.g.
Pollution, Trace constituents) and others. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="93809fc5-da7c-4ca2-9585-70f09bd99898"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PHENOMENOLOGICAL MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Models that focus on an individual terrestrial phenomenon such as Hurricane
track/intensity prediction, El-Nino (ENSO) predictions, Tsunami warming
systems, Air quality index predictions, UV index predictions, Heat wave
predictions, Drought index and predictions, Flood warning/predictions and
Disease outbreak warning systems/predictions.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9a1dd3c3-a126-437e-ad04-9dc0a382d567"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Models that aid in decision support of a specific topic such as population,
irrigation scheduling, coastal zone decisions, ecosystem distribution, crop
yields, water use, energy generation, telecommunications, and space weather
activity.  
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e49f0aae-c2ef-4fd2-aaf4-ddfad074bb75"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">REGULATORY MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Models that provide predictions and analysis of environmental factors such as
air quality and water quality; also included are dispersion modeling. These
models are generally associated with the U.S. EPA to support policy and
regulatory decisions. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f96bf6c8-2f34-412a-b734-b2644f08a329"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GEOLOGIC/TECTONIC/PALEOCLIMATE MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Models that represent or predict the geology over a given area; the tectonic
activity or probability of earthquakes and tectonic movement, or prevention of
future earthquakes; and paleoclimate reconstructions or predictions of future
climate systems. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="640d703f-9312-4f11-8367-30a8bd8fc508"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CARBON CYCLE/CARBON BUDGET MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Models relating to carbon cycle modeling that simulates, over a given period of
time, carbon interactions on the ecosphere.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0a22b06c-eeed-46dc-b41b-af44ca94c419"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CRYOSPHERE MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Cryosphere Models are models that look at the Earth's cryosphere regions, specifically looking at frozen water, snow, permafrost, floating ice, and glaciers. The cryosphere component is directly related to ocean sea-level, therefore is indirectly related to changes in the atmosphere and biosphere.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="46461db7-88ba-446f-bdae-2d1e7f6302c2"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LAND SURFACE MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Models that predict the characteristics of the landscape such as DEMs/DTMs.
Also included are models that predict land surface reflectance including the
scattering, absorption, or reflection of electromagnetic radiation at the land
surface.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1eb8b98b-73a1-4657-beda-76ab6355dd08"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PHYSICAL/LABORATORY MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Physical and laboratory models are models that represent a larger or smaller physical copy of an object or structure. Most commonly, these models are created in laboratories, but can often be located and studied in the real environment. Physical models allow visualization, from examining the model, of information about the thing the model represents.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="92471848-b940-4b31-9165-f106457a4616"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WEATHER RESEARCH/FORECAST MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) Model is a next-generation mesocale&#xd;
numerical weather prediction system designed to serve both operational&#xd;
forecasting and atmospheric research needs. It features multiple dynamical&#xd;
cores, a 3-dimensional variational (3DVAR) data assimilation system, and a&#xd;
software architecture allowing for computational parallelism and system&#xd;
extensibility. WRF is suitable for a broad spectrum of applications across&#xd;
scales ranging from meters to thousands of kilometers.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c61a56a3-c08f-4989-92f3-0f0787688424"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">OCEAN GENERAL CIRCULATION MODELS (OGCM)/REGIONAL OCEAN MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An OGCM is the ocean counterpart of an Atmosphere general circulation model
(AGCM); it is a three-dimensional representation of the ocean and sea ice.
OGCMs are useful by themselves for studying ocean circulation, interior
processes and variability, but they depend on being supplied with data about
surface air temperature and other atmospheric properties.&#xd;
For a list of some Ocean Circulation models, see
http://stommel.tamu.edu/~baum/ocean_models.html&#xd;
http://www.ocean-modeling.org/
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="3668de06-8a7d-4667-beb8-d04dcac619b0"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ATMOSPHERIC CHEMISTRY MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">(A numerical representation of) the chemical constituents of Earth's&#xd;
atmosphere, and the roles they play in influencing the atmosphere's&#xd;
temperature, radiation, and dynamics.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b8615aad-d2eb-45a3-98a7-4adac5bdf5a5"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">EARTH SCIENCE REANALYSES/ASSIMILATION MODELS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Models that deal with the retrospective-analyses or reanalyzes of data.
Reanalyzes blend the continuity and breadth of output data of a numerical model
with the constraint of vast quantities of observational data. The result is a
long-term continuous data record. Merging many different observations together
with an estimate of the variables provided by the model is the main function of
Assimilation models. Global ocean, atmosphere and land surface models are
developed as components of assimilation and forecast systems, as well as for
addressing the weather and climate research questions.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e1f20631-b5b9-438c-b5c2-b1fa0fce100a"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CORONA HOLES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An extended region in the solar corona where the density and temperature are
lower than other places in the corona. The weak diverging and open magnetic
field lines in coronal holes extend radially outward and do not immediately
return to the sun. The high speed part of the solar wind comes from coronal
holes.&#xd;
Reference: the Cambridge Encyclopedia of the Sun, The Cambridge University
Press,&#xd;
Cambridge, CB2, 2RU, UK, 2001.
</skos:definition>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The NINO3.4 index is one of several El NiÃ±o/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) indicators based on sea surface temperatures.

NINO3.4 is the average sea surface temperature anomaly in the region bounded by 5Â°N to 5Â°S, from 170Â°W to 120Â°W. This region has large variability on El NiÃ±o time scales, and is close to the region where changes in local sea-surface temperature are important for shifting the large region of rainfall typically located in the far western Pacific.

An El NiÃ±o or La NiÃ±a event is identified if the 5-month running-average of the NINO3.4 index exceeds +0.4Â°C for El NiÃ±o or -0.4Â°C for La NiÃ±a for at least 6 consecutive months.</skos:definition>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SHORTWAVE RADIATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Shortwave radiation is electromagnetic radiation in the visible
and&amp;nbsp;near-visible portions of the spectrum (0.4 to 1.0 microns). Shortwave
radiation&amp;nbsp;is the small fraction of the sun's total radiated energy
reaching the&amp;nbsp;atmosphere. Shortwave radiation reaching the surface of the
ocean is direct&amp;nbsp;radiation or indirect radiation scattered from the
atmosphere.        &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="63bc0693-52eb-4ebd-a39e-e77e96409072"/>

characteristic&amp;nbsp;rise and fall of temperature associated with the hours of
light and darkness.&amp;nbsp;

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">VIRTUAL TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">In a system of humid air, the temperature of dry air having the same
density&amp;nbsp;and pressure as the humid air.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="35e1f93b-99b3-4430-b477-0ecafa80d67a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="855c22f5-d1e0-4ccf-81bd-c8120e7c4055"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WIND SHEAR</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A sudden variation in the vector of wind flow that is especially dangerous
to&amp;nbsp;aircraft during takeoff and landing.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="346cade5-801a-4afc-9652-48d02905bc4f"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="fc889d75-41f3-4f36-b461-1100536c8f50"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LESSON PLANS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Lesson Plans are defined as Education / Outreach Services that comprise a set of courses, sections, or teaching modules related to a topic or topics within the Earth Sciences and/or Global Environmental Change. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="97675827-9b0a-4d13-a795-d4a3e78c476a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="718fb499-8c55-4fa6-9a07-ac9155d4bc9d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SUSPENDED SOLIDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Particulate matter suspended in the water column, greater than
0.45&amp;nbsp;micrometers, as distinguished from dissolved solids which are less
than 0.45&amp;nbsp;micrometers.  Synonymous with Particulates.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6eb3919b-85ce-4988-8b78-9d0018fd8089"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c0656cbc-5d94-4945-bbfd-1c8eabb059b2"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">OSCILLATIONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The process of regularly varying pressure above and below a mean value,
a&amp;nbsp;periodic process.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="08fd82a1-4370-46a2-82ea-94c0f91498a7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="25fcdcb7-efd2-4d2f-ba57-92bbcc7ba69a"

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SKIN TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Temperature of the top layer of the ice/ocean surface from which
thermal&amp;nbsp;radiation emanates.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="35e1f93b-99b3-4430-b477-0ecafa80d67a"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4809f1e1-1b36-46a7-a7ae-ce55523424e6"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ORBITAL CHARACTERISTICS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Those properties which describe a satellite in its  periodic revolution.
These&amp;nbsp;consist of the satellite's altitude, orbital  inclination (angle
with respect&amp;nbsp;to the equator, thus a polar orbit is  near 90 degrees, while
an equatorial&amp;nbsp;orbit is near 0 degrees), orbital period, etc.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="cda9b483-8711-42b8-82f9-e7d22ce9c62c"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f634ab55-de40-4d0b-93bc-691bf5408ccb"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The degree of hotness or coldness as measured on some definite
temperature&amp;nbsp;scale by means of any of various types of thermometers.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="35e1f93b-99b3-4430-b477-0ecafa80d67a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5223ebeb-a22d-4bb9-b2b2-ed949a10ac29"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ELECTRON FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The rate of flow of electrons through a reference surface. In cgs&#xd;
units, measured in electrons s-1, or simply s-1.    &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="cad91f82-7e2a-43b7-b272-2dc77e2791f4"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d9ce8e7e-44ff-4555-a910-86b87daca0c2"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ION FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An atom (or molecule) which has become charged as a result of gaining or losing
one or more orbiting electrons. A completely ionized atom is one stripped of
all its electrons. Heavy ions are those ionized particles at high energy (MeV
range). Flux is the rate of flow through a reference surface, measured in
particles per unit area.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="cad91f82-7e2a-43b7-b272-2dc77e2791f4"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a2443978-118d-4f7c-843d-dcd0059fe949"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PROTON FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The rate of flow of protons through a reference surface, measured in particles
per unit area.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="cad91f82-7e2a-43b7-b272-2dc77e2791f4"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="67773da0-f5f1-4047-871a-1fb5a5c1621a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HEAVY NUCLEI FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Solar energetic particles consisting of nuclei of elements heavier than protons
and electrons.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="cad91f82-7e2a-43b7-b272-2dc77e2791f4"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8f801f54-9ca9-4ba6-be35-fd87968f24e7"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NEUTRAL PARTICLE FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Neutral atoms or neurons in the solar wind observed in space and on earth
at energies of around 10*7 - 10*9 ev.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="cad91f82-7e2a-43b7-b272-2dc77e2791f4"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8686285f-9949-4a22-ad80-a1bf4d43e122"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">X-RAY FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The rate of flow of x-rays through a reference surface.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="cad91f82-7e2a-43b7-b272-2dc77e2791f4"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="1ef327e1-6139-49ff-87c3-f959ea75a511"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CORONA</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The outermost, high temperature region of the solar atmosphere. Above the
chromosphere and transition region, consisting of almost fully ionized plasma
contained in closed magnetic field loops, called coronal loops or expanding out
along open magnetic field lines to form the solar wind. The corona is a highly
rarefied, low density gas, with electron densities of less than 10*16
electrons/ m*3, heated to temperatures of millions of degrees. The corona is
visible to the unaided eye as a white halo during a total eclipse of the sun.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0d32a340-ee64-4795-9254-09dcaf55bf4c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A region of the solar atmosphere from the photosphere to the corona that
develops when strong magnetic fields emerge from inside the sun. The magnetized
realm in and around the sunspots is called an active region. Radiation from
active regions is enhanced when compared to neighboring areas in the
chromosphere a corona over the whole electromagnetic spectrum. They may last
from a few hours to a few months. They are the sites of intense explosions,
called solar flares.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e2fc7768-955b-4e76-935e-d33805fcc914"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR IMAGERY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Solar imagery refers to solar images obtained for research in any spectral
wavelength from ground or space-borne platforms.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="33f0ec3e-cd6d-498c-9468-749741fc12e2"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR IRRADIANCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Solar irradiance at the top of the atmosphere on a plane normal to the
incidentÂ¿radiation, and at the mean distance of the Earth from the Sun. Solar
irradianceÂ¿is also referred to as the solar constant. In satellite remote
sensing, theÂ¿solar irradiance is used as an onboard calibration of visible band
sensors.Â¿Some climate studies suggest that small variations in the solar
irradianceÂ¿associated with solar activity over days to decades may have an
effect theÂ¿Earth's climate.Â¿&#xd;
The intensity of the sun's radiation at different wavelengths. The radiation is
generally given in terms of solar constant \ S, defined in terms of flux of
total radiation received outside the earth's atmosphere per unit area at mean
sun earth distance., and has the value S = 1.34 X 10*6 ergs cm*-2  sec*-1.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="88bd8ce6-334d-4a42-8d51-5ed074ef5a89"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR OSCILLATIONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The surface of the sun oscillates in certain modes defined by the&#xd;
numberÂ¿of latitudinal and longitudinal modal planes. The sun vibrates&#xd;
inÂ¿multiple modes simultaneously, each mode typically having a&#xd;
differentÂ¿amplitude. Observing the amplitudes of the various solar&#xd;
oscillationÂ¿modes is a way to look inside the sun. A commonly observed&#xd;
phenomena is theÂ¿"5-minute" oscillation, but other periods have been&#xd;
observed from 10 to 160Â¿minutes on the long period scale to about 10&#xd;
seconds on the short periodÂ¿scale. Also observed are so-called "g-mode"&#xd;
oscillations (internal gravityÂ¿waves) generated by turbulent convection&#xd;
below the photosphere.Â¿These oscillations are the result of internal motions of
the sun and their study is known as helioseismology.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="7b52f7f5-4102-4829-8ea3-c0dcdd36bdca"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR PROMINENCES/SOLAR FILAMENTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A term identifying cloud-like features in the solar atmosphere. The&#xd;
features appear as bright structures in the corona above the solar limb&#xd;
and as dark filaments when seen projected against the solar disk. &#xd;
Solar filaments are also known as prominences, can appear as arcs and
properties can vary with the solar cycle. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a15e514b-4b44-4587-a857-34ab7e2d357e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR X-RAY EMISSIONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Solar X-Ray emissions can consist of X-Ray background flux or X-Ray bursts. A
daily average background X-ray flux is in the 1 to 8 angstrom range.  It is a
midday minimum designed to reduce the effects of flares. X-Ray burstsare a
temporary enhancement of the X-ray emission of the sun.  The time-intensity
profile of soft X-ray bursts is similar to that of the H-Alpha profile of an
associated flare. Bursts last from minutes to several hours.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="429d42ef-9b58-4068-b389-0a9e60e55486"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SUNSPOTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An area seen as a dark spot on the PHOTOSPHERE of the sun.  Sunspots&#xd;
are concentrations of magnetic flux, typically occurring in bipolar&#xd;
clusters or groups.  They appear dark because they are cooler than the&#xd;
surrounding photosphere. Sunspots are classified as to their group&#xd;
characteristics (called the Zurich Sunspot Classification; older sunspot&#xd;
counting schemes may have used the Wolf Sunspot Number classification).&#xd;
Satellite observations of the sun (notably by the ACRIM and ERBE sensors)&#xd;
have demonstrated a correlation between sunspot luminosity changes and&#xd;
sunspot numbers - a possible influencing factor in Earth's climate&#xd;
dynamics. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ace2d2e5-0b9a-472e-b27b-c687b9108076"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR SYNOPTIC MAPS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Synoptic maps refer to the state of the entire viewable solar disk at a&#xd;
given moment in time. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e4fcb001-f517-4295-89dd-73292e0bf3ee"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR VELOCITY FIELDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Solar velocity fields are also known as differential rotation. The sun rotates
slightly more rapidly at the equator than at the poles. Gases at the equator
make about 10 rotations, whiles gases at midlatitudes rotates 9 times and gases
at the poles rotates about 7 times. This produces a shear in the gas motions
and a pronounced E-W orientation of the magnetic field.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6d486f25-7477-4da9-96ae-0091596ed4d2"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CORONAL MASS EJECTIONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Coronal mass ejection (CME) is a huge cloud of hot plasma, occasionally
expelled from the Sun. It may accelerate ions and electrons and may travel
through interplanetary space as far as the EarthÂ¿s orbit and beyond it, often
preceded by a shock front. When the shock reaches Earth, a magnetic storm may
result.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e06822d8-b640-4d75-ac37-33ab3cc5e765"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">COSMIC RAYS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">High energy particles and photons emitted by stellar processes. The highest
energies have been observed at 10*8 Tev and are believed to come from shocks
emanating from galaxies. Solar cosmic rays are protons observed at 1 Gev,
having been accelerated by shocks associated with solar flares.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="2e83362e-d8f8-4bca-83fd-bae360ebe94b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="449ad1fb-8010-43c7-b994-178a049d4cff"

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TEMPERATURE TENDENCY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Temperature is defined, in general, as the degree of hotness or coldness
as&amp;nbsp;measured on some definite temperature scale by means of any of various
types of&amp;nbsp;thermometers.&amp;nbsp;Tendency is defined as the local rate of
change of a vector or scalar quantity&amp;nbsp;with time at a given point in space.
Because of the difficulty of measuring&amp;nbsp;instantaneous variations in the
atmosphere, variations are usually obtained&amp;nbsp;from the differences in
magnitudes over a finite period of time; and the&amp;nbsp;definition of tendency is
frequently broadened to include the local time&amp;nbsp;variations so
obtained.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="35e1f93b-99b3-4430-b477-0ecafa80d67a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="47fb8f57-2ddd-4289-b8a5-af7ffa0ee031"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">EAST ATLANTIC JET PATTERN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The East Atlantic Jet pattern is the third primary mode of low frequency variability found over the North Atlantic, appearing between April and August. This pattern also consists of a north-south dipole of anomaly centers, with one main center located over the high latitudes of the eastern North Atlantic  ... and Scandinavia, and the other center located over Northern Africa and the Mediterranean Sea. A positive phase of the EA-Jet pattern reflects an intensification of westerlies over the central latitudes of the eastern North Atlantic and over much of Europe, while a negative phase reflects a strong split-flow configuration over these regions, sometimes in association with long-lived blocking anticyclones in the vicinity of Greenland and Great Britain.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b887d3e5-4280-43d2-a34e-0f63ac086b6a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="45dd0a01-d428-4407-ba18-c074d3172b41"/>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A weather system charcterised by relatively low surface air pressure at a

for a&amp;nbsp;severe tropical cyclone with sustained surface wind speeds greater
than 64&amp;nbsp;knots (74 mph) in the western South Pacific and Indian Oceans,
equivalent of a&amp;nbsp;hurricane or typhoon.&amp;nbsp;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Soil Water Content: The water lost from soil upon drying to constant
mass&amp;nbsp;at 105 degrees Celcius; expressed either as the mass of water per
unit mass&amp;nbsp;of drysoil or as the volume of water per unit bulk volume of
soil.&amp;nbsp;For GCMD purpose, this also includes all measurements related to
soil water,&amp;nbsp;such as capcity, potential, and pressure, etc...&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="199e3af8-4cf3-48ba-8b28-b9b54756b3db"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a870d769-b815-435a-b7cc-cba5e6c27bb3"

of&amp;nbsp;organic material.&amp;nbsp;

   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TROPHIC DYNAMICS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Trophic dynamics are major interactions among organisms which involve
feeding&amp;nbsp;relationships.	  The feeding levels are called trophic levels
where all&amp;nbsp;producers belong to the first trophic level; all primary
consumers (in other&amp;nbsp;words, all herbivores), whether feeding on living or
dead producers, belong to&amp;nbsp;the second trophic level; organisms feeding on
these herbivores belong to the&amp;nbsp;third level, and so on.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="233a4d81-44f8-4b0e-8ad3-695f641729f8"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The preparation or customized data sets for delivery to customers.  Methods of&#xd; data delivery may include, but are not limited to, the following:&#xd;
- On-line download of the data over the Internet. 
- Placing an order for delivery of data via either on-line (e.g. ftp) or&#xd; off-line (e.g. CD/DVD via U.S. Mail) delivery. &#xd;
- Display of contact (who to call) information so that the user may contact&#xd; some person to obtain the data of interest.	 
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f0b7311e-df08-45fa-8dd5-33b6f74a66d9"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MAGNETIC INCLINATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the dip of the Earth's magnetic field.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FUNGI</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">One of the taxonomic kingdoms, comprising eukaryotic, non-photosynthetic

unicellular, filamentous (mycelial), or plasmoidal.

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NITROUS OXIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Nitrous oxide (N2O) is a greenhouse gas produced from ocean upwelling and soils
in tropical and temperate regions. Ice core studies have shown that nitrous

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0a81d67a-102b-4611-a38c-dbfdd7ba4e7d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GAMMA RAY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Gamma Rays (or gamma radiation) is electromagnetic radiation originating from&#xd;
transitions between energy levels of atomic nuclei. &lt;P&gt;&#xd;
A nucleus formed as a consequence of beta or alpha emission sometimes exists&#xd;
briefly in an excited energy level and makes a transition to a lower energy&#xd;
level accompanied by emission of a gamma ray photon with energy equal to the&#xd;
difference between the energies of the initial and final levels. Gamma ray&#xd;
energies from radioactive decay lie in the approximate range 10 keV6 MeV. Gamma
rays are also emitted in nuclear reactions. The boundary between x-rays and&#xd;
gamma rays is fuzzy, the latter term being most often used for electromagnetic&#xd;
radiation of nuclear origin. </skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="83150c54-5da8-4ee8-9579-19b95a8dc10c"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="fd8d9257-795c-4406-b205-cf20059d8e77"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="fd8d9257-795c-4406-b205-cf20059d8e77"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GAMMA RAY FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The portion of the electromagnetic spectrum from approximately 10^-7 to&#xd;
10^-5 micrometers.  Most often, gamma ray sensors are used to detect&#xd;
composition (from wavelengths of rays emitted by nuclei) or to measure&#xd;
soil moisture. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="0a81d67a-102b-4611-a38c-dbfdd7ba4e7d"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="73629546-592e-41ed-bfde-feb4c94415fb"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BRIGHTNESS TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The apparent temperature of the surface assuming a surface emissivity of 1.0. Setting the emissivity to one is equivalent to assuming the target is a blackbody, so the brightness temperature is defined as the temperature a blackbody would be in order to produce the radiance perceived by the sensor.
Brightness Temperature is a descriptive measure of radiation in terms of the temperature of a hypothetical blackbody emitting an identical amount of radiation at the same wavelength. The brightness temperature is obtained by applying the inverse of the Planck function to the measured radiation. Depending on the nature of the source of radiation and any subsequent absorption, the brightness temperature may be independent of, or highly dependent on, the wavelength of the radiation. Units: C
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="7a73c724-b532-45eb-a9a5-c77330b61bab"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d1407646-e34a-4a43-ae1d-afc4c229d6de"

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">INFRARED IMAGERY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A reproduction of an object by imaging the infrared radiation coming from&#xd;
the object or reflected by the object. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="7a73c724-b532-45eb-a9a5-c77330b61bab"/>
</skos:Concept>

meter and steradian.   Units: WÂ·sr^â1Â·m^â2</skos:definition>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">REFLECTED INFRARED</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reflected infrared In remote sensing, infrared which is solar-generated electromagnetic radiation that has been reflected from an object. Characteristically, reflected infrared radiation has a wavelength between 0.7 Î¼m and 3 Î¼m and is therefore near-infrared.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="7a73c724-b532-45eb-a9a5-c77330b61bab"/>

</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="68c2baba-b9b9-41d4-89bf-07488728bc4f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">THERMAL INFRARED</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Thermal infrared Infrared radiation which has a wavelength between 3.0 Î¼m and 100 Î¼m. At normal environmental temperatures objects emit infrared between these wavelengths; hotter objects, such as fires, emit infrared at wavelengths shorter than thermal infrared. Compare REFLECTED INFRARED.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="7a73c724-b532-45eb-a9a5-c77330b61bab"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="14edbe59-89a4-45ce-ac61-0143fb311da6"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">VIEWING GEOMETRY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The properties of the sensor which affect the image geometry, including the sensor scan angle, instantaneous field of view (IFOV), and internal distortions. The sensor scan angle is the angle between the sensor view vector and the downward pointing (to nadir) axis. Data with very large scan angles generally are greatly distorted, and navigation of extremely off-nadir pixels may have large errors. The area detectable on the ground is determined by the IFOV of the sensor, or the angle contained by the minimum area distinguished by the sensor.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8799f524-e313-4d2d-9428-8d672d123513"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f6b97280-74d0-4233-bd17-f9f3d9dd21c2"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HYDROCHLOROFLUOROCARBONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">HCFCs, with one or more hydrogen-carbon bonds  are slated to replace CFCs&#xd;
in most of the current applications. HCFCs are more unstable and subject&#xd;
to hydroxyl radical and  ozone attack early in their gas phase career in&#xd;
the atmosphere. Therefore, their atmospheric lifetime is projected to be&#xd;
shorter  and their chance of reaching the stratosphere&#xd;
decreased. [Spectator; v 272; p 9-11; 1994][New Scientist; v 141; p 6-7;&#xd;
1994.] &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d46a5046-e1c6-4a09-a2f1-db6a21eda611"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="14625f2a-4186-4377-a0d9-88998bb6b775"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PH</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A measure of the alkaline or acid strength of a substance.  pH is defined
as&amp;nbsp;the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration of
a&amp;nbsp;solution. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8c02f5d1-ce86-4bf5-84d5-b3496cdba6ad"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e001c431-c204-419e-af64-cc8978132abf"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BOREHOLES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Boreholes are holes drilled deep into the ground (or ocean crust). Profiles of
rock temperatures with depth can be related to the history of temperature
changes at the surface, which can be converted to estimates of air temperature.
Borehhole temperature measurements can provide estimates of local temperature
variations over time intervals of a few hundred to over a thousand years. 
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="45325a01-2522-48d3-bffa-0edf1a934d48"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8f6ad4bb-ab00-4e5a-baee-2c17335ba809"

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">IDENTIFICATION/CLASSIFICATION SYSTEMS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A service that aids in the classification of objects in an ordered system that
indicates natural relationships.  This may include taxonomy.     
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a3a5d0dd-0e8f-4649-8a55-25f9251e1008"/>

including bacteria and protozoa.

<skos:Concept rdf:about="99ea6719-b751-4a4f-95d4-aaa02e961bc1"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WAVE PERIOD</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The time for successive wave crests to pass a fixed point.   &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a04804d5-1064-48fd-a7a7-8da8e10399e1"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="40d6a3e7-89dd-4399-8fa5-bbc7a0917b4e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SKIN TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Skin temperature refers to the effective radiating temperature of the soil&#xd;
plus canopy surface. It is inferred from satellites in the 8-12 um window&#xd;
region. In climate models, it is the temperature used to determine upward&#xd;
thermal emission. The skin temperature usually shows a larger diurnal&#xd;
variation than the surface air temperature, a factor that needs to be&#xd;
considered when evaluating data/model comparisons. See [R. E.  Dickinson.&#xd;
Land surface. In K. E. Trenberth, editor, Climate System Modeling, pages&#xd;
149-171. Cambridge Univ. Press, 1992]. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a228b67f-0791-470b-a4ca-71b8da279332"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="926c1b80-6c11-40eb-ae7f-f5bcfdc43fac"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TEMPERATURE PROFILES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Temperature is defined, in general, as the degree of hotness or coldness
as&amp;nbsp;measured on some definite temperature scale by means of any of various
types of&amp;nbsp;thermometers.&amp;nbsp;In meteorology, a profile is defined as a
graph of the value of a scalar&amp;nbsp;quantity versus a horizontal, vertical, or
time scale.   It usually refers to a&amp;nbsp;vertical representation.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="35e1f93b-99b3-4430-b477-0ecafa80d67a"/>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ANTICYCLONES/CYCLONES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An anticyclone is a dome of air that exerts relatively high
atmospheric&amp;nbsp;pressure compared with the surrounding air at a given level. A
cyclone is a&amp;nbsp;weather system characterised by relatively low surface air
pressure at a given&amp;nbsp;level and a closed cyclonic wind circulation.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="08fd82a1-4370-46a2-82ea-94c0f91498a7"/>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A unit measure of electrical conduction; the facility with which a

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d14d762c-4117-438a-9093-a098a0d0e4e6"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ENSO PRECIPITATION INDEX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The goal in constructing a precipitation-based measure of ENSO was to estimate the gradient of rainfall anomalies across the Pacific basin and ensure a good relationship with SST- and pressure-based indices. Areas were selected that represent the Maritime Continent (MC) (10Â° N â 10Â°S; 90Â° E â 150Â° E) and central to eastern Pacific (P) (10Â° N â 10Â° S; 160Â° E â 100Â° W). These regions capture the largest precipitation anomalies associated with the interannual variations of the Walker circulation and contain the largest correlations between GPCP and Nino 3.4 and SOI. Within P and MC the absolute magnitude of the largest correlation is over +0.6. 

Because of the spatially varying nature of rainfall, it was decided to use a moving block average which would capture the strongest zonal gradients within the equatorial Pacific. This procedure is unlike many fixed area average indices, and allows for a realistic meridional component of the precipitation gradient and migration of the ascending and descending branches of the Walker circulation. </skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="52347642-9786-4b59-be77-02e9f307118d"/>
   <skos:changeNote>2012-06-27 10:18:41.0 [mpmorahan] Move Concepts 
delete broader relation (null); 
add broader relation (ENSO PRECIPITATION INDEX [d14d762c-4117-438a-9093-a098a0d0e4e6,22497] - PRECIPITATION INDICES [52347642-9786-4b59-be77-02e9f307118d,39663]); 
</skos:changeNote>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9abe9fdb-59f3-4bd6-b24f-b9b7e46eae7c"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ELECTRIC FIELDS/ELECTRIC CURRENTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An electric field is the region in which electric forces can be observed, e.g.&#xd;
near a charged particle.  As a field, it may also be viewed as a region of&#xd;
space&#xd;
modified by the presence of electric charges. An electric current is a&#xd;
continuous flow of electrons and/or ions, through a material which conducts&#xd;
electricity. A current usually flows in a closed circuit, without beginning or&#xd;
end. In daily life, currents are generally driven through wires by voltages&#xd;
produced by batteries or generators.  In space plasmas, currents are&#xd;
produced by the movement of charged paricles in the presence of a &#xd;
magnetic field.       &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3a942e8a-d2f2-42bf-9e83-b7b3793b100e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="64074461-95d0-4538-869a-0114e39216aa"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">OCEAN MIXED LAYER</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Also called the surface zone. The ocean mixed layer is the upper layer
of&amp;nbsp;ocean in which temperature and salinity are relatively constant with
depth.&amp;nbsp;Depending on local conditions, the surface layer may reach to 1,000
meters&amp;nbsp;(3,300 feet) or be absent entirely.   &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PRESSURE THICKNESS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">In synoptic meteorology, the vertical depth, measured in geometric
or&amp;nbsp;geopotential units, of a layer in the atmosphere bounded by two
different&amp;nbsp;constant-pressure surfaces.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="08fd82a1-4370-46a2-82ea-94c0f91498a7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="625da982-3648-43fc-a640-1b230509944e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RADAR BACKSCATTER</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The (microwave) signal reflected by elements of  an illuminated scene back&#xd;
in the direction of the radar. It is so named to make clear the difference&#xd;
between energy scattered in arbitrary  directions, and that which returns&#xd;
to the radar and thus may be received  and recorded by the sensor. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d3b7c3c0-e644-4f01-94da-dfebe854c0d1"/>
</skos:Concept>

materials&amp;nbsp;other than lime or gypsum sold in the trade.&amp;nbsp;

to sea&amp;nbsp;level.&amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f3b5489d-6723-40bf-bd55-68a0f2fc1874"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PEATLANDS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Peatlands are areas formed by a brown mass of organic matter in which
twigs,&amp;nbsp;roots, and other plant parts can still be recognized.  These areas
formed due&amp;nbsp;to lack of enough oxygen to decay vegetation completely on
land. Peatlands form&amp;nbsp;in fresh-water swamps, indicated by the plant
fossils. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="7da95c01-4b39-437e-a8d4-fd572e43f693"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c5e1c055-768e-4aa3-a0a1-3adfda8ecdca"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">NORTH ATLANTIC OSCILLATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) index is often defined as the&#xd;
difference of sea-level pressure between 2 stations situated close to&#xd;
the "centres of action" over Iceland and the Azores. Stykkisholmur&#xd;
(Iceland) is invariably used as the northern station, whereas either;&#xd;
Ponta Delgada (Azores) Lisbon (Portugal) Gibraltar are used as the&#xd;
southern station.&#xd;
Strong positive phases of the NAO tend to be associated with&#xd;
above-normal temperatures in the eastern United States and across&#xd;
northern Europe and below-normal temperatures in Greenland and&#xd;
oftentimes across southern Europe and the Middle East. They are also&#xd;
associated with above-normal precipitation over northern Europe and&#xd;
Scandinavia and below-normal precipitation over southern and central&#xd;
Europe. Opposite patterns of temperature and precipitation anomalies&#xd;
are typically observed during strong negative phases of the&#xd;
NAO. During particularly prolonged periods dominated by one particular&#xd;
phase of the NAO, abnormal height and temperature patterns are also&#xd;
often seen extending well into central Russia and north-central&#xd;
Siberia.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b887d3e5-4280-43d2-a34e-0f63ac086b6a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="19631138-70c8-4922-8052-821ec5ce093b"/>
   <skos:changeNote>2012-06-25 10:43:09.0 [mpmorahan] Insert Concept 
add narrower relation (NORTH ATLANTIC OSCILLATION [c5e1c055-768e-4aa3-a0a1-3adfda8ecdca,22585] - NAO [19631138-70c8-4922-8052-821ec5ce093b,39711]); 
</skos:changeNote>
</skos:Concept>
