<skos:Concept rdf:about="7e26f9e3-4c20-453d-bbc6-1970eca1ffb8"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PALMER DROUGHT CROP MOISTURE INDEX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The Palmer Index was developed by Wayne Palmer in the 1960s and uses temperature and rainfall information in a formula to determine dryness. It has become the semi-official drought index.
The Palmer Index is most effective in determining long term droughtÂ¿a matter of several monthsÂ¿and is not as good with short-term forecasts (a matter of weeks). It uses a 0 as normal, and drought is shown in terms of minus numbers; for example, minus 2 is moderate drought, minus 3 is severe drought, and minus
4 is extreme drought. The Crop Moisture Index (CMI) is also a formula that was developed by Wayne Palmer subsequent to his development of the Palmer Drought Index. The CMI responds more rapidly than the Palmer Index and can change considerably from week to week, so it is more effective in calculating
short-term abnormal dryness or wetness affecting agriculture. CMI is designed to indicate normal conditions at the beginning and end of the growing season; it uses the same levels as the Palmer Drought Index. It differs from the Palmer Index in that the formula places less weight on the data from previous weeks and more weight on the recent week.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="f50672b3-13d8-4206-b6c9-a1f9891ea470"/>

The Palmer Index is most effective in determining long term droughtÂ¿a matter of several monthsÂ¿and is not as good with short-term forecasts (a matter of weeks). It uses a 0 as normal, and drought is shown in terms of minus numbers; for example, minus 2 is moderate drought, minus 3 is severe drought, and minus
4 is extreme drought. The Crop Moisture Index (CMI) is also a formula that was developed by Wayne Palmer subsequent to his development of the Palmer Drought Index. The CMI responds more rapidly than the Palmer Index and can change considerably from week to week, so it is more effective in calculating
short-term abnormal dryness or wetness affecting agriculture. CMI is designed to indicate normal conditions at the beginning and end of the growing season; it uses the same levels as the Palmer Drought Index. It differs from the Palmer Index in that the formula places less weight on the data from previous weeks and more weight on the recent week.);

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6f96d1bd-f6ba-437a-9079-c575c4822248"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CHLORINE MONOXIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">ClO - a radical species which plays an important role in the breakdown&#xd;
of stratospheric ozone over Antarctica. Formed by the photolysis of CFCs&#xd;
in the stratosphere and the subsequent destruction of an ozone molecule,&#xd;
these radicals can act as a catalyst in the destruction of ozone while not&#xd;
being destroyed themselves. ClO, reacting with a oxygen atom (present from&#xd;
the Chapman Mechanism), releases a free chlorine radical once again. As a&#xd;
result, one Cl atom can destroy thousands of ozone molecules before being&#xd;
sequestered as HCl or another reservoir species (see chlorine nitrate).&#xd;
[Earth Island Journal; v 7; page 18; 1992.] [Chronicle of Higher&#xd;
Education; v 38; pages A6-A7; 1992.]  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d46a5046-e1c6-4a09-a2f1-db6a21eda611"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="72304037-ce59-451a-beeb-4258f3db296a"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">INVERSION HEIGHT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The height of the layer in which air temperature increases with
altitude,&amp;nbsp;representing an "inversion" of the typical temperature decrease
with height in&amp;nbsp;the troposphere.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="35e1f93b-99b3-4430-b477-0ecafa80d67a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ccbf4ef8-955b-4337-a45b-95affc360173"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the chemical process by which ions move from one crystal&#xd;
structure or molecular substance to another across contact boundaries. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="906e647b-2683-4ae7-9986-1aea15582b52"/>
</skos:Concept>

compounds. &#xd;

analysis.      &#xd;

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MARINE GEOCHEMISTRY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The study of the chemical composition of the various phases of the earth and&#xd;
the physical and chemical processes which have produced the observed&#xd;
distribution of the elements and nuclides in these phases. Specifically refers&#xd;
to the physical and chemical processes of the seafloor, sediments, and&#xd;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c5563d03-2f68-4dac-a50b-3b8450725356"

Ocean Temperature Advisory Service include warnings for overall temperature of
the ocean.	  &#xd;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Body temperature of the instrument, usually a  pyrgeometer. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8799f524-e313-4d2d-9428-8d672d123513"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="26637389-f4f6-47a0-9c3d-17e93ab99dea"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">EOLIAN LANDFORMS/PROCESSES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Landforms created by the processes of wind erosion or deposition of wind&#xd;
weathered surface materials. These include landforms with some of the following
geomorphic features: sand dunes, deflation hollows, and desert pavement.&#xd;
Alternative spelling "aeolian landforms."     &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b5cb1fab-7281-478f-bb3b-ff04f900b3fc"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="cb5193ab-2d7a-4b35-b7ec-f16ce78ae270"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FLUVIAL LANDFORMS/PROCESSES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">"Fluvial landforms" are features on the Earth's surface produced by the action,
i.e. erosion and deposition, of a stream or river and include such landforms as
bars, levees, braided and meandering channels, and alluvial fans.  "Fluvial
processes" are those processes included in the action of running water in a
stream or river &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b5cb1fab-7281-478f-bb3b-ff04f900b3fc"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="3c78951a-0293-4fb0-baff-ec7372fe784d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GLACIAL LANDFORMS/PROCESSES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">"Glacial landforms" are landforms derived from the erosion and deposition
caused by glaciers and ice sheets, associated meltwater, and the Earth's
rheological response.  Such landforms include drumlins, moraines, cirques,
fjords, etc.  "Glacial processes" include deposition of sediments and erosion
of the Earth's surface by grinding, scouring, and polishing effected by the
movement of glacier ice armed with rock fragments frozen into it, together with
the erosive action of meltwater streams.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b5cb1fab-7281-478f-bb3b-ff04f900b3fc"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c5ae3a71-d144-4b91-9cf0-e3cb27ce718f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CLUB MOSSES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="589875d3-4770-4fb3-871c-b37c7aff4b47"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="020585ff-91fb-421b-ba24-305d657c2231"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PRESENT WEATHER</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reports providing information on the observed weather conditions at a fixed
observation station.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="89554e78-d69d-4a38-b7f1-78d9e1e4aa57"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="792cf9f0-6d24-4de8-902c-b74e42c74fd3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AURORAE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A faint visual phenomenon associated with geomagnetic activity,&#xd;
which occurs mainly in the high-latitude night sky.  Typical&#xd;
auroras are 100 to 250 km above the ground.   The phenomenon&#xd;
caused by collisions between charged particles, atoms, and ions&#xd;
in the Earth's ionosphere and upper atmosphere.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3a942e8a-d2f2-42bf-9e83-b7b3793b100e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="882d9a10-713c-4b58-8c7b-d9af086115a3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GEOMAGNETIC FORECASTS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The levels of geomagnetic field activity, or disturbance, currently used in the
long-term (up to 27 days) forecasts are labelled qualitatively for general&#xd;
usage. For each of the three major zones (subauroral, auroral, polar cap), the&#xd;
range of activity is divided into four classifications: quiet, unsettled,&#xd;
active, storm. The actual parameter used for reporting and forecasting magnetic
activity is a daily index. It is known as DRX and is the average of the hourly&#xd;
ranges (maximum minus minimum during each hour) in the X (northward) component&#xd;
of the magnetic field intensity for a day (the UT [or GMT] day), i.e., DRX for
the&#xd;
zone is the mean of 24 values. Because this averaging process has the effect of
smoothing (filtering) the more rapid fluctuations in the field, the qualitative
descriptors are defined rather differently than for the short-term forecasts.&#xd;
Units are nanoteslas (nT).&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3a942e8a-d2f2-42bf-9e83-b7b3793b100e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e453077b-b6f3-44f0-9f3d-4408bf9a69e5"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MAGNETIC STORMS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A magnetic storm is a large-scale disturbance of the magnetosphere, often
initiated by the arrival of an interplanetary shock originating at the Sun. A
magnetic storm is marked by the injection of an appreciable number of ions from
the magnetotail into the ring current, a process accompanied by increased
auroral displays. The strengthened ring current causes a world-wide drop in the
equatorial magnetic field, taking perhaps 12 hours to reach its greatest
intensity, followed by a more gradual recovery.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3a942e8a-d2f2-42bf-9e83-b7b3793b100e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5f8a9188-d588-4782-a34b-07fa68380c41"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PLASMA WAVES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A plasma is a gas containing ions, electrons, and a magnetic field, and
therefore capable of&#xd;
conducting electric currents. A plasma wave is a set of particles under the
influence of electromagnetic fields, exhibiting wave-like motions with
amplitude and periodicity.     
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3a942e8a-d2f2-42bf-9e83-b7b3793b100e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5d290bd8-049b-4002-86c8-8acba563d0e1"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SOLAR WIND</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The solar wind is hot solar plasma spreading from the solar corona in all
directions, at a typical speed of 300-1,000 km/sec. The solar wind is
essentially the hot solar corona on expanding in all directions into the
interplanetary space. The solar wind is diverted around the Earth by the
Earth's magnetic field, although some solar particles enter the Earth's field
at the poles. The solar wind carries coronal magnetic fields by a process known
as frozen in the flux. If these frozen in fields have the same North-South
orientation as the Earth's magnetic field, energy can be transferred into the
Earth's magnetosphere, leading to geomagnetic storms.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="3a942e8a-d2f2-42bf-9e83-b7b3793b100e"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9cd875b0-210b-458f-b208-1690f50820d0"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">KARST LANDFORMS/PROCESSES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Landscapes characterized by (or the processes characterizing) the formation
and&amp;nbsp;collapse of caves and sinkholes because of carbonation weathering of
a&amp;nbsp;limestone bedrock.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d35b9ba5-d018-48a5-8f0d-92b9c55b3279"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e78ae4ce-807a-4417-ad6e-a458c6da6638"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CHLOROFLUOROCARBONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">CFCs are very stable chemical compounds, used in refrigerants, solvent, and&#xd;
(in the past in the U.S.) aerosols, which release chlorine (important) and&#xd;
fluorine (less important) into the upper atmosphere. In the stratosphere,&#xd;
CFCs are photolyzed (by incoming solar UV) to form carbon dioxide, CO2,&#xd;
hydrogen fluoride, HF, and ultimately (after multiple UV absorption&#xd;
events) chlorine radicals. These chlorine species are crucial in the&#xd;
destruction of the ozone layer over Antarctica and probably elsewhere (see&#xd;
chlorine). [Environmental Science and Technology; v 28; pages 1619-1622;&#xd;
1994.]	&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d46a5046-e1c6-4a09-a2f1-db6a21eda611"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="dd6de9e1-61e7-41bf-a2dc-9d2afc690bb3"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SNOW MELT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the rate and extent of melting snow pack(s). &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="50b8fe04-9149-4b7f-a8b2-b33b1e3aa192"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="dc9fcd27-58ac-4705-a522-6475d59cfb81"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">GRAVITY WAVES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A progressive wave occurring at the boundary between liquids of
different&amp;nbsp;densities.   &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a04804d5-1064-48fd-a7a7-8da8e10399e1"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="38dadd6d-6adb-44e2-b28a-fd18d797d052"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">STABLE ISOTOPES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any non-radioactive form of a chemical element, having the same atomic
weight&amp;nbsp;as that element (i.e. same number of protons), but a different
number of&amp;nbsp;neutrons. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6eb3919b-85ce-4988-8b78-9d0018fd8089"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5b49fd6d-3759-4b61-8b04-8309f38b2f90"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HYDROXYL</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Hydroxyl (OH) - an atom consisting of one hydrogen atom and one oxygen&#xd;
atom which does not normally exist in a stable form; this radical readily&#xd;
reacts with methane and carbon monoxide. The source of the hydroxyl&#xd;
radical in the atmosphere occurs primarily through the 1) photolysis of&#xd;
hydrogen peroxide, heat, and light and 2) the attack on water of an&#xd;
excited oxygen radical (created by the photolysis of ozone). [JAPCA; v39;&#xd;
704; 1989] [Journal of Chemical Society; v85; 577; 1989.]  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d8dcfd36-f71c-499f-84f5-43da9fee26c5"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5d7e487d-0ec4-40ef-9811-401779c31794"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DIFFERENTIAL PRESSURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The difference between static air pressure and the total air pressure
produced&amp;nbsp;by forward motion of an aircraft. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="08fd82a1-4370-46a2-82ea-94c0f91498a7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="51ce7da1-b441-474f-b7e5-cedaa04903f7"

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c1111b23-9946-497a-8829-b58da3fce720"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MARINE WEATHER/FORECAST</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Warnings and forecasts which help mariners plan and make decisions protecting
life and property.  Examples of this type of advisory includes information
about hazardous sea conditions or lower wind speeds that may affect small craft
operations, warnings for storms(ie tropical storms and hurricane warnings) &lt;BR&gt;
Example: &lt;a href="http://205.156.54.206/om/marine2.htm"&gt;&#xd;
http://205.156.54.206/om/marine2.htm&lt;/a&gt;&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="39f5a91f-c5b6-4aa9-a0c6-05530306f17b"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9becd489-f8fb-4dbb-b920-6c8399100515"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RADIOLARIANS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Radiolarians belong to the class Actinopoda, meaning "ray feet" which refers
to&amp;nbsp;the numerous slender, reinforced pseudopods that radiate from the body.
Like&amp;nbsp;foramniferans, the radiolarians are well represented in the fossil
record, for&amp;nbsp;they have ornate, silica-hardened parts that resist
degradation. Radiolarian&amp;nbsp;shells contribute to the formation of siliceous
rocks such as chert. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="663a2ea2-e2bf-4209-ae9b-334c8222b106"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a74059fe-6b15-4b55-8ea5-4a65b66c7e11"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ALKALINITY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The alkalinity of seawater is the combined negative charges due to&#xd;
hydrogen carbonate and carbonate ions expressed in molal concentrations.&#xd;
Alkalinity is based on seawater being electrically neutral and is&#xd;
determined by titration (and therefore given the subscript t). &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8c02f5d1-ce86-4bf5-84d5-b3496cdba6ad"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4453ac7c-1869-4aef-8b06-dbdc9e63e245"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AMMONIA</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A gaseous compound of one nitrogen atom and three hydrogen atoms, NH3, that
is&amp;nbsp;highly water-soluble. A dissolved form, ammonium, NH4+, is a nutrient
and is&amp;nbsp;listed as a detailed variable under ammonia. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CARBON DIOXIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A gaseous compound of one carbon atom and two oxygen atoms, CO2. It
is&amp;nbsp;colorless, odorless, incombustible, and is soluble in water. Its
dissolution in&amp;nbsp;seawater is important to understanding the global carbon
cycle. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CARBONATE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A dissolved ion of carbonic acid, with the chemical formula CO3(-2), formed
by&amp;nbsp;dissolution of carbon dioxide in water. Other forms of carbonate, such
as&amp;nbsp;bicarbonate, HCO3-, are included with this variable as detailed
variables. &amp;nbsp;

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A measure of the alkaline or acid strength of a substance.  pH is defined

a&amp;nbsp;solution. &amp;nbsp;

   <skos:broader rdf:resource="6eb3919b-85ce-4988-8b78-9d0018fd8089"/>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The average height of the highest one-third of all waves occurring in

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4e4d3c18-cdd4-474a-a936-6e127ec526f7"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SWELLS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The long-period, undulating waves that propagate energy to great
distances&amp;nbsp;from the point of generation; the source of "breakers" along the
beach.    &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a04804d5-1064-48fd-a7a7-8da8e10399e1"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0d91f6d9-44c4-4418-90b0-00feb09c6fc0"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WAVE FREQUENCY</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The number of waves passing a fixed point in a given period of time.    &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a04804d5-1064-48fd-a7a7-8da8e10399e1"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0fc68280-1361-43e1-bc5a-40c49e9679b7"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WAVE HEIGHT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Vertical distance between a wave crest and the adjacent wave troughs.    &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a04804d5-1064-48fd-a7a7-8da8e10399e1"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WAVE LENGTH</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The horizontal distance between two successive wave crests (or troughs) in
a&amp;nbsp;progressive wave.   &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="a04804d5-1064-48fd-a7a7-8da8e10399e1"/>

under Wave&amp;nbsp;Speed/Direction.   &amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="daab3b2a-1fe7-4ad9-8340-1a7cfa54a2ac"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">METHANE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Methane (CH4) is a greenhouse gas and is seen in polar ice cores. From the ice
core record, it is known that methane rose rapidly whenever climate changed
from glacial to interglacial conditions (during "deglaciation"). Warming of
water bathing the seafloor could have led to large-scale release of methane
from the melting of methane ice.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="dba19648-3f52-48ba-b00b-8527d44c4d74"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="868b87a1-d8c2-49b3-8bbd-9cbbed115271"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">WILDFIRES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">An uncontrolled fire in combustible vegetation that occurs in the countryside or a wilderness area. Other names such as brush fire, bushfire, forest fire, desert fire, grass fire, hill fire, peat fire, vegetation fire, and veldfire may be used to describe the same phenomenon depending on the type of vegetation being burned. A wildfire differs from other fires by its extensive size, the speed at which it can spread out from its original source, its potential to change direction unexpectedly, and its ability to jump gaps such as roads, rivers and fire breaks. Wildfires are characterized in terms of the cause of ignition, their physical properties such as speed of propagation, the combustible material present, and the effect of weather on the fire.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="ec0e2762-f57a-4fdc-b395-c8d7d5590d18"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="5e693789-87a8-4f94-9b5d-a50cecf55e24"/>
   <skos:changeNote>2012-10-15 10:26:14.0 [tbs1979] added definition 
update PrefLabel (WILDFIRES); 
</skos:changeNote>

A wildfire differs from other fires by its extensive size, the speed at which it can spread out from its original source, its potential to change direction unexpectedly, and its ability to jump gaps such as roads, rivers and fire breaks. Wildfires are characterized in terms of the cause of ignition, their physical properties such as speed of propagation, the combustible material present, and the effect of weather on the fire.);

<skos:Concept rdf:about="b632d0cc-d4b0-458e-a182-16bbd2a5ab05"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">OXYGEN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A colorless, odorless, gaseous element, constituting 21 percent of the volume
of the atmsophere, and essential for aerobic forms of life. Gaseous oxygen has
a chemical forumla of O2. Despite its abundance in air, the concentration of
oxygen in water is usually quite low, at just a few parts per million.
Nevertheless, this concentration is a good indicator of water quality. If it is
too low, many organisms, including fish, will die.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8c02f5d1-ce86-4bf5-84d5-b3496cdba6ad"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ed5106fd-a73f-4203-87a3-9c9e7e85dcfc"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HYDROFLUOROCARBONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The HFCs are a class of replacements for CFCs. Because they do not&#xd;
contain chlorine or bromine, they do not deplete the ozone layer. All HFCs&#xd;
have an ozone depletion potential of 0. Some HFCs have high GWPs (Global&#xd;
Warming Potentials). HFCs are numbered according to a standard scheme. The&#xd;
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) provides more&#xd;
detailed information about HFCs on their  &lt;A&#xd;
HREF="http://www.cmdl.noaa.gov/noah/flask/hfc.html"&gt;web site&lt;/a&gt;. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d46a5046-e1c6-4a09-a2f1-db6a21eda611"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5d7f7568-bfc3-4c11-b446-c4f6488c8ae9"

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">STRAIN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the measurement, analysis, or modeling of strain that has
occurred in the Earth's crust, either through in-situ measurements, or through
laboratory experiments. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="1e17c8d3-81d0-473c-8f24-d2a4ea52b6b9"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d2db293d-2ed7-4831-9794-a2cf903e4d4d"

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e02b0b50-a0f2-4c47-841b-9689fdb99121"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">POTENTIAL TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Measurement of water temperature taking water's&amp;nbsp;compressibility into
account, provided no heat exchange of the water sample&amp;nbsp;with its
surroundings.	 This is important because water temperature is
higher&amp;nbsp;under the higher pressure conditions of the deep ocean compared to
the&amp;nbsp;temperature of that same water at the lower pressure conditions of the
ocean&amp;nbsp;surface.    &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="251c87cd-03b3-464f-8390-8ede2fec28fc"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="68772b70-e493-48d5-b063-00b9d2dd4078"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">THERMOCLINE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The zone of the ocean in which temperature decreases rapidly with depth.
&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="251c87cd-03b3-464f-8390-8ede2fec28fc"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5569b7a3-3a4b-4799-8c68-98126757074b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HEAT FLUX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The measurement of the heat flux or heat loss from open ocean areas within
the&amp;nbsp;sea ice pack is important for the study of energy balance in the polar
regions&amp;nbsp;and local and regional climatology. Heat loss through the open
water is 100&amp;nbsp;times more than through thick ice. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="860e2af9-ce29-4f3f-b027-ae3747eb3e01"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5fa04fa9-06c7-41c7-98f9-f92756f080ea"

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE EDGES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The ice edge is the demarcation at any given time between open water and&#xd;
the sea (can also refer to river and lake ice) whether fast or drifting.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="860e2af9-ce29-4f3f-b027-ae3747eb3e01"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE FLOES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Floe refers to any relatively flat piece of ice 20 m or more across. Floes&#xd;
are subdivided according to horizontal extent: small, medium, big, vast,&#xd;
giant.	&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="860e2af9-ce29-4f3f-b027-ae3747eb3e01"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="d9667e73-30db-45f9-861c-e0a5caaf2bf0"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE GROWTH/MELT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Melt of the ice can occur at various stages: puddle, thaw holes, dried&#xd;
ice, rotten ice, flodded ice, and frozen puddle. Developing sea ice (or&#xd;
growth) takes on the following stages: New Ice, Youg Ice, First-Year Ice,&#xd;
Old Ice. Lake Ice development goes through the following stages: New Lake&#xd;
Ice, Thin Lake Ice, Medium Lake Ice, Thick Lake Ice, and Very Thick Lake&#xd;
Ice.   &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="860e2af9-ce29-4f3f-b027-ae3747eb3e01"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="ce3a1edd-a2fe-4efd-8971-9dd7b97b6d79"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE ROUGHNESS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The small-scale variation in the relief of the terrain surface (in this&#xd;
case the surface of the ice). Remote sensing instruments, such as radar&#xd;
and microwave sensors, have been able to detect the degree of roughness of&#xd;
sea, lake, and river ice.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="860e2af9-ce29-4f3f-b027-ae3747eb3e01"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6bfd4d52-fad4-470f-9da0-fa7df2a5b4aa"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE TYPES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Ice Types is a general term applied to sea, river, and lake ice to&#xd;
describe attributes such as age, stage of development or growth, or&#xd;
surface feature.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="860e2af9-ce29-4f3f-b027-ae3747eb3e01"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5d7ea074-225b-4221-b122-e6a085cdce24"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PACK ICE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pack ice refers to high concentrations of sea ice. When concentrations are&#xd;
60% or less, then the term drift ice is used.  &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="860e2af9-ce29-4f3f-b027-ae3747eb3e01"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="cece77b6-42bf-44f6-9193-050cbc5f4cf7"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">REFLECTANCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The reflectance properties of ice bodies. A smooth ice surface will act as&#xd;
a near-specular reflector. As surface roughness increases, the reflection&#xd;
becomes diffuse. It is the ratio of the intensity of reflected radiation&#xd;
to that of the incident radiation on a surface. The suffix (-ance) implies&#xd;
a property of that particular specimen surface. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="860e2af9-ce29-4f3f-b027-ae3747eb3e01"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="3488309d-ef21-4d60-81a3-78fb99ffa756"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEA ICE AGE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The age of the sea ice is usually a distinction between first-year
and&amp;nbsp;multiyear ice. Multiyear sea ice is usually thicker, has more ridges,
and can&amp;nbsp;be more of a hinderance to ship travel than first-year ice.
Microwave remote&amp;nbsp;sensing studies have shown that first-year sea ice has a
higher emissivity at&amp;nbsp;the 1.55 cm wavelength than multiyear ice, thus
making it possible to&amp;nbsp;distinguish between different ice ages from
satellites. Ice age can also be&amp;nbsp;qualitatively determined using visible,
infrared and radar wavelengths from&amp;nbsp;satellites. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="860e2af9-ce29-4f3f-b027-ae3747eb3e01"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8012fda7-3ea4-4ef2-bb4e-0f66d4d9e850"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SEA ICE CONCENTRATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The ratio of the area of the water surface covered by ice as a fraction of
the&amp;nbsp;whole area. Sea ice concentration has been monitored by polar
orbiting&amp;nbsp;satellites at all wavelengths. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="860e2af9-ce29-4f3f-b027-ae3747eb3e01"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SNOW DEPTH</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the thickness of snow pack throughout the year.

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f0d4b06b-c498-4760-bc92-877e28f3a098"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ISOTOPES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Isotopes are a form of an element with a certain number of neutrons, for&#xd;
example carbon exists in three isotopes: C12, C13, and C14. Some isotopes are&#xd;
naturally unstable and spontaneously decay at a fixed rate; other isotopes are&#xd;
stable.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="860e2af9-ce29-4f3f-b027-ae3747eb3e01"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a5aa7055-642d-4442-9b4b-76a759e15257"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">HYDROSTATIC PRESSURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The pressure in a fluid in hydrostatic equilibrium - that is , the
downward&amp;nbsp;pressure at a point due solely to the weight of fluid in a column
of unit&amp;nbsp;cross-sectional area. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="08fd82a1-4370-46a2-82ea-94c0f91498a7"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="6f4e850f-84e4-466f-b5ad-2032ea2187ea"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">RADIOISOTOPES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any radioactive form of a chemical element, having the same atomic weight
as&amp;nbsp;that element (i.e. same number of protons), but a different number of
neutrons.&amp;nbsp;Used in a variety of oceanic applications such as dating and
movement of water&amp;nbsp;masses. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8c02f5d1-ce86-4bf5-84d5-b3496cdba6ad"/>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="e86ea427-f735-4998-af16-9bd619df4974"

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any measure related to the contamination and toxicology of food stuffs
caused&amp;nbsp;by improper handeling, improper storage, improper preparation,
etc... Food&amp;nbsp;safety; Deleterious food microorganisms; Food toxicology and
spoilage: defects,&amp;nbsp;diseases, adulteration, contamination; Residues from

<skos:Concept rdf:about="37dac8df-b04b-4561-91fb-886e1bded2c1"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CARBON DIOXIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A minor but very important component of the atmosphere, carbon dioxide traps
infrared radiation. Atmospheric CO2 has increased about 25 percent since the
early 1800s, with an estimated increase of 10 percent since 1958 (burning
fossil fuels is the leading cause of increased CO2, deforestation the second
major cause). The increased amounts of CO2 in the atmosphere enhance the
greenhouse effect, blocking heat from escaping into space and contributing to
the warming of Earth's lower atmosphere. (Earth Observatory)&#xd;
The most direct method for measuring atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations
for periods before direct sampling is to measure bubbles of air (fluid or gas
inclusions) trapped in the Antarctic or Greenland ice caps. The most widely
accepted of such studies come from a variety of Antarctic cores and indicate
that atmospheric CO2 levels were about 260Â¿280uL/L immediately before
industrial emissions began and did not vary much from this level during the
preceding 10,000 years. &#xd;
The longest ice core record comes from Vostok, Antarctica, where ice has been
sampled to a depth of 3,600 meters, corresponding to an age of 420,000 years
before the present. During this time, the atmospheric carbon dioxide
concentration has varied between 180Â¿210 uL/L during ice ages, increasing to
280Â¿300 uL/L during warmer
interglacials.(http://www.nationmaster.com/encyclopedia/Carbon-dioxide)
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="dba19648-3f52-48ba-b00b-8527d44c4d74"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="3643618f-3af3-4c69-8beb-2ad14141a176"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE CORE AIR BUBBLES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Trapped gases in ice-core bubbles are highly reliable records of atmospheric
composition in reconstructing past climates.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="dba19648-3f52-48ba-b00b-8527d44c4d74"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="591d2038-5c5e-47bf-a551-1b28f33d1f05"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">IONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the measurement of various electrostatically charged&#xd;
compounds found in ice cores. Ions can be analyzed to infer human, biological,
and volcanic activity, as well as ocean water conditions. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="dba19648-3f52-48ba-b00b-8527d44c4d74"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="63c7d604-707e-4c38-8baf-19a620e61917"

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PARTICULATE MATTER</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Particulate matter in ice cores (continental dust, volcanic ash, diatoms, and
pollen)can provide information on past climate conditions and climate
variability.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="dba19648-3f52-48ba-b00b-8527d44c4d74"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8cb47594-3af6-4f4f-8ba1-4299a6d6887e"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LAKE ICE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the measurement, and analysis to ice formation on inland
bodies&amp;nbsp;of salt or fresh water.&amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="16329a9b-72ea-4b46-b507-2ce389c63f50"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FOREST FIRE DANGER INDEX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A forest fire danger index (FDI) or burning index (BI) is a relative number&#xd;
related to the contribution that fire behavior makes to the amount of effort&#xd;
needed to contain a fire of a specified fuel type. The index may be calculated&#xd;
differently by different agencies around the world.&#xd;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="080389c4-68d4-41ee-ab89-070794038c8e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CARBON MONOXIDE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A colorless, odorless, and very toxic gas; molecular formula CO. It is found
in&amp;nbsp;trace quantities in the natural atmosphere, but also produced by the
incomplete&amp;nbsp;combustion of carbonaceous gasses.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="77397026-09c9-44e0-b85f-77b2bc9b1630"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="7a0bd777-be0d-43c8-80eb-5ac58f4832de"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">POTENTIAL TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The temperature a dry air parcel would have if brought dry adiabatically
from&amp;nbsp;its initial state to the standard pressure of 1000 hectopascals
(millibars). &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="35e1f93b-99b3-4430-b477-0ecafa80d67a"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f2d6aa01-5070-4147-bae1-4b2cad2c3987"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TRACE METALS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Trace metals are metals in extremely small quantities, almost at the molecular
level, that reside in or are present in animal and plant cells and tissue.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8c02f5d1-ce86-4bf5-84d5-b3496cdba6ad"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SPECIES COMPETITION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Competition is the interaction of two species where they both use the
same&amp;nbsp;limited resource or harm one another while seeking a resource.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="58f39353-7e1c-4884-9501-376cd0377fbf"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SPECIES PREDATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Predation is where one animal eats all or part of a second animal
species.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="58f39353-7e1c-4884-9501-376cd0377fbf"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="abc96dce-cbae-43a4-b7c2-2ff02276b030"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SCAVENGING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Scavenging is the manner of feeding where the animal feeds on dead animal
and&amp;nbsp;plant matter. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="58f39353-7e1c-4884-9501-376cd0377fbf"/>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Symbiosis is the intimate living together or association of two kinds
of&amp;nbsp;organisms.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="58f39353-7e1c-4884-9501-376cd0377fbf"/>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Life History of a population are long-term attributes, such as age at

changes in&amp;nbsp;an organism's environment.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="58f39353-7e1c-4884-9501-376cd0377fbf"/>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MIGRATORY RATES/ROUTES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Migration is a persistent movement across different habitats in response

and&amp;nbsp;routes are observed for many migrating species.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Range Changes with respect to Migration include forays outside the home

opportunities.&amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5efc3bc4-6403-4e33-ba23-5418fbc026b1"

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BIOLUMINESCENCE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Bioluminescence is a flashing of light that emanates from an organism
when&amp;nbsp;excited electrons of ATP phosphorylates, luciferins (highly
fluorescent&amp;nbsp;substances), return to a lower energy level. An example of
bioluminescence are&amp;nbsp;fireflies which give off these flashes of light as the
luciferases convert&amp;nbsp;chemical energy to light energy. &amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="58f39353-7e1c-4884-9501-376cd0377fbf"/>
</skos:Concept>

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TOTAL TEMPERATURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Measurement made using a temperature probe (e.g. thermistor) which is the
sum of the ambient air temperature plus the heat of friction caused by the high
speed air passing over the probe.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8799f524-e313-4d2d-9428-8d672d123513"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="733092b1-4256-433a-85fe-78c912f21f80"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TOTAL PRESSURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure when these concepts
are&amp;nbsp;applicable. (Also called Stagnation Pressure)&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="8799f524-e313-4d2d-9428-8d672d123513"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The degree to which an electrical current can pass through water due to

conductivity and&amp;nbsp;temperature.   &amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="997dc5a6-d83f-4d59-8c5a-1d901b069830"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">STATISTICAL APPLICATIONS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Statistical Applications are defined as Data Analysis and Visualization Services that are designed to process Earth science data in a primarily numerical environment and that allow the user of the service to apply statistical or mathematical algorithms to the data in a non-graphical manner. Mathematical Applications may or may not include graphical visualization&amp;nbsp;functionality but do not have visualization as their primary operation. EXAMPLES: A Spreadsheet, SPSS.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="41adc080-c182-4753-9666-435f8b1c913f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4f938731-d686-4d89-b72b-ff60474bb1f0"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">CALIBRATION/VALIDATION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Calibration and Validation are defined as Data Analysis and Visualization Services that are designed to allow, in the case of calibration services, a user of the service to properly adjust Earth science data to achieve optimal accuracy and/or precision or, in the case of validation services, allow the user of the service to confirm the accuracy and/or precision of Earth science data.  EXAMPLES: An algorithm to correct for the decaying orbit of a satellite (calibration). A reference data set created under controlled circumstances for comparison with other data (validation).</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="41adc080-c182-4753-9666-435f8b1c913f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="7c23be3f-89fc-4a85-83fc-128b0837ee83"

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ICE GROWTH/MELT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the measurement of ice growth/melting rates, and annual&#xd;
changes in those rates. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="50b8fe04-9149-4b7f-a8b2-b33b1e3aa192"/>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Any type of rapidly varying perturbation to Earth's magnetic field caused by

Advisory will incorporate information on geomagnetic storms that may interfere
with some technology, including satellite communications.&#xd;

period 1950-79. The anomalies are with respect to a 1950-79 climatology.</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c7fa79e4-67a1-45da-b393-a1b89d54a1a5"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">COMMON SENSE CLIMATE INDEX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The Common Sense Climate Index (Hansen et al. 1998) is a simple&#xd;
measure of the degree (if any) to which practical climate change is&#xd;
occurring. The index is a composite of several everyday climate&#xd;
indicators. It is expected to have positive values when warming occurs&#xd;
and negative values for cooling. If the Index reaches and consistently&#xd;
maintains a value of 1 or more, the climate change should be&#xd;
noticeable to most people who have lived at that location for a few&#xd;
decades.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="e8580cbb-701a-4ab1-a40f-5fae4ae1ea24"/>
   <skos:changeNote>2012-06-26 10:14:51.0 [gee-cee] Move Concepts 
delete broader relation (null); 
add broader relation (COMMON SENSE CLIMATE INDEX [c7fa79e4-67a1-45da-b393-a1b89d54a1a5,22893] - TEMPERATURE INDICES [e8580cbb-701a-4ab1-a40f-5fae4ae1ea24,39791]); 
</skos:changeNote>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="5e7a091a-894f-423f-a431-ab52cf205311"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ISOSTATIC REBOUND</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Pertaining to the measurement, mapping, or processes involved in isostatic
rebound, due to glacial removal, mountain building, the removal of water
weight, or similar effects. &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="1e17c8d3-81d0-473c-8f24-d2a4ea52b6b9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="71e9bc66-6f8c-41ec-8b22-2fe390223639"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PLATE TECTONICS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">A theory of global tectonics in which the lithosphere is &#xd;
divided into a number of plates whose pattern of horizontal movement is &#xd;
that of torsionally rigid bodies that interact with one another at their &#xd;
boundaries, causing seismic and tectonic activity along these boundaries.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="1e17c8d3-81d0-473c-8f24-d2a4ea52b6b9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="64ccd7be-577b-4784-8072-8c456aab2185"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LITHOSPHERIC PLATE MOTION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The rate and direction of movement between two torsionally rigid thin segments&#xd;
of the Earth's lithosphere (lithospheric plates). &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="1e17c8d3-81d0-473c-8f24-d2a4ea52b6b9"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="4adc15b8-0c18-4ccd-a6ec-75be82df5359"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">PLATE BOUNDARIES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Zones of seismic and tectonic activity along the edges of &#xd;
lithosphere plates, presumed to indicate relative motion between plates.&#xd;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c53868ba-608c-495c-a65d-038f53f7267f"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DIMENSION MEASUREMENT SERVICES</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Services that compute dimensions of objects visible in an image or other geospatial data.</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="a69f9faf-f730-4eba-9e38-0f72b0544bbe"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">BIVARIATE ENSO TIMESERIES INDEX</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The BEST index was designed to be simple to calculate and to provide a long time period ENSO index for research purposes. Nino 3.4 has traditionally been used as a measure of ENSO strength in the tropical Pacific. However, it's use alone neglects explicit atmospheric processes. By adding the SOI or Southern Oscillation Index (the pressure difference between Tahiti and Darwin), these processes are more directly included. In addition, older SST values are at least partially reconstructed and not explicitly measured. By including the SOI, which is better measured historically, the effect of biases in the SST data introduced by the reconstruction technique are reduced. A more detailed explanation how the index was created is available (http://www.esrl.noaa.gov/psd/people/cathy.smith/best/details.html).</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b887d3e5-4280-43d2-a34e-0f63ac086b6a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="94ecf3ab-aa20-4756-8e3b-629795b3d5b5"/>
   <skos:changeNote>2012-06-25 10:25:42.0 [mpmorahan] Insert Concept 
add narrower relation (BIVARIATE ENSO TIMESERIES INDEX [a69f9faf-f730-4eba-9e38-0f72b0544bbe,22905] - BEST [94ecf3ab-aa20-4756-8e3b-629795b3d5b5,39691]); 
</skos:changeNote>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="9613f08d-da11-4ed0-989e-c0c830870044"

the same level of reflection as that observed from the	sample&#xd;
target. &#xd;
</skos:definition>

   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Web-Based Geographic Information Systems (GIS) are defined as Data Analysis and Visualization Services designed for use on the web. These services include GIS map viewers, GIS web services, GIS applications, and software tools specifically used for creating GIS applications for the web.
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0dd83b2a-e83f-4a0c-a1ff-2fbdbbcce62d"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">MOBILE GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Mobile Geographic Information Systems are defined as GIS applications that have moved from the office into the field. A mobile GIS enables field-based personnel to capture, store, update, manipulate, analyze, and display geographic information. Mobile GIS integrates one or more of the following technologies: (1) Mobile devices, (2) Global positioning system, and (3) Wireless communications for Internet GIS access.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="794e3c3b-791f-44de-9ff3-358d8ed74733"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="11e14ac8-e9f3-4737-b83d-98668ad975ed"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">SIGMA NAUGHT</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The conventional measure of the strength of radar signals reflected by a distributed scatterer, usually expressed in dB. It is a normalized dimensionless number, comparing the strength observed to that expected from an area of one square meter. Sigma naught is defined with respect to the nominally horizontal plane, and in general has a significant variation with incidence angle, wavelength, and polarization, as well as with properties of the scattering surface itself (see speckle, and statistics). </skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="d3b7c3c0-e644-4f01-94da-dfebe854c0d1"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="41ebe049-230e-4ff7-acb1-43de68ace83e"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"

   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ALBEDO</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Albedo is the ratio of the radiation (radiant energy or luminous
energy)&amp;nbsp;reflected by a surface to that incident on it. Snow and cloud
surfaces have a&amp;nbsp;high albedo, because most of the energy of the visible
solar spectrum is&amp;nbsp;reflected. Vegetation and ocean surfaces have low
albedo, because they absorb a&amp;nbsp;large fraction of the energy. Clouds are the
chief cause of variations in the&amp;nbsp;Earth's albedo.&amp;nbsp;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="aa35a52f-e3d9-41bd-abd2-ec7e1a8101d1"/>
</skos:Concept>

Pacific off the&amp;nbsp;west coast of Mexico to the International Dateline.&amp;nbsp;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="83b711e1-3fb5-4ef3-bafb-783e8239a4b5"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">TROPICAL/NORTHERN HEMISPHERE PATTERN</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The Tropical/ Northern Hemisphere pattern was first classified by Mo and Livezey (1986), and appears as a prominent mode from November-February. The pattern consists of one primary anomaly center over the Gulf of Alaska and a separate anomaly center of opposite sign over the Hudson Bay. A weaker area of anomalies having similar sign to the Gulf of Alaska anomaly extends across Mexico and the extreme southeastern United States. This pattern reflects large-scale changes in both the location and eastward extent of the Pacific jet stream, and also in the strength and position of the climatological mean Hudson Bay Low. Thus, the pattern significantly modulates the flow of marine air into North America, as well as the southward transport of cold Canadian air into the north-central United States.</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="b887d3e5-4280-43d2-a34e-0f63ac086b6a"/>
   <skos:narrower rdf:resource="8eac6c91-8af5-4b1b-8dc3-89cd4871915f"/>

A weaker area of anomalies having similar sign to the Gulf of Alaska anomaly extends across Mexico and the extreme southeastern United States. This pattern reflects large-scale changes in both the location and eastward extent of the Pacific jet stream, and also in the strength and position of the climatological mean Hudson Bay Low. Thus, the pattern significantly modulates the flow of marine air into North America, as well as the southward transport of cold Canadian air into the north-central United States.

<skos:Concept rdf:about="fb47fa33-8b9b-4655-b448-1acf8a629015"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">FROST/FREEZE WARNING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Reports providing information on when below freezing temperatures are expected
and may cause significant damage to plants, crops, or fruit trees.     &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="89554e78-d69d-4a38-b7f1-78d9e1e4aa57"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="8b1af14c-25f1-42bb-bba9-24ee5cee4e43"

   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">LARVACEANS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="c34af039-4868-41f0-aaf0-39e8e9554e03"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="f6c057c9-c789-4cd5-ba22-e9b08aae152b"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">AQUACULTURE</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">The farming of aquatic organisms including fish, molluscs, crustaceans and
aquatic plants with some sort of intervention in the rearing process to enhance
production, such as regular stocking, feeding, protection from predators, etc. 
Also referred to as Mariculture - Marine fish farming (aquaculture). Raising of
marine animals and plants in the controlled or selected aquatic environments
for any commercial, recreational, or public purpose.&#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="f27ad52c-3dfd-4788-851a-427e60ae1b8f"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="fa57b0a0-9723-4195-bdd1-4f26aefa0e07"

of species in marine and non-marine environments, excludes fish farming,&#xd;

<skos:Concept rdf:about="c75db4f8-716c-47a8-a2f4-34e5a48296b0"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">ARCHIVING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Archiving services are defined as Data Handling Services that function to provide storage of Earth science data for later retrieval. Archive services may store the data in any manner but must allow for access and retrieval by a data requestor. This service also includes any tools that facilitate the handling of data into (storage/ingest) or out of (access/retrieval) an archive. EXAMPLES: NASA's Distributed Active Archive Centers (DAACs), Library of Congress.      &#xd;
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="02d92216-70c6-437c-8c15-2b76f2132921"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="07291e32-fd39-45e8-a603-7443cb780976"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DATA MINING</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Data mining is a variety of techniques used to identify nuggets of information or decision-making knowledge in bodies of data, and extracting these in such a way that they can be put to use in areas such as decision support, prediction, forecasting, and estimation. The data is often voluminous but, as it stands, of low value as no direct use can be made of it; it is the hidden information in the data that is useful.     
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="02d92216-70c6-437c-8c15-2b76f2132921"/>
</skos:Concept>

   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DATA COMPRESSION</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Compression services are defined as Data Handling Services that reduce the proportions (file size, physical size, volume or mass) of Earth science data. Data can be reduced by mechanical means (e.g., dehydration) or by &#xd; computer algorithms (e.g., .zip). EXAMPLES: Dehydration or Deflation (mechanical). ZIP, TAR, JAR, GZIP (computer).&#xd;
</skos:definition>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="80e34388-3d24-4ff9-8d23-784fad52c432"
   xml:base="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concept/"
   xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:skos="http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#">
   <skos:inScheme rdf:resource="http://gcmdservices.gsfc.nasa.gov/kms/concepts/concept_scheme/sciencekeywords"/>
   <skos:prefLabel xml:lang="en">DATA NETWORKING/DATA TRANSFER TOOLS</skos:prefLabel>
   <skos:definition xml:lang="en">Data networking tools refer to tools and services that facilitate the ability&#xd; of two or more computers to communicate together and to share data with each&#xd; other.&#xd; Data transfer tools refer to tools and services that manage or facilitate the&#xd; transmission of data from one computer or device to another. For example, grid&#xd; computing is a form of networking that harnesses the processing cycles of all&#xd; computers connected in a network to solve problems that are too large for any&#xd; one computer. In the Earth sciences, these tools facilitate the networking of&#xd; large volumes of satellite data or climate model output data.
</skos:definition>
   <skos:broader rdf:resource="02d92216-70c6-437c-8c15-2b76f2132921"/>
</skos:Concept>

<skos:Concept rdf:about="0d67baa7-19c7-440b-b658-1bda9a8e09bf"
